headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Roper Technologies Fourth Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. 
I will now turn the call over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Deanna, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our fourth quarter financial results. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; an
componenttext:
Thank you, Deanna, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our fourth quarter financial results. 
Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Rob Crisci, Vice President of Planning and Investor Relations. 
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also on our website. 
If you turn to Slide 2, we begin with our safe harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties, as described on this page, and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information. 
Next slide. Today, we will be discussing our income statement results for the quarter, primarily on an adjusted non-GAAP basis. A full reconciliation between GAAP and adjusted measures is in our press release this morning and also included as a part of this presentation on our website. 
For the fourth quarter the difference between our GAAP and adjusted results consists of 3 items: First, we completed the divestiture of ABEL Pumps during the fourth quarter, resulting in a pretax gain of $70.9 million. This was partially offset by an impairment charge of $9.5 million relating to an imaging investment we made in 2007; second, a $4 million purchase accounting adjustment to acquire deferred revenue relating to software acquisitions made in 2015. This represents revenue that those companies would have recognized if not for our acquisition. Finally, we have a $2.6 million inventory step up expense relating to the acquisition of RF IDeas. 
Now if you please turn to Slide 4, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. And after his remarks, we will take questions from our telephone systems. Brian?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. So we'll start off here with our Q4 results. They were flat to last year, we'll talk a little bit about that, at $948 million. It's exactly the same number as last year but with lots of activity to get you there.
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. So we'll start off here with our Q4 results. They were flat to last year, we'll talk a little bit about that, at $948 million. It's exactly the same number as last year but with lots of activity to get you there. We had another 2 points of FX headwind in the quarter and then the acquisitions net of the ABEL divestiture offset the organic shortfall in energy primarily. 
The Industrial and Energy markets declined in the fourth quarter and really had less seasonal adjustment favorable in the fourth quarter than normally, and we'll talk about that when we get to that segment. But we have very strong growth in Medical and the RF segments. Our gross margins continue to escalate. They were up 190 basis points in the quarter to 61.8%. 
Our EBITDA margin also hit 35.9%, that's the EBITDA margin, not the gross margin. And EBITDA was up another 2% to $341 million, which is sort of an annualized run rate of $1.364 billion. 
Our free cash flow was up to $261 million, and it's 140% cash conversion. And we also issued 5- and 10-year bond, which totaled $900 million in the month of December, and deployed over $700 million in a quarter in some very attractive acquisitions, so we enjoyed good acquisition in the quarter and terrific discipline capital deployment. 
Next slide. If we look at the income statement in the quarter, you can see that, while the orders and the revenue were exactly the same as the year ago, no 2 businesses would have been the same. So this was a case of watching the ducks on the pond with a whole lot of paddling going on underneath it. 
The book-to-bill at 0.98 is actually pretty good for the fourth quarter. Just to give you some sense of history in 2011, our book-to-bill in the fourth quarter was 0.94. In '12, it was 0.95 and in '13, it was flat 1 or by 1. In '14, it was 0.98; and this year, it's 0.98. So from a historical perspective, it's about what we would expect to see. 
Our gross profit as we said was up from 59.9% to 61.8% and operating income, the margin was 30.1 and that absorbed 70 basis points of higher noncash amortization as acquisitions came in. 
The interest expense was up $5 million due the bond issuance, so a little bit more drawn at the revolver during the quarter. 
Net earnings were down 1% from $187 to $186, which you can see from the interest. 
Next slide. Here, we shift into the full year enterprise results. 
So next slide. On the enterprise results, the whole point of the year really was our ability to demonstrate nimble execution in the field and then deploy capital in really a tough acquisition market with great transactions. 
So if you look at records, everything, once again, was a record. We had the most orders, the highest revenue, the best margins, the highest net earnings, and best EBITDA and cash flow of any year in our history. The growth was led by Medical and RF. We had continued margin improvement throughout the year. The gross margin was up 140 basis points on a year to 60.7% and the operating margin was up 80 basis points to 29% offering profit margin and of course, EBITDA was higher. 
A very strong cash flow. We were up 11% in cash flow for the year, and that was 26% of the revenue. Our free cash flow was also up 11% and our cash conversion on a free cash flow basis was 132%. 
We deployed $1.8 billion in acquisitions in 2015, with almost entirely a focus on software and medical technologies. 
All of our acquisitions are really very high-margin businesses. They're all asset light, they're very specific leaders in niche markets, and they have high recurring revenue and strong management teams at each one of these companies that we acquire. 
And our recent acquisitions have been growing in excess of 10% a year, which gives us, as they become organic acquisitions, have benefit to our organic growth. 
Next slide. If we look at this bridge, we put together, I think, really help people understand about the performance and the forward nature of what we'll do in 2016. If you look at the base revenue in 2015, it was $3.552 billion, and it ended the year at $3.593 billion, but that's not the story being up 1%. The story is that we had organic growth in our RF segment, we had organic growth in Medical, we had substantial acquisitions even though we divested ABEL, which is $20-plus million revenue business. 
So those 3 components added 7% to our trailing revenue number last year. But we had a 3% currency headwind almost all of which was in the energy and industrial segments. 
That 3% brought the number down and then we had $35 million of negative organic growth in industrial almost all of which was in Roper and FTI, which re upstream fluid handling businesses. 
And then we had $72 million negative organic in Energy, the vast majority of which was again upstream. 
Although in the fourth quarter, we didn't get the seasonal push that we normally would get, so we had a little bit of a fall off in the fourth quarter in the mid-and downstream business. So about 2.5% of the 3% negative organic in Industrial and Energy was related directly to oil and gas. Also something that gets skewed a bit by the numbers is our organic growth in the first quarter of '15 was 6%, excluding oil and gas. And we actually grew 2% in the second, third and fourth quarter, excluding oil and gas, so those headwinds that we've had to contend with in 2015 around oil and gas markets will be dramatically smaller in '16 than they were this year, although they're still some real challenges. And the currency isn't going to be $104 million, it will be probably 80% less than that negative number. 
Next slide. If we look at the outstanding margin, you can see on the left-hand side the gross margins in 2013, we were 58.6%, and those raised 70 basis points in '14 and then raised twice that 140 basis points this year to 60.7%.  
And our EBITDA margins in 2013 were 32.8%, they were raised 100 basis points in '14 to 33.8% and another 80 basis points this year to 34.6%. 
So the continued margin expansion just comes really from a focus on our asset-light businesses being able to reinvest for growth in themselves, and we had to reach leverage throughout the enterprise as a result. 
Next slide. We get to really what's the core of our entire business model is compounding our cash flow. And this compounding, you can see continues to be outstanding in a year where we really only have 1% revenue growth. Our free cash flow was up 11%. Our free cash flow at 9/29 is up $89 million from the $840 million. So we had a great quarter in the fourth quarter with $269 million of cash what we had a terrific year with $893 million and cash in our view is still the best measure performance. 
If you look at our cash guidance, you'll see our cash guidance tells a different story than the EPS guidance. 
Next slide. If you look at the financial position of the company, here, you can see cash at the end of this past year closed out at $779 million, up from $610 million the year before and up from $460 million in 2013. 
Now we've deployed almost 1/3 of that here in January to close the CliniSys acquisition, which is a little bit over $250 million, and that happened in the month of January. 
We also upsized our revolver. Our revolver used to be $1.5 billion. Our revolver is now $1.850 billion, and you can see on our undrawn revolver, we have $1.670 billion. So between cash and undrawn revolver, there's about $2.5 billion of powder there. 
Our trailing 12 months EBITDA at 1 50, of course, will be -- that's not a performing number, it will continue to get bigger as the year goes on. But even at $1.245 billion, our net debt-to-EBITDA is only 2. At the end of '13, it was $1.9 billion, so we've done over a couple of billion of acquisitions. Only have net debt for about $500 million, so we still have a great deal of ample liquidity to do anything we want to do in the acquisition front in 2016. 
Next slide. Here, we'll start to look at the specific segment detail and outlook. 
Next slide. If we look at the 4 segments, the Energy segment, the Industrial, the RF and the Medical segment, you'll see that they all our performing phenomenally from an EBITDA and gross margin basis. So even though you have a year where energy and industrial together came in at $1.333 billion, which was down 12% from the prior year's $1.519 billion, they still delivered 31% EBITDA margins in both years and both were over 50% of gross margins. 
In our RF and Medical space, those guys were up 11% from $2 billion, roughly to $2.260 billion. And of course, they have even stronger margins with 36% EBITDA for RF and 45% EBITDA for Medical. 
In the Medical and RF businesses they're now already 70% of our total EBITDA and even though all the segments have extraordinary margins. 
Next slide. So we'll start first with medical, which is our largest segment. And here you can see in the quarter, we have organic revenue of plus 3, acquisitions of plus 12% and foreign exchange, a negative 3%. Both SHP and IPA, acquisitions from '14, finally went to organic, and they delivered double-digit growth for us in this quarter. 
We had very strong sales out of Verathon nearly double digits with new product launches that we have talked about earlier in the year continuing to gain traction. 
And our Northern Digital business had an outstanding year, we're up more than 10% with very strong revenue growth in the fourth quarter. 
Atlas Medical, which is a small acquisition that we bolted into Sunquest again in the fourth quarter, its integration activity is doing well, and we expect that to contribute in 2016. 
MHA, we should comment on we completed all-time record year. It's compounding their growth and everything going well in that arena. 
In 2016, the way we see the year unfolding is that we'll continue to be nimble and I would say our operating leverage for the full year in Medical was 50%. So as this grow, they contribute outsized incremental gains for us. 
We think we'll have mid-single digit organic growth in Medical throughout '16, and we think that will get stronger as the year goes on. Sunquest has a number of version changes and software release updates that are rolling out in the second half that will be quite beneficial. And then Strata, Data Innovations and SoftWriters, which are growing rapidly will become organic in the second half. 
Verathon and Northern Digital continue to grow at a relatively higher rate in '16 and then we closed on January 7, the CliniSys acquisition in the U.K, which is a European hospital laboratory software provider. It will add to our acquisition sales growth in 2016. 
Next slide. Here we look at RF Technology. And RF Technology was up in the fourth quarter 4% organically. It had a negative FX of 1 point and acquisitions and divestitures added 15%. So their was up 18%, operating profit that 30% and operating profit margin, 31.1%. 
Software throughout the segment performed exceptionally well in the fourth quarter as we returned to pretty good growth at iTrade and double-digit growth at Trade Matching. 
Aderant was acquired in October and is off to a great start with the Aderant team and in fact, some of us are working with them in terms of coordinating some large clients being more secure going in with Aderant in the future as opposed to the fact that they were in private equity in the past. 
Toll and traffic projects are progressing really quite well. Riyadh is doing all right, although the start-ups in traffic in Riyadh tend to be more civil engineering at the beginning before we get all the software revenue but they're still fine. 
In our infinity lanes that we've been rolling out in Florida and Texas are on schedule and contributing substantially. 
We think we'll have mid-single digit organic growth for the year with stronger growth in the second half for RF primarily because TransCore is finally out of at arrangement where we were providing tolling administration in Puerto Rico, and that's been quite a challenge and last half of this past year and we'll be completely out of our business model this year.  So it's a little bit dilutive to our revenue, but it's very much accretive to our sanity as trying to get money out of Puerto Rico. As you know, it's not an easy task. But that will put a drag on revenue in the first 2 quarters, about $10 million each quarter, but that's revenue we're happy to avoid. 
Our operating leverage for this segment by the way, in 2015 was 56%. So here again as we get incremental revenue and again, we expect to have that in 2016, you'll see continued margin enhancement. 
The software businesses we think will grow at kind of mid-single digits, but they do have exceptional margins. It allows to use cash to reinvest in other transactions. 
And then the recent acquisitions that we've had, Aderant, RF IDeas and On Center, are all growing at a pretty strong rate, and they have excellent cash flow performance and eventually, they, too, will become organic. 
Next slide. If we look at Industrial Technology, here, in the fourth quarter, organic revenue was down 8%. It's all pretty much all oil and gas, upstream with our businesses that are related to that. Again, some context about this. In 2014, the oil and gas portion of Industrial Technology was about 12% of revenue. And unlike RF where it's 0 and in Medical, where it's at 0, in Industrial Tech, it was 12%. 14% this year. That dropped to 9% of revenue. And then our forecast for '16 we think it will be down 6%, the revenue in the segment. Almost exclusively upstream activity for surface and water pumping projects. 
We also have the divestiture which came from a circle with ABEL with about in the low of 20 to revenue about contributed nothing in the fourth quarter this year. Of course, it will be out over the next year. 
Neptune grew really quite well, double-digit growth in the U.S. in the fourth quarter. The Toronto project was still there, it's a headwind as we pulled you last year it's, close to $10 million a quarter, but it finally sense that in the first quarter of next year. So Neptune's growth in 2016 will be outsized compared to the way it has looked with the Toronto headwind in the past. 
We're forecasting continuing declines really in the upstream oil and gas. It was off about 30% for 2015. We think it will be off another 30% in 2016. But of course, it gets to be down to the smaller number, so it's about a $20 million headwind for the segment going into 2016. 
And the rest of the business will grow at kind of low single digit numbers, maybe a little bit better than t. 
So if we go to the next slide. Oh I should to say that energy leverage in industrial for the year, it delevered at 40%. So with gross margins above 50 and delevering at 40%, we think that's a pretty good performance. 
Next slide. On Energy Systems & Controls, they had continued falloff as one would expect particularly in the upstream arena. Their operating leverage for 2015 though was really quite good at negative 39% and their gross margins are 58%. So I think everybody performed quite nimbly, although in the fourth quarter, Compressor Controls started to see really deep dive on their project work and haven't really structured around that yet, and that activity will happen here in the first quarter. So they contributed terrifically over the last several years, but are to have to pay a major a decline in project work that's not going to reoccur for some long period of time. 
Now in the quarter, organic growth then was off you could see 17%, FX by 4%. Our seasonal improvement actually did occur sort of as we forecasted just not quite as much. We were up 9% seasonally in the fourth quarter in energy, but normally, we're up kind of 17% to 20% and occasionally, 25% in the fourth quarter. So we had thought will be up maybe 15% in the fourth quarter and by only coming up 9% at that kind of pullback of revenue to add in the fourth quarter, which was direct result of seeing a little less revenue that we expected out of them. 
Certainly backlogs are reduced in this segment in the oil and gas project business kind of rapidly deteriorate, although that's not a surprise. 
Unbelievable growth in Zetec as both South Korea, Japan and Middle East are roaring back and in fact, we were up quite dramatically in Zetec, and we think that will lead likely to very strong performance for Zetec in 2016. 
The operating margin, which really speaks to the nimbleness of the operating people we have in these businesses, was still 32.7% even though the segment was down substantially in revenue. 
If we look at the -- what we're talking about here for 2016, you can see sort of high single digit organic decline for the segment. Oil and gas, we think, will be down about 15%, which will be about a $50 million drag on the settlement, so about $20 million out of Industrial, about $50 million out of Energy. The project activity is going to force Compressor Controls to do some aggressive restructuring, and I know that it's a challenge for everybody but there's no question the market requires us to do that. 
And then we think we'll have modest growth in the rest of the areas in the industrial arena. 
Next slide. So here as we get into the 2016 guidance. Next slide. We created another bridge for you here for 2016, see you get a sense of what's really going on in the health of the overall business. 
You can see we finished this past year, at '15, at $3,593 million. We expect revenue to be up between 8% to 10% in 2016, and we think organic revenue will be between 2% and 4% in the coming year or so we'll get mid-single digits organic growth out of RF and mid single digits organic growth out of Medical. We think we'll have low single digit organic growth out of Industrial whereas last year, as you remember, it was a negative number. And then already completed acquisitions net of the ABEL investiture are going to contribute sizable portion of revenue in 2016. We think we'll still have the high single digit organic drop in energy but that's a big improvement over last year's organic drop. And then foreign exchange, which was $104 million last year is probably going to be about an 80% less headwind for us in 2016, so maybe something in the $20 million to $25 million arena and that makes just as we showed you we grew last year at 7% until you hit the oil and gas number. Just easier comps throughout the year for us once we get past the first quarter. 
Next slide. So if we look at the 2016 guidance, you can see for the full year, we're saying operating cash flow we would hope would meet or exceed $1 billion and operating cash flow is going to have just very limited CapEx drag for it to convert of free cash flow this past year. I think our CapEx was $36 million. We wouldn't expected to be at a higher than that this year so certainly less than 1% of revenue, probably quite a bit less than 1% of revenue. 
Free cash flow -- I'm sorry, full year adjusted DEPS, we're saying or $6.85 to $7.15 and the key assumptions around that is we got, for the full year, revenue growth of 8% to 10%; organic growth of 2% to 4%. Comps eased after the first quarter. In the first quarter, we've got a lot of headwinds, we've got revenue drag out of Puerto Rico, we got oil and gas that not really hit us in the first quarter last year, and we had some unique revenue coming out of Roper Pump that will continue. 
We had a little higher gross cost because of bigger draw with the acquisitions, but we also get benefit in earnings. 
But Q1 last year at 6% organic and the last 3 quarters had 2% organic, so we certainly don't expect 6% organic net of oil and gas in the first quarter. 
Our noncash amortization increases by $30 million, so our noncash amortization will be $195 million in 2016. And if you want to use cash earnings, you can add that back to the net earnings number. 
Interest expense is about $25 million higher than last year to $109 million. Our tax rate is going to be somewhat somewhere in this past year in the 30% to 30.5% arena and of course, none of these include any new acquisitions, and we do expect to be pretty active in 2016 and adding additional high-quality businesses. 
In the first quarter, we're going to establish guidance at $1.42 to $1.47 because of those things that we have to face in the first quarter that were not there last year, but we'll get improvement throughout the year on those things, quite dramatic improvement in the second half, which is not based on hope but just a reality of what we know to be the case. 
Next slide. As we look at the 2015 summary and then the outlook for the year, we delivered record annual results orders in revenue, margin and net earnings, EBITDA and cash flow in '15, and that was despite quite the biggest headwind period we have with so must coming from currency and oil and gas. 
Our operating cash flow was up 11%, free cash flow also up 11%. We had terrific margin improvement with gross margins up 140 basis points to 60.7%, EBITDA margins up 80 basis points to 34.6% and free cash flow at $893 million, represented 25% of every dollar of our revenue and 132% cash conversion versus the DEPS number. 
We deployed $1.8 billion in really attractive acquisitions, so we increased our dividend by 20%. 
As we go into this year, we expect to deliver record performance in '16 with that revenue growth we mentioned just the slide before at 8% to 10%, operating cash flow around $1 billion. We think we'll deploy well over $1 billion in acquisitions. It could be easily be higher than that, and we've already closed our first one with CliniSys for about $250 million in January. 
We got a very attractive pipeline, we're looking at transactional and another one on Monday so there's just a great yield activity going on probably, and those that we've ever seen in terms of pipeline. 
We continue to compound cash, increase shareholder value last year, you have a lot of [indiscernible] in 2015 and there's no reason to think we can continue to increase our cash as we look at 2016. 
So with that, John, I think we're ready for questions.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. So Deanna, we're ready for the Q&A portion of our call.
componenttext: I think so. So Deanna, we're ready for the Q&A portion of our call.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Now we'll take our first question from Shannon O'Callaghan with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Now we'll take our first question from Shannon O'Callaghan with UBS.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, just on the assumptions on the oil and gas they're down 30 for Industrial Tech and now, '15 for Energy, maybe just explain a little bit the difference between those 2 decline rates and then some of the other businesses around the oil and gas within
componenttext: Brian, just on the assumptions on the oil and gas they're down 30 for Industrial Tech and now, '15 for Energy, maybe just explain a little bit the difference between those 2 decline rates and then some of the other businesses around the oil and gas within the energy segmented you have that better outlook for.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in the Industrial, basically, Roper Pump is almost exclusively oriented around upstream oil and gas. So it's not a huge business, but it has a big, big, big drawback when you have that change. In fact, it's primarily U.S. business. So it's oil and g
componenttext: Well, in the Industrial, basically, Roper Pump is almost exclusively oriented around upstream oil and gas. So it's not a huge business, but it has a big, big, big drawback when you have that change. In fact, it's primarily U.S. business. So it's oil and gas component was down 30% in '15 from '14, and we expect it will down another 30% in '16 for '15, but it's still a fairly small number. So it's about a $20 million revenue drag that we're modeling into '16. None of the other businesses in Industrial Technology have anything to do with oil and gas. There instrument companies or -- over half is the Neptune, water pump business, which is going to grow next year. So it's just that one isolated and there's no midstream and downstream activity really in industrial. When you get into energy, much, much bigger total dollars of what you're talking about, about 60% of the segment is oil and gas, but only some of it is upstream, primarily the upstream portion, there are a couple of very small businesses and a little bit of [indiscernible] and then quite a lot of Compressor Controls. So Compressor Controls has been living off of a great project backlog. Their service work, we expect to be a record as you in 2016, but we think there project will drop really dramatically, to drop $30 million, $40 million. And the midstream and downstream activity for the year has been really decent, all the way along. The only drag has been the currency. But been in the fourth quarter, we didn't get as much of a seasonal uptick in those downstream businesses as we normally do, so mostly testing businesses. So that bodes for slight deterioration probably in '16. The rest of the Energy business, the 40%, are really mostly test and measurement kind of businesses and then dropped, really, sharply at Zetec so that's helped offset that's what we're d saying 15% for Energy, but it's 30% for the upstream portion of Industrial.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then within Industrial in terms of getting for organic declines starting to grow there again, what is the Toronto comp impact, what was in 4Q, what was it 1Q? And then what's driving that double-digit Neptune growth? I mean is it kind of a susta
componenttext: Okay. And then within Industrial in terms of getting for organic declines starting to grow there again, what is the Toronto comp impact, what was in 4Q, what was it 1Q? And then what's driving that double-digit Neptune growth? I mean is it kind of a sustainable rate? Or what's driving that?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it certainly going to be very solid growth in 2016. It's about a $10 million dividend each quarter for the Toronto project as it selloff. There's a little bit of revenue, we're still getting out of Toronto for last unit adjustments, but it's not very
componenttext: Yes, it certainly going to be very solid growth in 2016. It's about a $10 million dividend each quarter for the Toronto project as it selloff. There's a little bit of revenue, we're still getting out of Toronto for last unit adjustments, but it's not very meaningful. It's just domestic growth in the winds in projects. We are going to have -- I mean, we have a share gains at the really obvious the when you look at the data, and we're going to have further share gains that are really in 2016 that we're comping it up based on contacts with our bid process.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Shannon, the Toronto project really completed substantially in the first quarter of 2015. So it's built kind of in that $10 million comp range in the fourth quarter against the fourth quarter of '14 and then we'll have a little bit of headwind in the
componenttext: Yes, Shannon, the Toronto project really completed substantially in the first quarter of 2015. So it's built kind of in that $10 million comp range in the fourth quarter against the fourth quarter of '14 and then we'll have a little bit of headwind in the first quarter on a year-over-year basis. And then after that, it's going to be more normalized. So it's not an acceleration that we're looking for, it's really some headwinds that will start to go away.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Deane Dray of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Deane Dray of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to go back onto the oil exposures for Industrial and Energy and just talk about if you could your visibility in the businesses, specifically around orders in the quarter. And then on the organic assumed the declines, maybe discuss what volume ver
componenttext: I'd like to go back onto the oil exposures for Industrial and Energy and just talk about if you could your visibility in the businesses, specifically around orders in the quarter. And then on the organic assumed the declines, maybe discuss what volume versus pricing. There's a lot of supply squeezing that's going on in the sector and it wouldn't be surprised maybe you're seeing some pricing pressure as well.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you talk about our salesman, they'll tell you it was massive pricing. There's no pricing pressure. That's silly. That's not the issue at all it's just pure the biggest component, of course, is currency, but then probably unit situation. It's the
componenttext: Well, if you talk about our salesman, they'll tell you it was massive pricing. There's no pricing pressure. That's silly. That's not the issue at all it's just pure the biggest component, of course, is currency, but then probably unit situation. It's the project work of Compressor Controls this year has really easy to detail that out. So those numbers are pretty good. Last year, we actually said, when we initiated guidance, we thought upstream would be down about 20%. You correctly challenged us about. CapEx was down 30%, it might not be down 30% and we said it could be down more than 20% but we thought we had a particular arrangement around surface drilling, which is new technology, which is rapidly gaining share that was doing that at the time that we thought that would continue in the second quarter. But in the second quarter, they basically stopped all ordering and consumed all inventory it could. That hurt us a little bit. And then in the fourth quarter, we didn't get any seasonal balance, any -- well we did, but not as much as you normally would. So we're very comfortable around guiding down $20 million in oil and gas, and Industrial and around $50 million in Energy, I think that's quite, quite correct. And then there is still be a little bit more drag on a nominal number basis with currency, but it's definitely not pricing. And the guys have been pretty correct all year long, except for that Q2 situation at Roper Pump where our supply agreement got suspended for that quarter.

componenttextpreview: What were orders in the quarter for both?

componenttext: And it was 0.97 for Industrial. So on the Industrial side, that 0.97, they're kind of typical for a fourth quarter, but it's definitely lighter. So you have about disability also. So for the product businesses particular around upstream and even on the mid and downstream, those are generally going to be booked in ship inside of a relatively short window 2 months or so. Where we do have better visibility and we're talking more about this is on the Compressor Controls side, right, so it's more of a projects business, and that's where we saw in order shortfall in the fourth quarter leading to that 0.9 book-to-bill area. And while we're expecting that to be a tough year for the project based business, but we can have good visibility in that area.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, you referenced back in the second quarter some of our expectations that the upstream could be worse. Just to kind of give you a data point, we have lunch on Friday with the CEO of should number Jay and their expectations is upstream could be down 3
componenttext: Brian, you referenced back in the second quarter some of our expectations that the upstream could be worse. Just to kind of give you a data point, we have lunch on Friday with the CEO of should number Jay and their expectations is upstream could be down 35%, so we're in that right neighborhood. And just last question for me would be these businesses, so we talked about Roper Pump, the Compressor Controls, these are legacy Roper industries businesses and certainly not something that you would be looking to investing today. Now in the teeth of the oil pressure is here certainly not a time to talk about divesting, but there would be an opportunity at some point to separate the Roper Industries legacy businesses from Roper Technologies where you're focusing today?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's certainly possible to talk about it quite a lot and there are a lot of different avenues for achieving that. It could be spun off as an independent entity where people would be able to make that kind of 1:1 decision about whether they wanted to be in
componenttext: It's certainly possible to talk about it quite a lot and there are a lot of different avenues for achieving that. It could be spun off as an independent entity where people would be able to make that kind of 1:1 decision about whether they wanted to be in that space as an investor and could be put together whether other business and some kind of merger. Again, it's not something we'd like we sell because the tax sale is just pretty prohibitive and the businesses are very good. I mean, the oil and gas businesses, we put the whole thing together, they have an EBITDA margin of 34%. And they don't  take a lot of assets, they are very, very cash accretive to our number. And for those people who like EPS, they give us terrific EPS but there's no amortization. But you're right, I mean, that we're always going to look at and certainly they have more than 1 phone call inbound about people like to do something but selling them is not the best thing for our investors, finding a tax free alternative to that would be more attractive.

componenttext: So what I've been trying to get with everyone's guidance is kind of separate how much of the progression throughout the year is anticipating a market upturn, like an underlining market upturn and how much is specific to the company as a cadence of revenue that's already in hand or orders you already haven't had. So how would you separate expectations of that the second half versus what you know and what you're hoping?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a whole lot more what we know and then. We hope we don't really have very many businesses with only 1 or 2 that have any type or something that's kind of a larger macro end market. The markets that we serve are so niche, they end up being more driven
componenttext: It's a whole lot more what we know and then. We hope we don't really have very many businesses with only 1 or 2 that have any type or something that's kind of a larger macro end market. The markets that we serve are so niche, they end up being more driven by our activity around new products or new releases rather than kind of a hope for some macroeconomic recovery. We're not really expecting any of that. That's not something that we try to forecast. It doesn't drive many of our businesses. But it's not as simple as orders in hand because we really don't have orders in hand for products that were for activity that's going to ship in the third quarter or fourth quarter. So we're not a projects type of E&C business like that. But it's really around many of the we know that we're going to be able to introduce to the niche market that we serve and let's take a newer products growth in those areas.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The bid-ask spread is wide, it's always wide but we were able to deploy $1 8 billion last year, and we're  already got $0.25 billion of that right now, so we don't anticipate any different at all. Do you think that the notes out today are interesting, so
componenttext: The bid-ask spread is wide, it's always wide but we were able to deploy $1 8 billion last year, and we're  already got $0.25 billion of that right now, so we don't anticipate any different at all. Do you think that the notes out today are interesting, so there weren't any IPOs in January. So if you were a seller of a private equity, you might continue to say whatever you think somebody's got to listen to. But the reality is, the debt costs are going up and exit strategies are diminishing. We remain the best mid-market acquirer of assets on the face of the earth. So we're not going to have any difficulty finding high-quality businesses at rational prices.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

componenttext: Maybe last from you. At what point do you start looking? You guys are ahead of pivoting some of the way of these energy industrial type of applications into where you're on, on your Medical businesses. At what point do you start to look opportunistically a little bit more aggressive with some of these sectors that have being down a little bit more?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we always look at is the cash return we can get out of on investment. And so what happens is, it's usually difficult for an industrial asset to have the kind of cash returns that we are going to demand. But whenever we see them, we're willing t
componenttext: Well, what we always look at is the cash return we can get out of on investment. And so what happens is, it's usually difficult for an industrial asset to have the kind of cash returns that we are going to demand. But whenever we see them, we're willing to make investments in those. We bought a pure product company and RFID this year, which is just a world-class business with terrific leadership, very high margins relatively light assets but there's certainly making stuff and they're selling stuff. So it depends on the quality of what it is we see, but we will never buy something at a public market the discount. Let's say, some energy business dropped 30%, we wouldn't buy something because it dropped 30%. We would only buy something because it's forward cash returns were extremely attractive. And as generally as a rule, people overpay for low-quality assets under the theory that they're going to find some way to make them better. So we'll  leave buying distressed assets to others. We want to buy businesses that have consistent growth and recurring revenue and light assets models. And we haven't seen any other than this. We haven't seen anything in the last 2 years in the industrial segment that qualifies for them.

componenttextpreview: It's a good question, but I sort of have to dissect the. But remember in the medical software, we have a huge amount of recurring revenue, right. So the recurring revenue, it's not going to grow by a higher number. So when we say mid- to high single digit
componenttext: It's a good question, but I sort of have to dissect the. But remember in the medical software, we have a huge amount of recurring revenue, right. So the recurring revenue, it's not going to grow by a higher number. So when we say mid- to high single digits, that has to be something that takes the whole segment into consideration. So the product portion in the new software sales have to be higher than that in order to get the whole segment up to mid-single digits. I don't think that there's any -- certainly Sunquest in the second half of the year should have outsized growth to what it had throughout 2015 because we've had meaningful use improvement in '14 the beginning of '15 that is a comparative drag, and that will go away as '16 matures. I don't think there's really any particular driver than the medical software in the software businesses in the RF component, there are some drivers that have had escalating growth. I don't know if, John, you want to add anything to that.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think. So I think it's really we expect '16 to be really more -- probably higher fee on the medical products side with some continued new product introductions introduce some things at Verathon in the latter part of '15. So those start to go r
componenttext: No, I don't think. So I think it's really we expect '16 to be really more -- probably higher fee on the medical products side with some continued new product introductions introduce some things at Verathon in the latter part of '15. So those start to go ramp up. We have other new products that are being introduced to the market as well as well as continued growth around some guided surgery applications that Northern Digital continues to just perform phenomenally well. And then as Brian mentioned in the software and services side, that's kind of a mid-single digit grower anyway because of the huge number recurring revenue, and that's what we expect in the latter part of '16. We're not expecting a whole lot of recovery at all in the emerging world. I don't think that's expected to be a be up a little bit.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 2 questions. One is just kind of the old chestnut that people ask about Roper and M&A. And clearly, given the environment we're seeing and I guess, one of the cofounders talk about the financing markets for shutting down the sky is falling. But in term
componenttext: So 2 questions. One is just kind of the old chestnut that people ask about Roper and M&A. And clearly, given the environment we're seeing and I guess, one of the cofounders talk about the financing markets for shutting down the sky is falling. But in terms of just coming back to that question, is there a particular types of companies that you're kind of looking at now that really went themselves real environment really product a traditional private equity and really you can kind of sweep in besides just the normal -- is there particular vertical or end markets where you're really well-positioned or well advantaged? And does this allow for bigger deals of size of a certain decile to be shaken out in this environment?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is certainly true that on things that are relatively watered potential acquisitions, there is maybe there will be less competition for those assets as the year unfolds than there have been in the last 3 years. I noticed on some of the large thing
componenttext: Well, it is certainly true that on things that are relatively watered potential acquisitions, there is maybe there will be less competition for those assets as the year unfolds than there have been in the last 3 years. I noticed on some of the large things that we've looked at, if it's private equity, it is up 1 turn, it's 3 guys going together. But that stables are still out there I mean we're looking at the deal Friday that has a 6.5x debt stable it. So as long as debt stables are that high, we would use it the private equity is going to use that, right? They can put in 4 terms of EBITDA, and you're still 10.5x EBITDA. So that kind of businesses that we acquire, they were public. They tend to trade at 25x at a private EBITDA or more. I know it's hard for people to follow that because they're looking at traditional multi-industry, but multiples that are dramatically less. So we're going to continue to look at these things or great yield from an arbitrage perspective in the public markets versus what we have to pay for them. And those tend to crowd out the lesser quality businesses, where people pay 8, 9, 10x for something that worth a step. And we tend to pay 11 and 12x for something that's worth 25, and that's really how we get all this out for performance consistently over a long pier to time, and that's going to continue. Now last year, we did something that I wouldn't have forecast, which is we did 6 or 7 deals to get to $2 billion. We would have rather down $1.5 billion deal and $500 million, but the small deals were unbelievably compelling and they're all growing double digits. So I mean it was a good thing to do. We are still seeing a lot of those kind of opportunities. So as the year unfolds, it will be battle between sort of saving our powder for really large transactions that were going ahead and investing early on things that are somewhat modest. At the end of the day, for our shareholders, the result is about the same. It's just easier for us to to do a large deal than do small deals. But we're -- it should be an easy year for us to deploy capital very favorably.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up. I may just obviously in ramping up coverage of again after a long dormancy, the cash return investment kind of maturity used in the kind of your M&A and capital deployment strategy obviously makes a heck of a lot of sense an
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up. I may just obviously in ramping up coverage of again after a long dormancy, the cash return investment kind of maturity used in the kind of your M&A and capital deployment strategy obviously makes a heck of a lot of sense and I certainly have tried to Kool-Aid with respect to the discipline around it. But I think the most important coming out of it is basically the strategy and the metrics were kind of completely aligned. In other words, you don't stretch for what is perceived as a strategic deal because a strategic deal is 1 which meets the metrics, right? So I guess, only question I have is where do you think there are risks to the CI discipline or maybe businesses you're looking at? Do you think it's maybe an assessment of the code? I know you used a third-party consultancy to kind of look at kind of the related and actual property and software in association with deals and there can be obviously risk there, technological substitution. Maybe if you could just talk about where were you just levelheaded Lee sic about the risks and association with your capital redeployment strategy?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, maybe just for a second, I'll stick about the risk in general if you look at the transactions because people were asking questions about we buy some cheap stuff, right? So that cheap stuff in Industrial, and they're all kinds of stuff and there are
componenttext: Well, maybe just for a second, I'll stick about the risk in general if you look at the transactions because people were asking questions about we buy some cheap stuff, right? So that cheap stuff in Industrial, and they're all kinds of stuff and there are public stocks are going to continue to deteriorate, and you can buy. What's wrong with that is they can get this intermediated from distribution channels. They can wind up with the premium model out of Google bizarre thing or they wind up with Amazon selling past their competition at low price points. And are all kinds of things that are going to happen. They definitely need absorption is a revenue falls off, there's nothing they can do without big restructuring charges. When we get to our space, it's really around whether or not the people in the niche that we acquire have domain expertise, which is very hard for somebody to break into. And so the entry barriers for their success are entirely different. So the risk is that we continue to assess the quality of the management teams that we acquire wealth, and we understand were the or not there are technologies that could leapfrog what they do. So that we spent most of our time around people aspects of the business and then around may be risks that those people don't see that we would put kind of difference factor on. We tend to discount their forward growth projections because we don't pay for synergies, for forward growth, we only pay for what we think the business is going to deliver at the time of the acquisition. And that really puts a huge dampening effect on the risk that we might otherwise have. And we've been kind up blessed to be fortunate in that arena. But I think our disciplines are such because we actually start with somebody's balance sheet and then we start with what it takes to run the business. We don't do -- like what a private equity, people do they'll buy a software company and their mandate an immediate 10% reduction. One of the private equity firms out there actually goes and a does a listing of the highest paid people and they lack off the highest paid people and put new college guy in, big salary reductions. And then that kind of tedious activity doesn't manifest itself in a business for 4 or 5 years. So you have to understand what each private equity group's business model is when you're looking at the assets they hold in your acquiring it and I think we can do that better than anybody.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering in Medical here the product cycles and the devices seems to be coming on pretty well. Wonder if of Northern bit digital, Verathon, you're looking at those to be able to climb in double-digit run rates at some point. Are the product cycles t
componenttext: Just wondering in Medical here the product cycles and the devices seems to be coming on pretty well. Wonder if of Northern bit digital, Verathon, you're looking at those to be able to climb in double-digit run rates at some point. Are the product cycles that have been notable the past few quarters, is that sort of a couple year dynamic, do you think?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do think so. Although we really seeing out of Verathon is a refresh so it's not a completely new product category, which actually reduces the risk for us. These are really upgrades and extensions of their existing live scope like in 2015 and then b
componenttext: Yes, I do think so. Although we really seeing out of Verathon is a refresh so it's not a completely new product category, which actually reduces the risk for us. These are really upgrades and extensions of their existing live scope like in 2015 and then bladder scan in 2016. And so those are kind of a couple year adoption rate to go on here. Northern Digital doesn't have to get up to double digits. They're up to continue double-digit growth. They've been growing at double-digit here for a couple of years and they're really the leader in both the optical tracking as well as the electromechanical -- sorry, electromagnetic tracking for computer-assisted surgery applications. And those continue to just expand, those applications just continue to expand and whatever there's a new 1 that an OEM customer wants the design, they always come back to Northern Digital to serve the world leaders in that technology.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just if there's any room left, just wanted to expand on Rob's line of question a little bit where you had a record year last year in deal flow and talk about I think record pipeline volume or breadth. As you -- have you transition more kind
componenttext: Okay. And then just if there's any room left, just wanted to expand on Rob's line of question a little bit where you had a record year last year in deal flow and talk about I think record pipeline volume or breadth. As you -- have you transition more kind of wholeheartedly to CRI? And is the increasingly intolerant definition of strategic kind of the reason why your pipeline and your yield has kind of accelerated to somewhat unpredictable levels?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. Let's go back and think about. The reason I said sometime ago that the Sunquest, MHA acquisitions were more transformational than Neptune and TransCore transformation. Because at Neptune, we paid 4x EBITDA at the enterprise in December of 2003
componenttext: No, no, no. Let's go back and think about. The reason I said sometime ago that the Sunquest, MHA acquisitions were more transformational than Neptune and TransCore transformation. Because at Neptune, we paid 4x EBITDA at the enterprise in December of 2003 to acquire Neptune at what some you probably thought was a high price for $500 million. Next year in 2004, we paid about 4x, again, the trailing revenue of the firm, 3.5% or something for TransCore at $600 million. Well neither one of those businesses have blended themselves to adding exciting bolt-on activities to them or giving you the main experience as an area that was easily widened, all right? So when you acquire a leading laboratory software provider in a world that's going to have more and more laboratory instrument usage and will move to genomics in the immediate future, you have big upside ramp. We have MHA with senior living in nursing homes, all the things around non-acute hospitalization shifts and demography. These things just give you all kinds of opportunity. Well, good heavens, we've acquired now SoftWriters for MHA, which is growing at double digits. That's a terrific acquisition. We've been able to acquire CliniSys, which we can act really with Sunquest, we acquired Data Innovations, which is a phenomenal company, that guides all the instrumentation in a hospital into various systems and yet it's part of Sunquest. So that's why we can look at these things, which are somewhat synergistic at least in the marketplace or in the information technology side of them that we couldn't do with the Industrial and Energy businesses.
