Good day, and welcome to the Roper Technologies Fourth Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.
I will now turn the call over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Deanna, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our fourth quarter financial results.Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and
componenttext:
Thank you, Deanna, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our fourth quarter financial results.
Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Rob Crisci, Vice President of Planning and Investor Relations. 
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also on our website. 
If you turn to Slide 2, we begin with our safe harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties, as described on this page, and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
Next slide. Today, we will be discussing our income statement results for the quarter, primarily on an adjusted non-GAAP basis. A full reconciliation between GAAP and adjusted measures is in our press release this morning and also included as a part of this presentation on our website.
For the fourth quarter, the difference between our GAAP and adjusted results consists of 3 items: first, we completed the divestiture of ABEL Pumps during the fourth quarter, resulting in a pretax book gain of $70.9 million. This was partially offset by an impairment charge of $9.5 million relating to an imaging investment we made in 2007; second, a $4 million purchase accounting adjustment to acquire deferred revenue relating to software acquisitions made in 2015. This represents revenue that those companies would have recognized if not for our acquisition; finally, we have a $2.6 million inventory step-up expense relating to the acquisition of RF IDeas.
Now if you please turn to Slide 4, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. And after his remarks, we will take questions from our telephone systems. Brian?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. So we'll start off here with our Q4 results. They were flat to last year, we'll talk a little bit about that, at $948 million. It's exactly the same number as last year but with lot of activity to get you there. W
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. So we'll start off here with our Q4 results. They were flat to last year, we'll talk a little bit about that, at $948 million. It's exactly the same number as last year but with lot of activity to get you there. We had another 2 points of FX headwind in the quarter and then the acquisitions net of the ABEL divestiture offset the organic shortfall in energy primarily.
The Industrial and Energy markets declined in the fourth quarter and really had less seasonal adjustment favorable in the fourth quarter than normally, and we'll talk about that when we get to that segment. But we have very strong growth in Medical and the RF segments. Our gross margins continued to escalate. They were up 190 basis points in the quarter to 61.8%.
Our EBITDA margin also hit 35.9%, that's the EBITDA margin, not the gross margin. And EBITDA was up another 2% to $341 million, which is sort of an annualized run rate of $1.364 billion.
Our free cash flow was up to $261 million, and it's 140% cash conversion. And we also issued 5- and 10-year bond, which totaled $900 million in the month of December, and deployed over $700 million in a quarter in some very attractive acquisitions, so we enjoyed both good execution in the quarter and terrific disciplined capital deployment.
Next slide. If we look at the income statement in the quarter, you can see that, while the orders and the revenue were exactly the same as the year ago, no 2 businesses would have been the same. So this was a case of watching the ducks on the pond with a whole lot of paddling going on underneath it.
The book-to-bill at 0.98 is actually pretty good for a fourth quarter. Just to give you some sense of history: in 2011, our book-to-bill in the fourth quarter was 0.94; in '12, it was 0.95; and in '13, it was flat 1 or 1; '14, it was 0.98; and this year, it's 0.98. So from a historical perspective, it's about what we would expect to see.
Our gross profit as we said was up from 59.9% to 61.8% and operating income, the margin was 30.1% and that absorbed 70 basis points of higher noncash amortization as acquisitions came in.
The interest expense was up $5 million due the bond issuance, so a little bit more drawn at the revolver during the quarter.
Net earnings were down 1% from $187 to $186, which you could see just from the interest.
Next slide. Here, we shift into the full year enterprise results.
So next slide. On the enterprise results, the whole point of the year, really, was our ability to demonstrate nimble execution in the field and then deploy capital in a -- in really a tough acquisition market with great transactions.
So if you look at the records, everything, once again, was a record. We had the most orders, the highest revenue, the best margins, the highest net earnings, and best EBITDA and cash flow of any year in our history. The growth was led by Medical and RF. We had continued margin improvement throughout the year. The gross margin was up 140 basis points on a year to 60.7% and the operating margin was up 80 basis points to 29% offering profit margin and, of course, EBITDA was higher. 
A very strong cash flow. We were up 11% in cash flow for the year, and that was 26% of the revenue. Our free cash flow was also up 11% and our cash conversion on a free cash flow basis was 132%.
We deployed $1.8 billion in acquisitions in 2015, with almost entirely a focus on software and medical technologies.
All of our acquisitions are really very high-margin businesses. They're all asset light, they're very specific leaders in niche markets, and they have high recurring revenue and strong management teams at each one of these companies that we acquired.
And our recent acquisitions have been growing in excess of 10% a year, which gives us, as they become organic growth acquisitions, a benefit to organic growth.[ph] 
Next slide. If we look at this briefly, we put together, I think, really help people understand about the performance and the forward nature of what we'll do in 2016. If you look at the base revenue in 2015, it was $3.552 billion, and it ended the year at $3.593 billion. But that's not the story, being up 1%. The story is that we had organic growth in our RF segment, we had organic growth in Medical, we had substantial acquisitions even though we divested ABEL, which was $20-plus million revenue business.
So those 3 components added 7% to our trailing revenue number of last year. But we had a 3% currency headwind almost all of which was in the energy and industrial segments.
And that 3% brought the number down and then we had $35 million of negative organic growth in industrial, almost all of which was in Roper and FTI, which are our upstream fluid handling businesses.
And then we had $72 million negative organic in Energy, the vast majority of which was again upstream.
Although in the fourth quarter, we didn't get the seasonal push that we normally would get, so we had a little bit of a fall off in the fourth quarter in the mid and downstream business. So about 2.5% of the 3% negative organic in Industrial and Energy was related directly to oil and gas. Also something that gets skewed a bit by the numbers is our organic growth in the first quarter of '15 was 6%, excluding oil and gas. And we actually grew 2% in the second, third and fourth quarter, excluding oil and gas, so those headwinds that we've had to contend with in 2015 around oil and gas markets will be dramatically smaller in '16 than they were this year, although they're still some real challenges. And the currency isn't going to be $104 million, it will be probably 80% less than that negative number.
Next slide. If we look at the outstanding margin, you can see on the left-hand side the gross margins in 2013, we were 58.6%, and those were raised 70 basis points in '14 and then raised twice that of 140 basis points this year to 60.7%.
And our EBITDA margins in 2013 were 32.8%, they were raised 100 basis points in '14 to 33.8% and another 80 basis points this year to 34.6%.
So the continued margin expansion just comes, really, from a focus on our asset-light businesses being able to reinvest for growth in themselves. And we had great leverage throughout the enterprise as a result.
Next slide. We get to, really, what's the core of our entire business model is compounding our cash flow. And this compounding, you can see continues to be outstanding in a year where we really only have 1% revenue growth. Our free cash flow was up 11%. Our free cash flow at 9/29 is up $89 million from $840 million. So we had a great quarter in the fourth quarter with $269 million of cash. But we had a terrific year, with $893 million and cash in our view is still the best measured performance.
If you look at our cash guidance, you'll see our cash guidance tells a different story than the EPS guidance.
Next slide. If you look at the financial position of the company, here, you can see cash at the end of this past year closed out at $779 million, up from $610 million the year before and up from $460 million in 2013.
Now we've deployed almost 1/3 of that here in January to close the CliniSys acquisition, which is a little bit over $250 million, and that happened in the month of January.
We also upsized our revolver. Our revolver used to be $1.5 billion. Our revolver is now $1.850 billion, and you can see on our undrawn revolver, we have $1.670 billion. So between cash and undrawn revolver, there's about $2.5 billion of powder there. 
Our trailing 12 months EBITDA at $1,250 million, of course, will be -- that's not a performing number, it will continue to get bigger as the year goes on. But even at $1.245 billion, our net debt-to-EBITDA is only 2. At the end of '13, it was $1.9 billion, so we've done over a couple of billion of acquisitions. Only have net debt of about $500 million, so we still have a great deal of ample liquidity to do anything we want to do in the acquisition front in 2016.
Next slide. Here, we'll start to look at the specific segment detail and outlook. 
Next slide. If we look at the 4 segments, the Energy segment, the Industrial, the RF and the Medical segment, you'll see that they all are performing phenomenally from an EBITDA and gross margin basis. So even though you have a year where Energy and Industrial together came in at $1.333 billion, which was down 12% from the prior year's $1.519 billion, they still delivered 31% EBITDA margins in both years and both were over 50% in gross margins.
In our RF and Medical space, those guys were up 11% from $2 billion, roughly to $2.260 billion. And of course, they have even stronger margins with 36% EBITDA for RF and 45% EBITDA for Medical.
In the Medical and RF businesses are now already 70% of our total EBITDA and even though all the segments have extraordinary margins.
Next slide. So we'll start first with medical, which is our largest segment. And here you can see in the quarter, we had organic revenue of plus 3, acquisitions of plus 12% and foreign exchange, a negative 3%. SHP and IPA, acquisitions from '14, finally went to organic, and they delivered double-digit growth for us in this quarter. 
We had very strong sales out of Verathon, nearly double digits, with new product launches that we have talked about earlier in the year continuing to gain traction.
And our Northern Digital business had an outstanding year, we're up more than 10% with very strong revenue growth in the fourth quarter.
Atlas Medical, which is a small acquisition that we bolted into Sunquest in the fourth quarter, its integration activity is doing well, and we expect that to contribute in 2016.
MHA, we should comment on, completed all-time record year. It's compounding their growth and everything going well in that arena.
In 2016, the way we see the year unfolding is that we'll continue to be nimble and I would say our operating leverage for the full year in Medical was 50%. So as this grow, they contribute outsized incremental gains for us.
We think we'll have mid-single-digit organic growth in Medical throughout '16. And we think that will get stronger as the year goes on. Sunquest has a number of version changes and software release updates that are rolling out in the second half that will be quite beneficial. And then Strata, Data Innovations and SoftWriters, which are growing rapidly will become organic in the second half.
Verathon and Northern Digital continue to grow at a relatively higher rate in '16. And then we closed on January 7, the CliniSys acquisition in the U.K, which is a European hospital laboratory software provider. It will add to our acquisition sales growth in 2016.
Next slide. Here we look at RF Technology. And RF Technology was up in the fourth quarter 4% organically. It had a negative FX of 1 point and acquisitions and divestitures added 15%. So the revenue was up 18%, operating profit at 30% and the operating profit margin, 31.1%.
Software throughout the segment performed exceptionally well in the fourth quarter as we returned to pretty good growth at iTrade and double-digit growth at Trade Matching.[ph] 
Aderant was acquired in October and is off to a great start with the Aderant team and in fact, some of us are working with them in terms of coordinating some large clients being more secure going in with Aderant in the future as opposed to the fact that they were in private equity in the past.
Toll and traffic projects are progressing really quite well. Riyadh is doing all right, although the start-ups in traffic in Riyadh tend to be more civil engineering at the beginning before we get all the software revenue but they're still fine. 
In our Infinity lanes that we've been rolling out in Florida and Texas are on schedule and contributing substantially.
We think we'll have mid-single digit organic growth for the year, with stronger growth in the second half for RF. Primarily, because TransCore is finally out of a arrangement where we were providing tolling administration in Puerto Rico, and that's been quite a challenge in the last half of this past year and we'll be completely out of our business model this year.  So it's a little bit dilutive to our revenue, but it's very much accretive to our sanity as trying to get money out of Puerto Rico. As you know, it's not an easy task. But that will put a drag on revenue in the first 2 quarters, about $10 million each quarter, but that's revenue we're happy to avoid.
Our operating leverage for this segment by the way, in 2015 was 56%. So here, again, as we get incremental revenue and we expect to have that in 2016, you'll see continued margin enhancement.
The software businesses we think will grow at kind of mid-single digits, but they do have exceptional margins that allow us to use cash to reinvest in other transactions.
And then the recent acquisitions that we've had, Aderant, RF IDeas and On Center, are all growing at a pretty strong rate, and they have excellent cash flow performance and eventually, they, too, will become organic.
Next slide. If we look at Industrial Technology, here, in the fourth quarter, organic revenue was down 8%. It's all pretty much all oil and gas, upstream with our businesses that are related to that. Again, some context about this.
In 2014, the oil and gas portion of Industrial Technology was about 12% of revenue. And unlike RF where it's 0; and in Medical, where it's 0. In Industrial Tech, it was 12%. 14% this year. That dropped to 9% of revenue. And then our forecast for '16, we think it will be down about 6% of revenue in the segment. It's almost exclusively upstream activity for surface and water pumping projects.
We also have the divestiture in -- which came from a circle with ABEL with about -- in the low 20 to revenue that contributed nothing in the fourth quarter this year. Of course, it will be out over the [ph] next year.
Neptune grew really quite well, double-digit growth in the U.S. in the fourth quarter. The Toronto project was still there, it's a headwind as we pulled you last year it's, close to $10 million a quarter. But it finally sense that's in the first quarter of next year. So Neptune's growth in 2016 will be outsized compared to the way it has looked with the Toronto headwind in [ph] the past.
We're forecasting continuing declines really in the upstream oil and gas. It was off about 30% for 2015. And we think it will be off another 30% in 2016. But of course, it gets to be down to a smaller number. So it's about a $20 million headwind for the segment going into 2016. 
Looking at the rest of the businesses [ph] will grow at kind of low single-digit numbers, maybe a little bit better than. 
So we'll go to the next slide. Oh, I want -- should say that OP, [ph] Industrial for the year, it delevered at 40%. So with gross margins about 50% and delevering at 40%, we think that was pretty good performance.
Next slide. On Energy Systems & Controls, they had -- that's continued to falloff as one would expect particularly in the upstream arena. Their operating leverage for 2015 though was really quite good at negative 39% and their gross margins are 58%. So I think everybody performed quite nimbly, although in the fourth quarter, Compressor Controls started to see really deep dive on their project work and haven't really structured around that yet, and that activity will happen here in the first quarter. So they contributed terrifically over the last several years, but have [indiscernible] of a major decline in project work that's not going to reoccur for some long period of time.
Now in the quarter, organic growth then was off you could see 17%, FX by 4%. Our seasonal improvement actually did occur sort of as we forecasted just not quite as much. We were up 9% seasonally in the fourth quarter in Energy, but normally, we're up kind of 17% to 20% and occasionally, 25% in the fourth quarter. So we had thought will be up maybe 15% in the fourth quarter and by only coming up 9% at that kind of pullback of revenue to add in the fourth quarter, which was direct result of seeing a little less revenue that we expected out of them. 
Certainly backlogs are reduced in this segment, and oil and gas project businesses -- kind of rapidly deteriorate, although that's not a surprise.
But unbelievable growth in Zetec as both South Korea, Japan and Middle East are roaring back and in fact, we were up quite dramatically in Zetec, and we think that will accrete to a very strong performance for Zetec in 2016.
The operating margin, which really speaks to the nimbleness of the operating people we have in these businesses, was still 32.7% even though the segment was down substantially in revenue.
If we look at the -- what we're talking about here for 2016, you can see sort of high single digit organic decline for the segment. Oil and gas, we think, will be down about 15%, which will be about a $50 million drag on the settlement. So about $20 million out of Industrial, about $50 million out of Energy. The project activity is going to force Compressor Controls to do some aggressive restructuring, and I know that it's a challenge for everybody but there's no question the market requires us to do that.
And then we think we'll have modest growth in the rest of the areas in the industrial and nuclear arena.
Next slide. So here as we get into the 2016 guidance. Next slide. We created another bridge for you here for 2016, so you get a sense of what's really going on in the health of the overall business.
You can see we finished this past year '15, at $3,593 million. We expect revenue to be up between 8% to 10% in 2016, and we think organic revenue will be between 2% and 4% in the coming year. So we'll get mid-single digits organic growth out of RF and mid-single digits organic growth out of Medical. I think we'll have low single-digit organic growth out of Industrial whereas last year, you might remember, was a negative number. And then already completed acquisitions net of the ABEL divestiture is going to contribute sizable portion of revenue in 2016. We think we'll still have the high single-digit organic drop in energy but that's a big improvement over last year's organic drop. And then foreign exchange, which was $104 million last year is probably going to be up about an 80% less headwind for us in 2016. So maybe something in the $20 million to $25 million arena and that makes just as we showed you, we grew last year at 7% until you hit the oil and gas number. Just easier comps throughout the year for us once we get past the first quarter.
Next slide. So if we look at the 2016 guidance, you can see for the full year, we're saying operating cash flow we would hope would meet or exceed $1 billion. Net operating cash flow is going to have just a very limited CapEx drag for it to convert to free cash flow this past year. I think our CapEx was $36 million. We wouldn't expect it to be any higher than that this year. So certainly less than 1% of revenue, probably quite a bit less than 1% of revenue.
Free cash flow -- I'm sorry, full year adjusted DEPS, we're saying or $6.85 to $7.15 and the key assumptions around that is we got, for the full year, revenue growth of 8% to 10%; organic growth of 2% to 4%. Comps eased after the first quarter. In the first quarter, we got a lot of headwinds, we got revenue drag out of Puerto Rico, we got oil and gas that not really hit us in the first quarter last year, and we had some unique revenue coming out of Roper Pump that will continue.
We had a little higher gross cost because of bigger draw with acquisitions, but we also get benefit in earnings.
But Q1 last year at 6% organic and the last 3 quarters had 2% organic, so we certainly don't expect 6% organic net of oil and gas in the first quarter.
Our noncash amortization increases by $30 million, so our noncash amortization will be $195 million in 2016. And if you want to use cash earnings, you can add that back to the net earnings number.
Interest expense is about $25 million higher than last year to $109 million. Our tax rate is going to be somewhat somewhere in this past year in the 30% to 30.5% arena and of course, none of these include any new acquisitions, and we do expect to be pretty active in 2016 in adding additional high-quality businesses.
In the first quarter, we're going to establish guidance at $1.42 to $1.47 because of those things that we have to face in the first quarter that were not there last year, but we'll get improvement throughout the year on those things, with quite dramatic improvement in the second half, which is not based on hope but just a reality of what we know to be the case.
Next slide. As we look at the 2015 summary and then the outlook for the year, we delivered record annual results for orders, revenue, margin and net earnings, EBITDA and cash flow in '15. And that was despite quite the biggest headwind period we had with so much coming from currency and oil and gas. 
Our operating cash flow was up 11%, free cash flow also up 11%. We had terrific margin improvement with gross margins up 140 basis points to 60.7%, EBITDA margins up 80 basis points to 34.6% and free cash flow at $893 million, represented 25% of every dollar of our revenue and 132% cash conversion versus the DEPS number.
We deployed $1.8 billion in really attractive acquisitions, so we increased our dividend by 20%. 
As we go into this year, we expect to deliver record performance in '16 with that revenue growth we mentioned just the slide before at 8% to 10%, operating cash flow around $1 billion. We think we'll deploy well over $1 billion in acquisitions. It could be easily be higher than that. And we've already closed our first one with CliniSys for about $250 million in January.
We got a very attractive pipeline, we're looking at transactional on priority [ph] and another one on Monday. And so there's just a great deal of activity going on probably, the most that we've ever seen in terms of the pipeline.
We continue to compound cash, increase shareholder value last year, we go a lot of -- in 2015 and there's no reason to think we can't continue to increase our cash as we look at 2016.
So with that, John, I think we're ready for questions.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. So Deanna, we're ready for the Q&A portion of our call.
componenttext: I think so. So Deanna, we're ready for the Q&A portion of our call.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Now we'll take our first question from Shannon O'Callaghan of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Now we'll take our first question from Shannon O'Callaghan of UBS.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, just on the assumptions on the oil and gas they're down 30% for Industrial Tech, they're now, 15% for Energy, maybe just explain a little bit more the differences between those 2 decline rates and then some of the other businesses around the oil an
componenttext: Brian, just on the assumptions on the oil and gas they're down 30% for Industrial Tech, they're now, 15% for Energy, maybe just explain a little bit more the differences between those 2 decline rates and then some of the other businesses around the oil and gas within the energy segmented that you have a better outlook for.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in the Industrial, basically, Roper Pump is almost exclusively oriented around upstream oil and gas. So it's not a huge business, but it has a big, big, big drawback when you have the change. In fact, it is primarily U.S. business. So it's oil and g
componenttext: Well, in the Industrial, basically, Roper Pump is almost exclusively oriented around upstream oil and gas. So it's not a huge business, but it has a big, big, big drawback when you have the change. In fact, it is primarily U.S. business. So it's oil and gas component was down 30% in '15 from '14. And we expect it will another 30% in '16 for '15, but it's still a fairly small number. So it's about a $20 million revenue drag that we're modeling into '16. None of the other businesses in Industrial Technology have anything to do with oil and gas. They are instrument companies or -- over half is the Neptune, water pump [ph] business, which is going to grow next year. So it's just that one isolated and there's no mid-stream and downstream activity, really, in Industrial. When you get into Energy, much, much bigger total dollars of what you're talking about, about 60% of the segment is oil and gas, but only some of it is upstream, primarily the upstream portion, there are a couple of very small businesses, Viatran and that's a little bit of [indiscernible] and then quite a lot of Compressor Controls. So Compressor Controls has been living off of a great project backlog. Their service work, we expect could be a record this year, in 2016, but we think their project will drop really dramatically. It could drop $30 million, $40 million. And the midstream and downstream activity for the year has been really decent, all the way along. The only drag has been the currency. But then in the fourth quarter, we didn't get as much of a seasonal uptick in those downstream businesses as we normally do, so mostly testing businesses, so that bodes for slight deterioration, probably in '16. The rest of the Energy businesses, the 40%, are really mostly test and measurement kind of businesses and then [indiscernible] were up really sharply at Zetec, so that helps offset. And that's why we're saying 15% for Energy, but it's 30% for the upstream portion of Industrial.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then within Industrial, in terms of getting from sort of organic declines to starting to grow there again, what is the Toronto comp impact? What was in 4Q? What was it 1Q? And then what's driving that double-digit Neptune growth? I mean, is that
componenttext: Okay. And then within Industrial, in terms of getting from sort of organic declines to starting to grow there again, what is the Toronto comp impact? What was in 4Q? What was it 1Q? And then what's driving that double-digit Neptune growth? I mean, is that kind of a sustainable rate? Or what's driving that?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it certainly going to be very solid growth in 2016. It's about a $10 million dividend each quarter for the Toronto project as it fell off. There's a little bit of revenue. We're still getting out of Toronto for last-minute adjustments, but it's not v
componenttext: Yes, it certainly going to be very solid growth in 2016. It's about a $10 million dividend each quarter for the Toronto project as it fell off. There's a little bit of revenue. We're still getting out of Toronto for last-minute adjustments, but it's not very meaningful. It's just domestic growth in commercial water meters and do wins in projects. We are going to have some -- I mean, we are having share gains that are really obvious to us when we look at the data. We're going to have further share gains in 2016, that we are confident enough, based on all of our contacts with our bid process.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Shannon, I mean, the Toronto project really completed substantially in the first quarter of 2015. So it's built kind of in that $10 million comp range in the fourth quarter against the fourth quarter of '14, and then we'll have a little bit of headwi
componenttext: Yes, Shannon, I mean, the Toronto project really completed substantially in the first quarter of 2015. So it's built kind of in that $10 million comp range in the fourth quarter against the fourth quarter of '14, and then we'll have a little bit of headwind in the first quarter on a year-over-year basis, but then after that, it's going to be more normalized. So it's not an acceleration that we're looking for, it's really some headwinds that start to go away.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Deane Dray of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Deane Dray of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to go back onto the oil exposures for Industrial and Energy. Just talk about, if you could, your visibility in the businesses, specifically around orders in the quarter. And then on the organic assumed declines, maybe discuss what's volume versus
componenttext: I'd like to go back onto the oil exposures for Industrial and Energy. Just talk about, if you could, your visibility in the businesses, specifically around orders in the quarter. And then on the organic assumed declines, maybe discuss what's volume versus pricing? There's a lot of supplier squeezing that's going on in the sector, and it wouldn't be surprised to see if you're seeing some pricing pressure as well?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you talk to our salesman, they'll tell you it's massive pricing. There's no pricing pressure. That's a silly -- that's not the issue at all. It's just pure -- the biggest component, of course, is currency, but then from a unit situation, it's the
componenttext: Well, if you talk to our salesman, they'll tell you it's massive pricing. There's no pricing pressure. That's a silly -- that's not the issue at all. It's just pure -- the biggest component, of course, is currency, but then from a unit situation, it's the project work at Compressor Controls. This year, has really easy to detail that out. So those numbers are pretty good. Last year, we actually said when we initiated guidance, we thought upstream would be down about 20%. You correctly challenged us about -- CapEx was down 30%, it might not be down 30% and we said, "Well, it could be down more than 20%, but we thought we had a particular arrangement around surface drilling, which is new technology, which is rapidly gaining share, that was doing that at the time that we thought that would continue in the second quarter. But in the second quarter, they basically stopped all ordering and consumed all inventory they could and that hurt us a little bit. And then in the fourth quarter, we didn't get any seasonal balance, any -- well, we did, but not as much as you normally would. So we're very comfortable around guiding down $20 million on oil and gas, and Industrial and around $50 million in Energy, I think that's quite, quite correct. And then there is still be a little bit more drag on a nominal number basis with currency, but it's definitely not pricing. And the guys have been pretty correct all year long, except for that Q2 situation at Roper Pump where our supply agreement got suspended for that quarter.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: What were orders in the quarter for both?
componenttext: What were orders in the quarter for both?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The segment book-to-bill was like 0.88 for Energy in the third quarter...
componenttext: The segment book-to-bill was like 0.88 for Energy in the third quarter...

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it was 0.97 for Industrial. So on the Industrial side, that 0.97, they're kind of typical for a fourth quarter, but it's definitely lighter. So you've asked about visibility also. So for the product businesses, particularly around upstream and even on
componenttext: And it was 0.97 for Industrial. So on the Industrial side, that 0.97, they're kind of typical for a fourth quarter, but it's definitely lighter. So you've asked about visibility also. So for the product businesses, particularly around upstream and even on the mid and downstream, those are generally going to be book and ship inside of a relatively short window, 2 months or so. Where we do have better visibility and while we're talking more about this is on the Compressor Controls side, right? Because it's more of a project business, and that's where we saw order shortfall in the fourth quarter, leading to that 0.9 book-to-bill area. And while we're expecting that to be a tough year for the project-based business, but we can have good visibility in that area.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, you referenced back in the second quarter some of our expectations that the upstream could be worse. Just to kind of give you a data point, we had lunch on Friday with a CEO of [indiscernible] and their expectations is upstream could be down 35%, s
componenttext: Brian, you referenced back in the second quarter some of our expectations that the upstream could be worse. Just to kind of give you a data point, we had lunch on Friday with a CEO of [indiscernible] and their expectations is upstream could be down 35%, so we're in that right neighborhood. And just last question for me would be these businesses, so we talk about Roper Pumps and Compressor Controls, these are legacy Roper Industries businesses and certainly not something that you would be looking to invest in today. Now in the teeth of -- the oil pressure is here, certainly not a time to talk about divesting, but would there be an opportunity at some point to separate the Roper Industries legacy businesses from Roper Technologies where you're focusing today?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's certainly possible to talk about it quite a lot and there are a lot of different avenues for achieving that. It could be spun off as an independent entity where people would be able to make that kind of one-to-one decision about whether they wanted t
componenttext: It's certainly possible to talk about it quite a lot and there are a lot of different avenues for achieving that. It could be spun off as an independent entity where people would be able to make that kind of one-to-one decision about whether they wanted to be in that space as an investor and could be put together with another business in some kind of merger. Again, it's not something we'd likely sell because the [indiscernible] sale is just pretty prohibitive and the businesses are very good. I mean, the oil and gas businesses, we put the whole thing together, they have an EBITDA margin of 34%. And they don't take a lot of assets. They are very, very cash accretive to our number. And for those people who like EPS, they give us terrific EPS, but there's no amortization. But you're right, I mean, that -- it's something we're always going to look at and certainly, they have been more than one phone call inbound about people like to do something, but selling them is not the best thing for our investors, finding a tax-free alternative to that would be more attractive.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Joe Giordano of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Joe Giordano of Cowen and Company.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what I've been trying to get with everyone's guidance is let's kind of separate how much of the progression throughout the year is anticipating a market upturn, like an underlining market upturn and how much is specific to the company as a cadence of r
componenttext: So what I've been trying to get with everyone's guidance is let's kind of separate how much of the progression throughout the year is anticipating a market upturn, like an underlining market upturn and how much is specific to the company as a cadence of revenue that's already in hand or orders that you already have in hand? So how would you separate your expectation in the better second half versus what you know and what you're hoping?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a whole lot more what we know and then what we hope. We don't really have very many businesses with only 1 or 2 that have any kind of something that's kind of a larger macro end market. The markets that we serve are so niche, they end up being more d
componenttext: It's a whole lot more what we know and then what we hope. We don't really have very many businesses with only 1 or 2 that have any kind of something that's kind of a larger macro end market. The markets that we serve are so niche, they end up being more driven by our activity around new products or new software releases rather than kind of a hope for some macroeconomic recovery. We're not really expecting any of that. That's not something that we try to forecast. It really doesn't drive many of our businesses. But it's not as simple as orders in hand because we really don't have orders in hand for products or for activity that's going to ship in the third quarter or fourth quarter. So we're not a projects type of E&C business, like that. But it's really around many of the -- we know that we're going to be able to introduce to the niche market that we serve and let's take a new product growth in those areas.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then as you look at your pipeline into 2016, what have you seen in terms of, I guess, across the various sectors that you play in and in terms of bid-ask spreads and how they are moderating? Or how they're moving, which areas are looking
componenttext: Fair enough. And then as you look at your pipeline into 2016, what have you seen in terms of, I guess, across the various sectors that you play in and in terms of bid-ask spreads and how they are moderating? Or how they're moving, which areas are looking increasingly more attractive or increasingly less so in terms of valuation?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, in term of acquisitions?
componenttext: Oh, in term of acquisitions?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The bid-ask spread is always wide. It's always wide. We were able to deploy $1.8 billion last year, and we already got $0.25 billion done now, so we don't anticipate any difficulty at all. I do think that the notes out today are interesting. Like, so ther
componenttext: The bid-ask spread is always wide. It's always wide. We were able to deploy $1.8 billion last year, and we already got $0.25 billion done now, so we don't anticipate any difficulty at all. I do think that the notes out today are interesting. Like, so there weren't any IPOs in January. So if you were a seller of a private equity, you might continue to say whatever you think somebody's got to listen to. But the reality is, their net costs are going up and their exit strategies are diminishing. We remain the best mid-market acquirer of assets on the face of the earth. So we're not going to have any difficulty finding high-quality businesses at rational prices.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe last from you. At what point is that do you start looking -- you guys are ahead of pivoting away from some of these Energy, Industrial type of applications into where you're on with your Medical businesses. At what point do you start to look, opport
componenttext: Maybe last from you. At what point is that do you start looking -- you guys are ahead of pivoting away from some of these Energy, Industrial type of applications into where you're on with your Medical businesses. At what point do you start to look, opportunistically, a little bit more aggressively at some of these sectors that have been beaten down a little bit more?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we always look at is the cash return we can get out of an investor. And so what happens is, it's gets usually difficult for an industrial asset to have the kind of cash returns that we are going to demand. But whenever we see them, we're willin
componenttext: Well, what we always look at is the cash return we can get out of an investor. And so what happens is, it's gets usually difficult for an industrial asset to have the kind of cash returns that we are going to demand. But whenever we see them, we're willing to make investments in those. We bought a pure product company in RFID this year, which is just a world-class business with terrific leadership, very high margins, relatively light assets, but they're certainly making stuff and they're selling stuff. So it depends on the quality of what it is we see, but we would never buy something at a public market deep discount. Let's say, some energy business dropped 30%, we wouldn't buy something because it dropped 30%. We would only buy something because its forward cash returns were extremely attractive. And as generally as a rule, people overpay for low-quality assets under the theory that they're going to find some way to make them better. So we'll leave the buying and distressed assets to others. We want to buy businesses that have consistent growth and recurring revenue and light-asset models. And we haven't seen any other than RFID. We haven't seen anything in the last 2 years in the industrial segment that qualifies for them.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, could you just speak for a minute or 2 to the Medical segment in general? Again, given the '16 guidance, mid-single-digit growth and the core order growth of 7% in the fourth quarter so it looks a little attractive. Is there anything in the mix to
componenttext: Brian, could you just speak for a minute or 2 to the Medical segment in general? Again, given the '16 guidance, mid-single-digit growth and the core order growth of 7% in the fourth quarter so it looks a little attractive. Is there anything in the mix to be alert for in '16 between Medical products, Software and SaaS and Imaging? When you're talking about mid-single-digit growth, either of those -- are any of those 3 kind of leading core growth and could give us an upward bias on the margin line for Medical?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, but I sort of have to dissect it. But remember that in the Medical and Software, we have a huge amount of recurring revenue, right? So the recurring revenue, it's not going to grow by a high number. So when we say mid- to high single
componenttext: It's a good question, but I sort of have to dissect it. But remember that in the Medical and Software, we have a huge amount of recurring revenue, right? So the recurring revenue, it's not going to grow by a high number. So when we say mid- to high single digits, that has to be something that takes the whole segment into consideration. So the product portion and the new software sales have to be higher than that in order to get the whole segment up to mid-single digits. I don't think that there's any -- certainly, Sunquest in the second half of the year should have outsized growth to what it had throughout 2015, because we've had the meaningful use improvement in '14 and the beginning of '15 that it is a comparative drag and that will go away, as '16 matures. I don't think there's really any particular driver than the Medical and Software. In the software businesses in the RF component, there are some drivers that have had escalating growth. I don't know if, John, if you want to add anything to that.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think. So I think it's really well -- we expect '16 to be less by a more -- probably higher fee on the medical product side. With some continued new product introductions, we introduced some things at Verathon in the latter part of '15. So tho
componenttext: No, I don't think. So I think it's really well -- we expect '16 to be less by a more -- probably higher fee on the medical product side. With some continued new product introductions, we introduced some things at Verathon in the latter part of '15. So those start to go ramp up. We have other new products that are being introduced to the market, as well, as well as continued growth around some image-guided surgery applications that Northern Digital continues to just perform phenomenally well. And then, as Brian mentioned, in the Software and services side, that's kind of a mid-single-digit grower anyway because of the huge number recurring revenue, and that's what we expect in the latter part of '16. We're not expecting a whole lot of recovery at all in the Imaging world. I think that's expected to be back, maybe up a little bit.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just one last question, John. When you kind of speak to '16 overall, again, we all have our estimates as to what acquisitions completed will contribute to the EBIT line, but on that 2% to 4% core growth, what's kind of a midpoint conversion rate that we should see on the 2% to 4% for the core business?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Robert McCarthy of Stifel.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 2 questions. One is just kind of the old chestnut that people ask about Roper and M&A. And clearly, given the environment we're seeing and I guess, one of the cofounders of [indiscernible] just talked about the financing markets are shutting down, the
componenttext: So 2 questions. One is just kind of the old chestnut that people ask about Roper and M&A. And clearly, given the environment we're seeing and I guess, one of the cofounders of [indiscernible] just talked about the financing markets are shutting down, the sky is falling, but in terms of just coming back to that question, is there a particular types of companies that you're kind of looking at now that really went themselves to be acquired to these environments? Or really there's a real crowd out of traditional private equity and really you can kind of sweep in, besides just the normal. Is there particular vertical or end market, where you're really well positioned or well advantaged? And does this allow for bigger deals or size of a certain decile to be shaken out in this environment?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is certainly true that on things that are relatively large in potential acquisitions, there's -- maybe there will be less competition for those assets as the year unfolds than there have been in the last 3 years. I noticed on some of the large th
componenttext: Well, it is certainly true that on things that are relatively large in potential acquisitions, there's -- maybe there will be less competition for those assets as the year unfolds than there have been in the last 3 years. I noticed on some of the large things that we've looked at, if they get buffed by private equity, it isn't 1 fund, it's 3 guys going together. But that staples are still out there, I mean, we're looking at a deal [indiscernible] that has a 6.5x debt staple on it. So as long as debt staples are that high and while we wouldn't use it, private equity is going to use them, right? They can put in 4x of EBITDA, and you're still 10.5x EBITDA. And so -- the kind of businesses that we acquire and they were public, they tend to trade at 25x enterprise value to EBITDA are more. I know it's hard for people to follow that because they're looking at traditional multi-industry step, but multiples are dramatically less. So we're going to continue to look at these things that are worth a great deal from an arbitrage perspective in a public market versus what we have to pay for them. And those tend to crowd out the lesser quality of businesses, where people pay 8, 9, 10x for something that's worth 10. And we tend to pay 11 and 12x for something that's worth 25. And that's really how we get all this out [indiscernible] performance consistently over a long period of time, and that's going to continue. Now last year, we did something that I wouldn't have forecast, which is we did 6 or 7 deals to get the $2 billion. We would have rather down $1.5 billion deal and a $500 million deal, but the small deals were unbelievably compelling, and they're all growing double digits. So I mean it was a good thing to do. We are still seeing a lot of those kind of opportunities. So as the year unfolds, it will be a battle between sort of saving our powder for really large transactions and we're going ahead and investing early on things that are somewhat modest. At the end of the day, for our shareholders, the result's about the same. It's just easier for us to do a large deal than 5 small deals. But we're -- it should be an easy year for us to deploy capital very favorably.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up, I mean, just obviously and ramping up coverage of you all again after a long dormancy, the cash return investment kind of metrically used and the kind of animates your M&A and capital deployment strategy, obviously, makes a
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up, I mean, just obviously and ramping up coverage of you all again after a long dormancy, the cash return investment kind of metrically used and the kind of animates your M&A and capital deployment strategy, obviously, makes a heck of a lot of sense and I certainly have tried with a cool head with respect to the discipline around it. But I think the most important tiffany coming out of it is basically the strategy and the metrics were kind of completely aligned. In other words, you don't stretch for what is perceived as a strategic deal, because a strategic deal is one which meets the metrics, right? So I guess, the only question I have is where do you think there are risks to the CRI discipline or maybe the businesses you're looking at? Do you think it's maybe an assessment of the code? I know you used a third-party consultancy to kind of look at kind of these related intellectual property and software in association with deals. And there can be obviously risk there. There can be risk of technological substitution. Maybe if you could just talk about where were you just levelheadedly think about the risks in association with your capital redeployment strategy?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, maybe just for a second, I'll stick about the risk in general. If you look at the transactions because people were asking questions about that we buy some cheap stuff, right? So the cheap stuff in Industrial, and they're all kinds of stuff, but thei
componenttext: Well, maybe just for a second, I'll stick about the risk in general. If you look at the transactions because people were asking questions about that we buy some cheap stuff, right? So the cheap stuff in Industrial, and they're all kinds of stuff, but their public stocks are going to continue to deteriorate, and you can buy, -- "Hey, what's wrong with us." They can get disintermediated from distribution channels. They can wind up with a premium model out of Google on some bizarre thing. Or they wind up with Amazon selling past their competition at low price points. And they are all kinds of things that happen. They desperately need absorption. So, if revenue falls off, there's nothing they could do without big restructuring charges. When we get to our space, it's really around whether or not the people in the niche that we acquire have domain expertise, which is very hard for somebody to break into. And so the entry barriers for their success are entirely different. So the risk is that we continue to assess the quality of the management teams that we acquire well, and we understand whether or not there are technologies that could leapfrog what they do. So that we spent most of our time around the people aspects of the business and then around maybe risks that those people don't see that we would put a kind of different factor on. We tend to discount their forward growth projections because we don't pay for synergies, for forward growth. We only pay for what we think the business is going to deliver at the time of the acquisition. And that really puts a huge dampening effect on the risk that we might otherwise have. And we've been kind of blessed to be fortunate in that arena. But I think our disciplines are such because we actually start with somebody's balance sheet and then we start with what it takes to run the business. We don't do -- like what a private equity people do, they'll buy a software company and they'll mandate an immediate 10% reduction. One of the private equity firms out there actually goes in and does a listing of the highest paid people and they whack off the highest paid people and put new college guys in with big salary reductions. And then that kind of hideous activity doesn't manifest itself in a business for 4 or 5 years. So you have to understand what each private equity group's business model is when you're looking at the assets they hold and you are acquiring it. And I think we can do that better than anybody.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering in Medical here the product cycles and the devices seems to be coming on pretty well. Wonder if Northern Digital, Verathon, you're looking at those to be able to climb in double-digit run rates at some point. Are the product cycles that hav
componenttext: Just wondering in Medical here the product cycles and the devices seems to be coming on pretty well. Wonder if Northern Digital, Verathon, you're looking at those to be able to climb in double-digit run rates at some point. Are the product cycles that have been notable in the past few quarters, is that sort of a couple year dynamic, do you think?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do think so. Although we really seeing out of Verathon is a refresh -- so it's not a completely new product category, which actually reduces the risk for us. So these are really upgrades and extensions of their existing GlideScope like in 2015 and
componenttext: Yes, I do think so. Although we really seeing out of Verathon is a refresh -- so it's not a completely new product category, which actually reduces the risk for us. So these are really upgrades and extensions of their existing GlideScope like in 2015 and then bladder scan in 2016. And so those are kind of a couple year adoption rate that go on there. Northern Digital doesn't have to get up to double digits. [indiscernible] continue double-digit growth. They've been growing in double-digit here for a couple of years, as they're really the leader in both the optical tracking as well as the electromechanical -- I'm sorry, electromagnetic tracking for computer-assisted surgery applications. And those continue to just expand, those applications just continue to expand and whenever there's a new one that an OEM customer wants to design, they always come back to Northern Digital to serve the world leaders in that technology.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just if there's any room left there, I just wanted to expand on Rob's line of question a little bit where you had a record year, last year, in deal flow and talked about I think record pipeline volume or breadth. As you -- have you transiti
componenttext: Okay. And then just if there's any room left there, I just wanted to expand on Rob's line of question a little bit where you had a record year, last year, in deal flow and talked about I think record pipeline volume or breadth. As you -- have you transitioned more kind of wholeheartedly to CRI? And is increasingly intolerant definition of strategic kind of the reason why your pipeline and your yield has kind of accelerated to somewhat unpredictable levels?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. Let's go back and think about. The reason I said sometime ago that the Sunquest, MHA acquisitions were more transformational than the Neptune and TransCore transformations were. Because at Neptune, we paid 4x EBITDA at the enterprise in Decemb
componenttext: No, no, no. Let's go back and think about. The reason I said sometime ago that the Sunquest, MHA acquisitions were more transformational than the Neptune and TransCore transformations were. Because at Neptune, we paid 4x EBITDA at the enterprise in December 2003 to acquire Neptune at what some you probably felt was a high price for $500 million. The next year, in 2004, we just paid about 4x, again, trailing revenue with the firm, 3.5% or something; for TransCore, $600 million. Well, neither one of those businesses have blend themselves to adding exciting bolt-on activities to them or giving you domain experience in an area that was easily widened, all right? So when you acquire a leading laboratory software provider in a world that's going to have more and more laboratory instrument usage and will move to genomics in the immediate future, you have big upside ramp. We have MHA with senior living in nursing homes, all the things around nonacute hospitalization shifts and demography. These things just give you all kinds of opportunity. Well, good heavens, we've acquired now SoftWriters for MHA, which is growing at double digits. That's a terrific acquisition. We've been able to acquire CliniSys, which we can act really with Sunquest, we acquired Data Innovations, which is a phenomenal company, that guides all the instrumentation in a hospital into various systems and yet it's part of Sunquest. So that's why we didn't look at these things, which are somewhat synergistic at least in the marketplace or in the information technology side of them that we couldn't do with the Industrial and Energy businesses.
