componenttext: The Roper Technologies First Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call will now begin. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Leann, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our first quarter results. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Rob Crisci
componenttext:
Thank you, Leann, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our first quarter results. 
Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Rob Crisci, Vice President of Planning and Investor Relations. 
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. That press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also on our website. 
If you turn to Slide 2, we begin with our safe harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties, as described on this page, and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information. Next slide. 
Today we, will be discussing our results for the quarter, primarily on an adjusted non-GAAP basis. A full reconciliation between GAAP and adjusted measures is in our press release this morning and also as a part of this presentation on our website. 
For the first quarter, the difference between our GAAP results and adjusted results consist of 3 items: Our normal adjustments related to recently acquired businesses on both deferred revenue and inventory valuation, which totaled $3 million to both revenue and income measures. 
We've also adjusted our operating cash flow to account for the cash taxes paid in the first quarter for the ABEL divestiture. The ABEL divestiture, you may recall, is completed in the fourth quarter last year. 
GAAP requires this amounts, $37 million in those tax payments to be recorded as an operating cash flow item even though it is related to that divestiture. We've added this $37 million back to reflect the ongoing nature of our cash flow. 
And as you please turn to Slide 4, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President , Chief Executive Officer. And after his remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. So we'll go through today, the first quarter enterprise results, and we'll look at the details around the 4 segments and the outlook for the remaining of the year. And while we're doing that, we'll comment on the second quarter and full y
componenttext:
Thank you, John. So we'll go through today, the first quarter enterprise results, and we'll look at the details around the 4 segments and the outlook for the remaining of the year. And while we're doing that, we'll comment on the second quarter and full year guidance at the end and then take your questions. 
Next slide. So we start with the Q1 enterprise results. Go to the next slide, Slide 6. You can see there's a lot of great things here. It was a very, very good quarter for us and certainly puts us on track for a record 2016, but just one word I'd say before we get started. Mr. Humphrey over here is actually just celebrating this month his 10th completed year with the enterprise and as John refers to, it's actually his 40th quarter. 
So with that, let's take a look at our first quarter, right? Congratulations, John. Revenue 
was up 4.4% to $906 million versus the first quarter of a year ago. And organic, it was down 3.2%, which is really not the story because, excluding oil and gas, the company's organic was actually up, around 1%. And then if you look at the headwinds that we newly had with the end of Toronto and Puerto Rico and so forth, really, the underlying basis the activity seemed better than that, more like plus 3. 
Our orders were up 9% in the quarter to a record. Book-to-bill was really spectacular because we haven't had a book-to-bill above 1.01 to where 2.5 years and this time, we were at -- as you combine Industrial, Energy together, the book-to-bill was 1.04 and Medical was 1.03 and RF was even just a hair above 1, but actually had an adjustment in there for some debookings around the business that we're doing something with. Otherwise, it would have been 1.02. 
So very good backlog at $1.12 billion is also very good. Gross margin was spectacular. Gross margin was up 210 basis points to 62.1% and what's really remarkable given the macroeconomic challenges around the world is each of our 4 segments improved their gross margin in the first quarter. 
EBITDA was up 4% and reached 34% EBITDA margin. We're going to talk some more about that. We still don't report in cash earnings but increasingly, we need to make sure people understand that quality of our earnings and the cash earnings nature because we just have so much noncash and amortization. 
Our earnings per share in the first quarter were $1.50. Our operating cash flow was $245 million, which represented 27% of our revenue. 
And the recent acquisitions that we made in 2015 are really performing sort of beyond very well. They have outstanding growth. For us, almost all of our double-digit grower, so we'll talk more about that throughout today's session. 
We deployed $265 million in acquisitions in the first quarter. We have extremely big and attractive pipeline that we'll talk a little bit more. 
And so with that, we can move to the next slide, which is 7. On the income statement, just to kind of backup some idea about how important the orders were. I'll give the our book-to-bill for the last 8 quarters was -- last year, it start out at 98, or 102 on a consolidated basis here. The next quarter was 99 and 101 at 98. The year before that was 101, 99, 101, 98. 
So you have all the way back to Q2, up 13 to see something as high as the bill book-to-bill we got here, and that was despite revenue being up. 
Gross profit was up 8%. Our operating income was basically flat to the prior period, but that's only because amortization in the quarter was up 120 basis points, so $11 million, results of which is noncash, so big difference between reporting GAAP operating income and what's really happening on the cash quality of the earnings. 
Interest expense was up $7 million. We did $900 million brand offering in December, which really went -- kind of termed out what we were doing on the revolver. So it gives a substantial capacity, well over $1.8 billion to be able to deploy here capital deployment throughout the year, and it's certainly worth $0.05 impact. That said, the different last year's was 55 but 50, is in fact, that $0.05. 
Next slide. If we look here at operating and EBITDA margins as a company, you'll see that incrementally, the operating margin went from 28.7 to 27.4, that's with a 120 basis points of amortization. They added back in, you can see that essentially, it was the same outstanding result as the year before. 
On the right-hand signed though, you can see that EBITDA margins was increasingly are more important for us. And here, there's no D in either side of the equation, there's just earnings before interest tax and amortization. So that's actually up in the last 2 years, 130 basis points, from 31.6% to 32.9%. 
Furthermore, this gross margin increase we're getting is encouraging us, which we're doing at a very fast pace to step up our R&D and engineering investment, which in this quarter was up 120 basis points over the first quarter of last year and is now reaching 7% of revenue. 
Next slide. Our asset-light business model continues. It were still easily able to compound our investment in asset-light businesses. And you get some sense about how important that is. 
So there's 2 aspect to slide like this. One is our governance process with our existing businesses and the second is the quality of the businesses that we continue to acquire. 
And at the end of the first quarter, just 3 years ago, in 2013, our net number here was 7.7%. Today, it's 4%, nearly a 50% reduction in just 3 years. Inventory back in '13 was 6.8%. Today, it's 5.5%. Receivables were 19.3 and in tough market for receivables. Today, they're only 17.4. And payables were 18.4. Now, they're 19. All going our way, so we go from 7.7%, down to 4%. 
And even just in the last 2 years, they've gone from 6.3% to 4%, which is truly a remarkable number, we're very proud of for our people focusing on asset velocity and the quality of the businesses that new leadership teams are bringing to us as we acquire them. 
Next slide. If you look at our cash flow performance here, you can see in the quarter, operating cash flow was 27% of revenue, free cash flow was 26% of revenue, that's not a gross margin number, that's the free cash flow to revenue number, 26%. 
Trailing 12-month operating cash conversion is 135%, and even though the cash conversion in the quarter is above 150, we really thought it's much more balanced to look at the trailing 12 months' operating cash flow to eliminate quarterly seasonality that occur sometime. So even there, you can see we've gone from 8 44 to 9 13 and we fully expect this year operating cash flow for the full year would be $1 billion or more. 
We're continuing to compound cash flow despite these macroeconomic challenges and they're quite substantial for us. We had about $100 million of foreign exchange in the last 12 months and another $100 million of oil and cash headwinds and also the Toronto project for millions of dollars and the Puerto Rico escape, which was another $10 million a quarter. So that compounding is still continuing. The same we would expect to continue. And we still think cash is the best measure of performance. 
Next slide. If we look at the financial position, the balance sheet is in really great shape. It gives us tremendous amount of powder for capital deployment in our pipeline is really is good, maybe the best it's ever been. 
Here, you can see, we still have $0.5 billion of cash. Our undrawn revolver is actually paid off. Now, it's $1.850 billion, which is very substantial if you look at cash and the undrawn revolver, you'd be over $2.3 billion. 
And you could see the EBITDA at $1.256 billion will continue to grow handsomely throughout the year, so we'll have a very solid debt ratio opportunities. 
If you look at the last 15 months, we've deployed over $2 billion in acquisitions and with a $1.8 billion undrawn revolver, we could absolutely repeat that effort and deploy another $2 billion in the next 15 to 18 months. 
Next slide. Here, we get into the very specific segment detail. 
Next slide. So in the first quarter, the segment performance, you can see here was, again, very strong all the way across the line on our EBITDA measurements, down at the bottom. There are 2 really big messages that we try to convey with this slide. First is that our RF software segment and the medical solutions segments together represent over 3/4 of the company's total EBITDA. But there's an equally important message here on the left-hand side, where we look at the energy and industrial businesses, which remain as really extraordinary businesses. 
Those 2 businesses you can see had 25% EBITDA and Energy even with all the difficulty that you see, we have very nimble leadership and the quality of this businesses still allow us to drive this kind of result. 
If you combine the 2 together, $119 million in energy and $171 billion in Industrial, you only have $300 million out of our 906 in revenue, and yet we have $81 million of EBITDA on $300 million base or 27% and those EBITDA margins in Energy is going to continue to improve throughout the year. So great extraordinary businesses in industrial and energy despite the oil and gas and oil and gas is becoming less and less critical. And here, it's well less than 9% of revenue. 
All right, next slide. We start off with the smallest segment, which is energy. Energy had negative organic in the quarter of 14%, but essentially, all of that was driven by the oil and gas business, which now represents just a little over half of the total segment. 
And inside Energy, it's different than the industrial portion of oil and gas because our energy business is primarily downstream, about 75% downstream, about 25% upstream. And the FX, as you can see, was 1 point. Oil and gas as a portion of the energy segment was down a little over 20%, which is pretty much consistent with what we expected throughout the year. The biggest challenge in there used to be our diesel engine shutoff valve business. This year, we'll shift over with our compressor control business and they're moving quickly to try to address everything they can do from a shortfall in projects that we'll see throughout the year. 
Very nimble execution. We haven't really talked to the market about any restructuring we've done, which has been pretty considerable. I will do a little bit more in the second quarter, but we're really not even asking from an adjustment in our restructuring investments because payback is pretty quick. 
Zetec in the quarter did extremely well, it's up high single digits. There's a lot of activity around the power generation side of nuclear and Zetec is best-in-class in this area, and it's going to enjoy some continuing tailwinds for the next couple of years. 
And then just as we move to thinking about the remainder of the year, Q2 to Q4, I'll just remind you that with the pull back in oil and gas, about half of the energy systems business is actually industrial measurement technologies. 
We expect high single digit organic decline in the rest of the year, but that's just because of the oil and gas. And then we think we'll get this modest growth in the other half of the sector, and we think margins will improve throughout the year sequentially.  And energy, as you can see, now, is down to only 9% of the company's EBITDA. 
Next slide. If you look at Industrial Technology, the same situation with the oil and gas. Organic as a segment was down 5%. However, if they exclude oil and gas, industrial was up organically, 3% in the quarter. 
So the upstream activity, which in here is really Roper Pump and a little bit up adjacency there, that upstream is about 80% of the market. And the total value of that is only about $10 million out of $171 million in the segment, so it's down to less than 5% of revenue. 
Neptune had a really strong quarter, they were up double digits and enjoy a very good U.S. which overcame the fact this was the last quarter with the negative Toronto project variants, which was mid-millions of dollars of headwind. 
This is segment EBITDA margins, I think, you're going to look at 2, which were really 30.1% on industrial. So the performance, despite any of the headwinds that you see, is still very solid. 
In second half of the year, we're looking at kind of low single digit organic growth for the segment. We don't see any improvement in upstream oil and gas, we think that will actually continue to decline a little bit. But we'll have kind of flat to modest growth in all of the other markets and then very strong growth at Neptune because as we get into the second quarter, the Toronto project tailwind is essentially behind us, and that was worth quite a bit of -- will be quite a positive various now in 2, 3 and 4. 
Next slide. If we look at the RF Technology and software business, and we have try the software recognition in here because the software business is actually becoming as large -- or larger than the tolling business. 
So when we look at the segment, you can see organic was down 1 %, but actually, organic would have been of up, excluding the roll off of the Puerto Rico exit that we had, which was $10 million just in that quarter. 
We had record margin performance throughout the segment, very strong software and SaaS business growth with terrific margins and cash flow in all of those businesses. 
Aderant, our most recent acquisition is performing very well. We've got several new winds, which are strategic importance that Play Go community can be talking about and has already started to discuss and comment on our share gains. 
In the toll and traffic area, as we say, our ITS business was down because of Puerto Rico. Our tech business continued to be strong, very good project execution. 
I'd also want to point out that, that OP margin, which was up 170 basis points to 32.2, again, belies the quality of the cash margin. Our EBITDA margins were at 39.2%, up 360 basis points, so the first quarter of the year ago. 
As we look to the second quarter, we expect flat organic growth in Q2 only because we still have one more quarter of the Puerto Rico drag of about $10 million, and that's 3 to 4 points. 
But in the second half, we'll have a much stronger organic growth because that Puerto Rico comps will be going away. 
We'll get multiple opportunities, we think, in the TransCore projects. We have very exceptional amount of bids in line, we're pretty confident in a lot of those. The timing of when those are able to be announced will be important for us. 
And then RF IDeas, which is doing phenomenally well, will become organic in the fourth quarter, so that will help our organic revenue comparisons. 
The software and SaaS businesses should grow kind of mid- to high single digits. Feel a little better than we might have expected previously in the give us strong cash returns. And then Aderant is going to continue to gain share, which will help this segment. 
Next slide. Here, we look at the medical solutions. Medical solutions, boy, it's another EBITDA margin story. You see the operating profit margin at 34.7%, but that just because of a lot of noncash amortization. Our EBITDA margin is 43.5% in medical. 
Organic was up 2%, acquisitions added 13%, but medicals organic as a standalone portion of the segment, was up 6% organically, while imaging was down 13%. We had double-digit growth in the medical products, which really was driven primarily by Verathon and Northern Digital. The acquisitions that we made in this segment are performing extremely well. If you put them all together, they actually are growing both at double-digit revenue and EBITDA basis. 
We had a really exceptional growth at Strata, which is up very dramatically as more hospitals understand what we're doing and are signing up our SaaS solutions on their cost visibility and how they contain and structure their costs. 
We acquired a small business called PCI Medical in the quarter, which will boost Civco's offering in ultrasound, and that business closed and led some revenue for us. 
If you look at the balance of the year, you have a high single digit organic growth in the segment. That comes from continued strength in the medical arena and then Strata, SoftWriters and Data Innovations become organic in Q2, which will make those comps standout, with very strong performance in all of those acquisitions, the IPA business that we announced some time ago has done particularly well from a growth perspective. 
Imaging will continue to improve with kind of substantial gains out of Gatan. Gatan, we're pouring a lot of money into innovation at Gatan to focus on cryo OEM markets. These involve significant R&D investments but with exciting out year opportunities. 
Some of you have read about the discovery of the Zika virus and how that was done and our products were absolutely crucial to the discovery technologies that have been announced recently. 
We have positive contributions from our CliniSys acquisition. Although CliniSys comes in initially at lower margins than the rest of the business, but we'll continue to improve those as we work with them. 
Sunquest investments and genetics continues. We acquired on -- just a day after the quarter, so we didn't included it here, GeneInsight, which is a technology and business that was really built by Partners Health that we've been doing in concert with and will have long-term implications in the out years here at medical. 
Also we'll just say that when you look at medical in this pie chart down here, it's 43% of the company's total EBITDA. And to put that in perspective, you can see there's energy the smallest piece of that pie in industrial is the next smallest. Those 2 together, only 24% of our EBITDA and medical is 43% and RF is 33%. So you can see what the future looks like. 
Next slide. So here, we'll get into the guidance of the company for the balance of the year. Next slide. 
So the guidance update we're going to continue our current guidance as we articulated at the beginning of the year, so we said the full year will be between $6.85 and $7.15 with the midpoint at $7 and then operating cash flow would be about $1 billion. And our tax rate guidance is the same as it was at the beginning of the year and really everything else, we see the same sort of revenue opportunities. There's one thing we'd say about the second quarter where we established the guidance at $1.56 to $1.61. We had an extraordinarily low tax rate in the second quarter last year than some people were maybe not looking at carefully. Tax rate was only 25%. We would expect the tax rate in the second quarter to be 30% to 30.5%. 
Another piece of good news when we look at FY, we're really comfortable with the second half of the year is that we're not really seeing any industrial contagion at all in those portions of either industrial energy businesses that are not oil and gas. And certainly, at the beginning of the year, that was something that many people were worried about. 
And the high end of our range will really be dependent on production rates and project timing and seasonal activity. So we feel quite good about reinforcing the full year guidance. 
Next slide. If we look at the summary of 2016, it pretty simples series of things here, right? Revenue is up 4.4%. Medical and software and Neptune, we're able to offset all of those declines in oil and gas. Our orders reached record level and got over $1 billion backlog. Our gross margin, which we'd like you to know how customers continue to feel about us and the products and services we provide, were up 210 basis points and as we said each of the 4 segments increased their gross margin. We're investing at fastest rates in our history in R&D. Our EBITDA margin you can see is 32.9%. Not all EBITDA is the same. We're always sometimes frustrated when people tell us about some of these EBITDA margins but it's really mostly D and then CapEx sucks away. And in our world, the leakage between EBITDA at 34 and EBITDA at 32.9 is only 110 basis points. 
EBITDA, as we said, was up 4% to 3.07%. Acquisitions performing very well. We really can't say enough about how well the acquired leadership teams are performing and how well they've embraced the Roper governance process. Every single one of these acquisitions is outperforming our expectation, and we have very attractive pipeline. We expect that we would -- as said earlier, we expect to deploy over $1 billion in the year, and it could easily be more than that. 
So great quarter, on track for record 2016. And with that, we'll open it up for questions.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our first question from Scott Davis from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our first question from Scott Davis from Barclays.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just trying to get a sense. I don't think I've ever asked this question before, and you may not have the answer off the top of your hand. But you say 2015 acquisitions are performing very well, and clearly, that looks to be the case. But can you quantify
componenttext: Just trying to get a sense. I don't think I've ever asked this question before, and you may not have the answer off the top of your hand. But you say 2015 acquisitions are performing very well, and clearly, that looks to be the case. But can you quantify that? Is there kind of the cash return on capital on those deals that you could quote for kind of first 12 months out or expect it for 2016 or something that we could hang at on?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, you've been around us a lot to know that I'm not a fan of return on invested capital where people look at stuff and don't add back accumulated depreciation and don't really realize how much future growing cash their CapEx will be. So in our
componenttext: Well, I think, you've been around us a lot to know that I'm not a fan of return on invested capital where people look at stuff and don't add back accumulated depreciation and don't really realize how much future growing cash their CapEx will be. So in our world, we look at cash return on investment. So in that case, if you look at the net earnings of the business and then you add back the noncash charges, and you divide it by the gross investment, which is the physical plant and equipment plus accumulated depreciation, plus net working capital. All of those acquisitions all well above 1% cash returns. Many of them are in the several 100% cash return basis. And some of them get paid in advance for what they do, so they have a negative cash return, which is even more powerful. So they're all doing very well. I think as a general rule anymore, you can assume that our acquisitions are going to come in and they're going to be substantially above the 34% EBITDA margin that the overall enterprise has and that they're going to have higher gross margins than the enterprise and they're going to have higher cash returns than the enterprise.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And as far as I mean you put a lot of capital to work last year, I think neighborhood of $1.8 billion, $1.85 billion. Would you anticipate, I mean you, say over $1 billion in 2016, but he also said, you have $1.8 million-or-so of firepo
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And as far as I mean you put a lot of capital to work last year, I think neighborhood of $1.8 billion, $1.85 billion. Would you anticipate, I mean you, say over $1 billion in 2016, but he also said, you have $1.8 million-or-so of firepower. Would you anticipate something closer to $1 billion or closer to the $1.8 billion that you have in the upper? Is it just as a potential, or is it just too early to say?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we don't sort of budget like let's deploy $1 billion. So just think about what we think about it is very simple is, we're going to deploy our cash flow, we're going to lever it 3x or more that to the acquired EBITDA. So it gives us usua
componenttext: Well, I think that we don't sort of budget like let's deploy $1 billion. So just think about what we think about it is very simple is, we're going to deploy our cash flow, we're going to lever it 3x or more that to the acquired EBITDA. So it gives us usually, it's part between 1.35 and 1.5x our -- the powder of whatever our cash flow is. So we have $1 billion in operating cash flow. We've had some dividends or whatever and we multiply that to the acquisitions, it would be very easy for us to deploy $1.3 billion or $1.5 billion all the time. So that's why we say, we'll deploy $8 billion over the next 4 or 5 years. And as we said, we deployed $2 billion in the last 15 months, we can easily deployed $2 billion in the next 15 months. So it's not like a budgetary thing, Scott. I mean, we're looking at things now that are over $2 billion, and we're looking at things that in the mid- to hundreds of millions and which ones we do and when they close is never thought of us a budget kind of thing. But our balance sheet capacity, and our debt ratios give us as much or more opportunity to invest once we've ever had.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016

componenttext: We did a little bit towards at the end of last year anticipation to the difficulty with it more in the first quarter, we'll do a couple million dollars here probably in the second quarter. Some of that -- you make the announcement, it takes a long time people in Europe. But we'll continue to pull back a little bit on the sort of baseline SG&A. But the businesses are really small. I think if you add them all up, we had about $65 million of oil and gas revenue in energy and about $10 million in industrial, right? So they really add huge cost basis. They're very high-margin businesses. If you look at them with sort of 30% pretax numbers or higher, there's just not a lot of cost inside that take out. We don't have big back recently we have to worry about with absorption issues and what have you. So another couple million, I think, and we feel like we could be.

That does imply and in fact, it's a part of our expectation that the second half will be in the mid-single digits organic growth. Second quarter will be about flat.

componenttextpreview: Okay, but at least flat, okay. And then just one last question on the RF business, the EBIT margin there, we have some real positive puts and takes, namely Puerto Rico's exit and then Aderant coming into the revenue profit number. But is it kind of a rese

And then just one last question on the RF business, the EBIT margin there, we have some real positive puts and takes, namely Puerto Rico's exit and then Aderant coming into the revenue profit number. But is it kind of a reset EBIT run rate that starts to push 32%? Is that start to be somewhat sustainable at that level?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes, I think it will be -- it will be in the low 30% range for the year. Of course, the timing of that, the software business that we have are clearly higher-margin. The timing associated with some of our toll and traffic projects, which are oftenti
componenttext: Sure, yes, I think it will be -- it will be in the low 30% range for the year. Of course, the timing of that, the software business that we have are clearly higher-margin. The timing associated with some of our toll and traffic projects, which are oftentimes a little bit more on the equity side, we had a little bit more the cost components to them even though there's not any negative drag from a cash flow perspective. Those margins come in a little bit below the average for the segment, and so it's about timing of the ITS, the the toll and traffic project in fact that. We still see north of 30% margins here for the remainder of the year.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the thing on the medical that you want or we want to have people understand, we're going to continue to make acquisitions there. We have extraordinary margins that we had with Sunquest and MHA. We're going to make a lot of acquisitions, we're  goi
componenttext: I think the thing on the medical that you want or we want to have people understand, we're going to continue to make acquisitions there. We have extraordinary margins that we had with Sunquest and MHA. We're going to make a lot of acquisitions, we're  going to have better than enterprise margins, but they will be dilutive to software components inside medical. So it doesn't bother us in any way. Now medical products had spectacular performance versus the medical software, which in services, so we can put Sunquest and MHA and then medical software services component, and they were down a little bit organically in the first quarter. Medical products was up more than double digits and then of course, we still have a little bit corruption around imaging because we've actually been intentionally winding down certain kinds of imaging businesses, while we're going to have much better growth in Gatan. But the camera stuff is yes, we're trying to only participate in profitable markets and the like. I don't if that helps you, but that's the best way to explain it.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we like that they're not going down. They're inching ahead in the sort of low single digit growth in both sectors. Industrial is going to have better growth in Neptune. And in energy we're getting a little bit of growth in small business called DJ I
componenttext: Well, we like that they're not going down. They're inching ahead in the sort of low single digit growth in both sectors. Industrial is going to have better growth in Neptune. And in energy we're getting a little bit of growth in small business called DJ Instruments. We have business called Alpha and we have stronger second half and Zetec is sort of high single digits, might even get the 10% growth. That's really becoming a secular trend for that, so for a while, with Fukushima and other problems with bringing things online, Zetec was really challenged. But today, people are working with us on all kinds of the applications, so we feel really quite good about that, but it's a relatively small business within the enterprise, but nonetheless, important.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Joe Ritchie with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Joe Ritchie with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, my first question is, I want to go back to your comment on M&A. Brian, you said it's the best it's ever been. I'm just curious, how much of that is being driven by the IPO market not being all that great right now and P is having a hard time like
componenttext: I guess, my first question is, I want to go back to your comment on M&A. Brian, you said it's the best it's ever been. I'm just curious, how much of that is being driven by the IPO market not being all that great right now and P is having a hard time like exiting. I'm just wondering what the driving factors are there.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's really the IPO market because generally, the kinds of things we acquired are things that probably wouldn't go the IPO route, they would either go through a strategic or they get flipped to another private equity group. So I think there'
componenttext: I don't think it's really the IPO market because generally, the kinds of things we acquired are things that probably wouldn't go the IPO route, they would either go through a strategic or they get flipped to another private equity group. So I think there's a lot of forces that work. It's certainly been lumpy feedback to sellers about just how much debt capacity they can get on things, although frankly, we don't ever see any well. we see one thing right now it's done 6x stable and then other one that we're really pursuing has 6 75 stable. They're still some 7 stable. But the cost of debt has flipped around quite a lot. Sometimes, the mezzanine portion and secured bonds are 10.5% and other times, it's 9%. The LIBOR at floor, comes into play sometimes and then may be you get 4.75 in the term loan. But there really isn't because there will be a LIBOR of 100 and 5 75. So I do think that there are a lot of private equity people feel that they've got an asset that they're going to sell in the foreseeable future. It may still be as good a time now to sell. And they changed weekly. I mean, first, they're very opportunistic, right? So in our situation, we are not affected by those things and our ability to finance stuff is certainly easier and better than their cost to debt. So I think that helps. But also, there's a lot of things we're looking have -- they have been in various portfolios for a while, and they need to get out, they might be more worried about the financing markets in 2017 than they are now, so I can't think of the time we made a call somebody to talk about their business that they haven't said, come on over.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's interesting color and helpful. I guess, switching gears a little bit. You mentioned some of kind of the known headwinds in the first half with kind of Puerto Rico and Toronto. I guess, as we look at the second half ramp, what do you need to see, I
componenttext: That's interesting color and helpful. I guess, switching gears a little bit. You mentioned some of kind of the known headwinds in the first half with kind of Puerto Rico and Toronto. I guess, as we look at the second half ramp, what do you need to see, I guess, from in order standpoint? How important is the second quarter to hit your organic growth ramp in the second half?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what happens is, just think about the things that are going away that are affecting us negatively. I mean, if you adjust it for all of our headwinds, which is kind of ridiculous, we just [indiscernible] think it's bad, it's great, so but if you real
componenttext: Well, what happens is, just think about the things that are going away that are affecting us negatively. I mean, if you adjust it for all of our headwinds, which is kind of ridiculous, we just [indiscernible] think it's bad, it's great, so but if you really look at headwinds we would have been up 3.5% organically right now. So the idea that we're going to be up 2% of 4% organically over the course of the year is not a big challenge. I mean we should do pretty well in the second half but thinks it can affect that are going to be the adoption rate of new products and some versions of software that are rolling out in the second half, and you never know what those adoption rates look like, right? So if they're high, then we have a much better opportunity to get to that midpoint number and above. If they're moderate, then it's harder. The second thing, the tolling projects, we have an enormous amount, a bid activity right now, but there is never anything us as a supplier can do to influence the beginning or the execution of those projects. So if they go at an expected pace, then that helps. If they go at a slow pace, and it's not particularly helpful. And then last year, we got nothing out of the year in instrumentation businesses in terms of seasonality. That's the only time that's happened in a decade. So we would expect to get some more modest return to seasonality in the fourth quarter in those instrumentation businesses. So those are the things that will determine where we're at. But within our guidance, we're certainly comfortable that we're going to be within our guidance for the year, irrespective of what happens with Q2 orders.

componenttext: All the restructuring is centered around the oil and gas businesses. And so, a substantial amount of that is at Roper Pump, which is virtually all, if not almost all upstream and has just collapsed. I mean, it will your breadth away if you look at the numbers in the first quarter of '14 versus here. So we've done quite a bit of restructuring there, and we've done some restructuring in Compressor Controls, and we'll continue to do more because the underlying service revenue continue to be good and even grow. But the project activity around the pressure controls, they will be off quite substantially. So in Q2, I'm going to guess $2 million additional as some of the European things finally come before. Be less than $3 million or $4 million in the last 6 months, I'd say.

And so it to put a little bit of context around, we'll take big restructuring charges that cost a lot of cash because you have to close down factories or take out capacity. But we have had quite a substantial reduction in the number of people to workforce in those segments.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: While the reality is that if you look up the industrial and energy businesses, they just have outstanding independent results, right? So they'd be kind of consolidated businesses with 30% EBITDA. They get all the internal investment they need, and they tu
componenttext: While the reality is that if you look up the industrial and energy businesses, they just have outstanding independent results, right? So they'd be kind of consolidated businesses with 30% EBITDA. They get all the internal investment they need, and they turn a lot of positive cash. So our view on that, at least for now is, that good grief. I mean, why wouldn't you want to have a portfolio that you could deploy all of your cash into the highest possible returning businesses? So why deploy -- why cheat the capital deployment model by forcing to invest in businesses with inherently lower returns than the technology businesses with inherently higher returns. It just doesn't make any sense for our investors. From an investor viewpoint, if you split the industrial and energy and say, "Oh, yipee, you're going to redeploy cash and stuff that produces dramatically lower returns than the high stuff? " I don't know why investors would like us for doing that.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think so. We'll continue to watch what people say about that. There is  -- GAAP really does distort a lot of things around cash, so I think we're content with showing people what the GAAP number is and what the non-GAAP number isn't. This pa
componenttext: Well, I don't think so. We'll continue to watch what people say about that. There is  -- GAAP really does distort a lot of things around cash, so I think we're content with showing people what the GAAP number is and what the non-GAAP number isn't. This particular year though, because all these acquisitions come in with lots of noncash amortization, so it doesn't show up in operating profit, it distorts the number. So we want to have people understand that things are absolutely fine here. But we haven't gone to the point of saying, well, her  what the cash earnings are and here's our share count, that's the earnings, cash earnings per-share basis. We think investors are smart enough to figure that out.

componenttext: Okay. And then perhaps another area where there's a little distortion from the sales of the acquired businesses. You talked about the added amortization component of SG&A, but that was up a lot, too. Is that an area to will away do deals in that contribution on SG&A to sales or is your comments on ramping up our D&E more important thought there?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure we understand that question, Christopher. So here's what happens when you do an acquisition, say $1 billion acquisition, you're going to have 2.5% or 3% or maybe more of the purchase price filling into noncash amortization. So if you deploy $
componenttext: I'm not sure we understand that question, Christopher. So here's what happens when you do an acquisition, say $1 billion acquisition, you're going to have 2.5% or 3% or maybe more of the purchase price filling into noncash amortization. So if you deploy $1 billion, you're going to have all that cash deployment that's gone into something, they're never coming back. It's not like capital your we invest and continue to invest in and that depreciation is called in the future. So that noncash amortization of $1 billion might be $30 million. So it shows up in GAAP as a reduction in operating profit when the reality, it's an increase in cash earnings, so that's all we're talking about.

Our sales investment and product management they're excelling, they're probably up another 110 basis points. I think that's going to change. We're going to try to drive for long-term growth.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as we continue to be much more of a technology company as opposed to manufacturing company, SG&A is where there's an awful -- that's where our value add for customers. It's not really the cost of goods sold line where it's about what are you able to m
componenttext: And as we continue to be much more of a technology company as opposed to manufacturing company, SG&A is where there's an awful -- that's where our value add for customers. It's not really the cost of goods sold line where it's about what are you able to machine the widget more efficiently than the next guy, is the intellectual accountable, which is inherent in the research and development is and engineering, it's in the customer support and customer application people to show up us the SG&A. But those are value-added resources for us. And as we continue to more of a technology company, that's how our P&L will continue to look like, with less cost of goods sold and more on the SG&A side. Not as a cost to be reduced, but as an investment in the value of producing parts of our enterprise.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Leann, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our first quarter results. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Rob Crisci
componenttext:
Thank you, Leann, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our first quarter results. 
Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Rob Crisci, Vice President of Planning and Investor Relations. 
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. That press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also on our website. 
If you turn to Slide 2, we'll begin with our safe harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties, as described on this page, and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information. Next slide. 
Today, we'll be discussing our results for the quarter, primarily on an adjusted non-GAAP basis. A full reconciliation between GAAP and adjusted measures is in our press release this morning and also as a part of this presentation on our website. 
For the first quarter, the difference between our GAAP results and adjusted results consist of 3 items: our normal adjustments related to recently acquired businesses on both deferred revenue and inventory valuation, which total $3 million to both revenue and income measures. 
We've also adjusted our operating cash flow to account for the cash taxes paid in the first quarter for the ABEL divestiture. The ABEL divestiture, you may recall, is completed in the fourth quarter last year. 
GAAP requires this amount, $37 million in those tax payments, to be recorded as an operating cash flow item even though it is related to that divestiture. We've added this $37 million back to reflect the ongoing nature of our cash flow. 
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 4, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. Then after his remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. So we'll go through today the first quarter enterprise results, and we'll look at the detail around the 4 segments and the outlook for the remaining of the year. And while we're doing that, we'll comment on the second quarter and full yea
componenttext:
Thank you, John. So we'll go through today the first quarter enterprise results, and we'll look at the detail around the 4 segments and the outlook for the remaining of the year. And while we're doing that, we'll comment on the second quarter and full year guidance at the end, and then take your questions. 
Next slide. So we start with the Q1 enterprise results. Go to the next slide, Slide 6. You can see there's a lot of great things here. It was a very, very good quarter for us and certainly puts us on track for a record 2016. 
But just one word I'd say before we get started. Mr. Humphrey over here is actually just celebrating this month his 10th completed year with the enterprise. And as John refers to, it's actually his 40th quarter. So with that, let's take a look at our first quarter, right? Congratulations, John. 
Revenue was up 4.4% to $906 million versus the first quarter of the year ago. And organic, you can see it was down 3.2%, which is really not the story because, excluding oil and gas, the company's organic was actually up around 1%. And if you look at the headwinds that we knew we had with the end of Toronto and Puerto Rico and so forth, really, the underlying basis of the activity seemed better than that, more like plus 3%. 
Our orders are up 9% in the quarter to a record. Book-to-bill was really spectacular because we haven't had a book-to-bill above 1.01 for 2.5 years. And this time, we were at -- if you combine Industrial and energy together, the book-to-bill was 1.04 and Medical was 1.03. And RF was even just a hair above 1 but actually had an adjustment in there for some debookings around the business that we're doing something with. And otherwise, it would have been 1.02. So very good backlog at $1.12 billion is also very good. 
Gross margin was spectacular. Gross margin was up 210 basis points to 62.1%. And what's really remarkable given the macroeconomic challenges around the world is each of our 4 segments improved their gross margin in the first quarter. 
EBITDA was up 4% and reached 34% EBITDA margins. We're going to talk some more about that. We still don't report on cash earnings. But increasingly, we need to make sure people understand the quality of our earnings and the cash earnings nature because we just have so much noncash amortization. Our earnings per share in the first quarter were $1.50. Our operating cash flow was $245 million, which represented 27% of our revenue. 
And the recent acquisitions that we made in 2015 are really performing sort of beyond very well. They have outstanding growth. For us, almost all are double-digit growers, so we'll talk more about that throughout today's session. 
We deployed $265 million in acquisitions in the first quarter. We have an extremely big and attractive pipeline that we'll talk a little bit more. 
And so with that, we can move to slide -- next slide, which is 7. On the income statement. Just to kind of back up some idea about how important the orders were, I'll give you our book-to-bill for the last 8 quarters was -- last year, it started out at 0.98 or 1.02 on a consolidated basis here. The next quarter was 0.99 and 1.01 at 0.98. Year before that was 1.01, 0.99, 1.01, 0.98. So if -- you have all the way back to Q2 of '13 to see something as high as the book-to-bill we got here, and that was despite revenue being up. 
Gross profit was up 8%. Our operating income was basically flat to the prior period, but that's only because amortization in the quarter was up 120 basis points. So our $11 million result of which is noncash, so big difference between reporting GAAP operating income and what's really happening on the cash quality of the earnings. 
Interest expense was up $7 million. We did a $900 million bond offering in December, which really went -- kind of termed out what we were doing on the revolver. So it gives us a substantial capacity, well over $1.8 billion, to be able to deploy here a capital deployment throughout the year, and it's certainly worth the $0.05 impact. That said, the difference between last year's $1.55 and $1.50 is, in fact, that $0.05. 
Next slide. If we look here at the operating and EBITDA margins as a company, you'll see that incrementally, the operating margin went from 28.7% to 27.4%. That's with the 120 basis points of amortization. You add it back in, you can see that essentially, it was the same outstanding result as the year before. 
On the right-hand signed, though, you can see the EBITDA margins, which increasingly are more important for us. And here, there's no D in either side of that equation. This is just earnings before interest, tax and amortization. So that's actually up in the last 2 years 130 basis points from 31.6% to 32.9%. Furthermore, this gross margin increase we're getting is encouraging us, which we're doing at a very fast pace to step up our R&D and engineering investment, which in this quarter was up 120 basis points over the first quarter of last year and is now reaching 7% of revenue. 
Next slide. Our asset-light business model continues. We're still easily able to compound our investment in asset-light businesses. And you get some sense about how important that is. So there's 2 aspects to a slide like this: one is our governance process with our existing businesses and the second is the quality of the businesses that we continue to acquire. And at the end of the first quarter just 3 years ago in 2013, our net number here was 7.7%. Today, it's 4%, nearly a 50% reduction in just 3 years. Inventory back in '13 was 6.8%. Today, it's 5.5%. Receivables were 19.3%, and in a tough market for receivables. Today, they're only 17.4%. And payables were 18.4%. And now they're 19%, all going our way. So we go from 7.7% down to 4%. 
And even just in the last 2 years, they've gone from 6.3% to 4%, which is truly a remarkable number. We're very proud of all of our people focusing on asset velocity and the quality of the businesses that new leadership teams are bringing to us as we acquire them. 
Next slide. If you look at our cash flow performance here, you can see in the quarter, operating cash flow was 27% of revenue, free cash flow was 26% of revenue. That's not a gross margin number, that's the free cash flow to revenue number, 26%. Trailing 12 months operating cash conversion is 135%. And even though the cash conversions in the quarter is above 150%, we really thought it's much more balanced to look at the trailing 12 months operating cash flow to eliminate quarterly seasonality that occurs sometimes. So even there, you can see we've gone from $844 million to $913 million. And we fully expect this year's operating cash flow for the full year would be $1 billion or more. 
We're continuing to compound cash flow despite these macroeconomic challenges, and they're quite substantial for us. We had about $100 million of foreign exchange in the last 12 months; and another $100 million of oil and gas headwinds; and also the Toronto project for millions of dollars; and the Puerto Rico escape, which was another $10 million a quarter. So the compounding is still continuing the same way we would expect to continue. And we still think cash is the best measure of performance. 
Next slide. If we look at the financial position, the balance sheet is in really great shape. It gives us tremendous amount of powder for capital deployment, and our pipeline is -- really is good, maybe the best it's ever been. 
Here, you can see we still have $0.5 billion of cash. Our undrawn revolver is actually paid off. Now it's $1.850 billion, which is very substantial. If you looked at cash and the undrawn revolver, you'd be over $2.3 billion. And you could see the EBITDA at $1.256 billion will continue to grow handsomely throughout the year, so we'll have very solid debt ratio opportunities. 
If you look at the last 15 months, we've deployed over $2 billion in acquisitions. And with a $1.8 billion undrawn revolver, we could absolutely repeat that effort and deploy another $2 billion in the next 15 to 18 months. 
Next slide. Here, we get into the very specific segment detail. 
Next slide. So in the first quarter, the segment performance, you can see here, was again very strong all the way across the line on our EBITDA measurements down at the bottom. There are 2 really big messages that we try to convey with this slide: first is that our RF software segment and the medical solutions segments together represent over 3/4 of the company's total EBITDA. But there's an equally important message here on the left-hand side, where we look at the energy and industrial businesses, which remain as really extraordinary businesses. Those 2 businesses you can see have 25% EBITDA in energy. Even with all the difficulty that you see, we have very nimble leadership, and the quality of these businesses still allow us to drive this kind of result. 
If you combine the 2 together, $119 million in energy and $171 million in industrial, you only have $300 million out of our $906 million in revenue, and yet you have $81 million of EBITDA on a $300 million base or 27%. And those EBITDA margins in energy are going to continue to improve throughout the year. So great extraordinary businesses in industrial and energy despite oil and gas. And oil and gas is becoming less and less critical. And here, it's well less than 9% of revenue. 
All right, next slide. We start off with the smallest segment, which is energy. Energy had negative organic in the quarter of 14%. But essentially, all of that was driven by the oil and gas business, which now represents just a little over half of the total segment. 
And inside energy, it's different than the industrial portion of oil and gas because our energy business is primarily downstream, about 75% downstream, about 25% upstream. And the FX, as you can see, it was a point. Oil and gas as a portion of the energy segment was down a little over 20%, which is pretty much consistent with what we expected throughout the year. The biggest challenge in there used to be our diesel engine shutoff valve business. This year, it'll shift over really to our compressor control business, and they're moving quickly to try to address everything they can do from shortfall in projects that we'll see throughout the year. 
Very nimble execution. We haven't really talked to the market about any restructuring we've done, which has been pretty considerable. I will do a little bit more in the second quarter, but we're really not even asking for an adjustment on our restructuring investments because the payback is pretty quick. 
Zetec in the quarter did extremely well. It was up high single digits. There's a lot of activity around the power generation side of nuclear, and Zetec is best-in-class in this area and is going to enjoy some continuing tailwinds for the next couple of years. 
And then just as we move to thinking about the remainder of the year, Q2 through Q4, I'll just remind you that with the pullback in oil and gas, about half of the energy systems business is actually industrial measurement technologies. We expect high single-digit organic decline in the rest of the year, but that's just because of the oil and gas. And then we think we'll get this modest growth in the other half of the sector, and we think margins will improve throughout the year sequentially. And energy, as you can see now, is down to only 9% of the company's EBITDA. 
Next slide. If you look at Industrial Technology, the same situation with the oil and gas. Organic as a segment was down 5%. However, if you exclude oil and gas, industrial was up organically 3% in the quarter. So the upstream activity, which in here is really Roper Pump and a little bit of adjacency there, that upstream is about 80% of the market. And the total value of that is only about $10 million out of $171 million in the segment, so it's down to less than 5% of revenue. 
Neptune had a really strong quarter. They were up double digits and enjoying very good U.S., which overcame the fact this was the last quarter with the negative Toronto project variance, which was millions of dollars of headwind. This segment EBITDA margins, I think you can all look at 2, which were really 30.1% on industrial. So the performance, despite any of the headwinds that you see, is still very solid. 
In second half of the year, we're looking at kind of low single-digit organic growth for the segment. We don't see any improvement in upstream oil and gas. We think that will actually continue to decline a little bit. But we'll have kind of flat to modest growth in all of the other markets, and then very strong growth at Neptune because as we get into the second quarter, the Toronto project tailwind is essentially behind us. And that was worth quite a bit of -- will be quite a bit of positive variance now in 2, 3 and 4. 
Next slide. If we look at the RF and technology and software business, and we have to throw the software recognition in here because the software business is actually becoming as large -- or larger than the tolling business. So when we look at the segment, you can see organic was down 1%. But actually, organic would have been up, excluding the roll-off of the Puerto Rico exit that we had, which was $10 million just in that quarter. 
We had record margin performance throughout the segment, very strong software and SaaS business growth with terrific margins and cash flow in all of those businesses. 
Aderant, our most recent acquisition, is performing very well. We got several new wins, which are strategic importance that the legal community can be talking about and has already started to discuss and comment on our share gains. 
In the toll and traffic area, as we say, our ITS business was down because of Puerto Rico. Our tech business continued to be strong, very good project execution. 
And I also want to point out that, that OP margin, which was up 170 basis points to 32.2%, again belies the quality of the cash margin. Our EBITDA margins were at 39.2%, up 360 basis points over the first quarter of the year ago. As we look to the second quarter, we expect flat organic growth in Q2 only because we still have one more quarter of the Puerto Rico drag of about $10 million, and that's 3 to 4 points. But in the second half, we'll have a much stronger organic growth because the Puerto Rico comps will be going away. 
We'll get multiple opportunities, we think, in the TransCore projects. We have very exceptional amount of bids in line. We're pretty confident in a lot of those. The timing of when those are able to be announced will be important for us. 
And then RF IDeas, which is doing phenomenally well, will become organic in the fourth quarter, so that will help our organic revenue comparisons. 
The software and SaaS businesses should grow kind of mid- to high single digits, which is a little bit better than we might have expected previously, and they give us strong cash returns. And then Aderant is going to continue to gain share, which will help this segment. 
Next slide. Here, we look at the medical solutions. Medical solutions, boy, it's another EBITDA margin story. You see the operating profit margin at 34.7%, but that's just because of a lot of noncash amortization. Our EBITDA margins are 43.5% in medical. Organic was up 2%. Acquisitions added 13%. But medical's organic as a stand-alone portion of the segment was up 6% organically, while imaging was down 13%. We had double-digit growth in the medical products, which really was driven primarily by Verathon and Northern Digital. The acquisitions that we made in this segment are performing extremely well. If you put them all together, they actually are growing both at double-digit revenue and EBITDA basis. 
We had really exceptional growth at Strata, which is up very dramatically, as more hospitals understand what we're doing and are signing up our SaaS solution on their cost visibility and how they contain and structure their costs. 
We acquired a small business called PCI Medical in the quarter, which will boost Civco's offering in ultrasound, and that business has closed and will add some revenue for us. 
If you look at the balance of the year, you have a high single-digit organic growth in the segment. That comes from continued strength in the medical arena. And then Strata, SoftWriters and Data Innovations become organic in Q2, which will make those comps stand out. We have very strong performance in all of those acquisitions. The IPA business that we announced some time ago has done particularly well from a growth perspective. 
Imaging will continue to improve with kind of substantial gains out of Gatan. Gatan, we're pouring a lot of money into innovation at Gatan to focus on cryo-EM markets. These involve significant R&D investments but with really exciting out-year opportunities. Some of you have read about the discovery of the Zika virus and how that was done, and our products were absolutely crucial to the discovery technologies that have been announced recently. 
We have positive contributions from our CliniSys acquisition. Although CliniSys comes in initially at lower margins than the rest of our business, but we'll continue to improve those as we work with them. 
Sunquest investments in genetics continues. We acquired on the -- just a day after the quarter so we didn't include it in here GeneInsight, which is a technology and business that was really built by Partners Health that we've been doing in concert with and will have long-term implications in the out-years here at medical. 
Also, I will just say that when you look at medical in this pie chart down here, it's 43% of the company's total EBITDA. And to put that in perspective, you can see energy the smallest piece of that pie, and industrial is the next smallest. Those 2 together are only 24% of our EBITDA, and medical is 43% and RF is 33%. So you can see what the future looks like. 
Next slide. So here, we'll get into the guidance of the company for the balance of the year. 
Next slide. So the guidance update. We're going to continue our current guidance, as we articulated at the beginning of the year. So we said the full year would be between $6.85 and $7.15 with the midpoint at $7, and then operating cash flow will be about $1 billion. And our tax rate guidance is the same as it was at the beginning of the year. And really everything else, we see the same sort of revenue opportunities. There's one thing we'd say about the second quarter, where we established the guidance at $1.56 to $1.61. We had an extraordinarily low tax rate in the second quarter last year. I think some people were maybe not looking at carefully. Tax rate was only 25%. We would expect the tax rate in the second quarter to be 30% to 30.5%. 
Another piece of good news when we look at FY, really comfortable with the second half of the year, is that we're not really seeing any industrial contagion at all in those portions of either industrial or the energy businesses that are not oil and gas. And certainly, at the beginning of the year, that was something that many people were worried about. And the high end of our range will really just be dependent on adoption rates and project timing and seasonal activity. So we feel quite good about reinforcing the full year guidance. 
Next slide. If we look at the summary of 2016, it -- pretty simple series of things here, right? Revenue is up 4.4%. Medical and software and Neptune were able to offset all of the declines in oil and gas. Our orders reached record level and got over a $1 billion backlog. Our gross margin, which would let you know how customers continue to feel about us and the products and services we provide, were up 210 basis points. And as we said, each of the 4 segments increased their gross margin. We're investing at the fastest rate in our history in R&D. Our EBITA margin, you can see, is 32.9%. Not all EBITDA is the same. We're always sometimes a little frustrated. People tell us about somebody's EBITDA margins. But it's really mostly D, and then the CapEx sucks it away. In our world, the leakage between EBITDA at 34% and EBITA, 32.9%, is only 110 basis points. 
EBITDA, as we said, was up 4% to 3.07%. Acquisitions, performing very well. We really can't say enough about how well the acquired leadership teams are performing and how well they've embraced the Roper governance process. Every single one of these acquisitions is outperforming our expectation. And we have a very attractive pipeline. We'd expect -- as said earlier, we expect to deploy over $1 billion in the year, and it could easily be more than that. 
So a great quarter, on track for record 2016. And with that, we'll open it up for questions.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our first question from Scott Davis with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our first question from Scott Davis with Barclays.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just trying to get a sense. I don't think I've ever asked this question before, and you may not have the answer off the top of your hand. But you say 2015 acquisitions are performing very well. And clearly, that looks to be the case. But can you quantify
componenttext: Just trying to get a sense. I don't think I've ever asked this question before, and you may not have the answer off the top of your hand. But you say 2015 acquisitions are performing very well. And clearly, that looks to be the case. But can you quantify that? Is there kind of a cash return on capital on those deals that you could quote for kind of first 12 months out or expected for 2016 or something that we could hang a hat on?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you've been around us a lot to know that I'm not a fan of return on invested capital, where people look at stuff and don't add back accumulated depreciation and don't really realize how much future draw on cash their CapEx will be. So in our
componenttext: Well, I think you've been around us a lot to know that I'm not a fan of return on invested capital, where people look at stuff and don't add back accumulated depreciation and don't really realize how much future draw on cash their CapEx will be. So in our world, we look at the cash return on investment. So in that case, if you look at the net earnings of the business and then you add back the noncash charges and you divide it by the gross investment, which is the physical plant and equipment plus accumulated depreciation plus net working capital, all of those acquisitions are well above 100% cash returns. Many of them are in the several 100% cash return basis. And some of them get paid in advance for what they do, so they have a negative cash return, which is even more powerful. So they're all doing very well. I think as a general rule anymore, you can assume that our acquisitions are going to come in and they're going to be substantially above the 34% EBITDA margin that the overall enterprise has and that they're going to have higher gross margins than the enterprise and they're going to have higher cash returns than the enterprise.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And as far as -- I mean, you put a lot of capital to work last year. I think it was somewhere in the neighborhood of $1.8 billion, $1.85 billion. Would you anticipate -- I mean, you say over $1 billion in 2016. But you also said you hav
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And as far as -- I mean, you put a lot of capital to work last year. I think it was somewhere in the neighborhood of $1.8 billion, $1.85 billion. Would you anticipate -- I mean, you say over $1 billion in 2016. But you also said you have $1.8 billion or so of firepower. Would you anticipate something closer to $1 billion or closer to the $1.8 billion that you have in the hopper? Is it just as a potential or is it just too early to say?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we don't sort of budget like let's deploy $1 billion. So just think about what -- when we think about it, it's very simple, is we're going to deploy our cash flow, we're going to lever this 3x or more that to the acquired EBITDA. So it
componenttext: Well, I think that we don't sort of budget like let's deploy $1 billion. So just think about what -- when we think about it, it's very simple, is we're going to deploy our cash flow, we're going to lever this 3x or more that to the acquired EBITDA. So it gives us usually somewhere between 1.35 and 1.5x our -- the powder of whatever our cash flow is. So we have $1 billion in operating cash flow. We've had some dividends or whatever, and we multiply that for the acquisitions, it'd be very easy for us to deploy $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion all the time. So that's why we say we'll deploy $8 billion over the next 4 or 5 years. And as we said, we deployed $2 billion in the last 15 months. We could easily deploy $2 billion in the next 15 months. So it's not like a budgetary thing, Scott. I mean, we're looking at things now that are over $2 billion, and we're looking at things that are in the mid- to hundreds of millions. And which ones we do and when they close is never thought of as a budget kind of thing. But our balance sheet capacity and our debt ratios give us as much or more opportunity to invest as we've ever had.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Deane Dray with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Deane Dray with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just given all the anxiety we had last quarter regarding oil, it's interesting, and some relief this -- the comments that you're expecting to see margins improve sequentially in energy this year. So maybe comment on the visibility, the backlog. And I know
componenttext: Just given all the anxiety we had last quarter regarding oil, it's interesting, and some relief this -- the comments that you're expecting to see margins improve sequentially in energy this year. So maybe comment on the visibility, the backlog. And I know you didn't call it out. You mentioned you did restructuring this quarter, but could you size for us how much restructuring was done and what that payback is?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we did a little bit towards the end of last year in anticipation of the difficulty. We did more in the first quarter. We'll do a couple million dollars here probably in the second quarter. Some of that -- you make the announcement. It takes a long t
componenttext: Well, we did a little bit towards the end of last year in anticipation of the difficulty. We did more in the first quarter. We'll do a couple million dollars here probably in the second quarter. Some of that -- you make the announcement. It takes a long time if people are in Europe. But we'll continue to pull back a little bit on the sort of baseline SG&A. But the businesses are really small. I think if you add them all up, we had about $65 million of oil and gas revenue in energy and about $10 million in industrial, right? So they really don't huge cost basis. They're very high-margin businesses. If you look at them with sort of 30% pretax numbers or higher, there's just not a lot of cost inside that to take out. We don't have big back [ph] reason we have to worry about with absorption issues and what have you. So another couple million, I think, and we feel like we're where we could be.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on organic guidance, I know you had a lot of moving parts in the second quarter, especially. But what are you expecting for organic second quarter? And how about for the year versus the previous guidance of 2% to 4%?
componenttext: And then on organic guidance, I know you had a lot of moving parts in the second quarter, especially. But what are you expecting for organic second quarter? And how about for the year versus the previous guidance of 2% to 4%?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let John celebrating his 40th quarter give you his view.
componenttext: I'll let John celebrating his 40th quarter give you his view.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, Deane, we're still in the same spot as we were when we initiated guidance with respect to the full year kind of in the 2% to 4% organic. That does imply and in fact, it's a part of our expectation that the second half will be in the mid-single-digit
componenttext: Look, Deane, we're still in the same spot as we were when we initiated guidance with respect to the full year kind of in the 2% to 4% organic. That does imply and in fact, it's a part of our expectation that the second half will be in the mid-single-digit organic growth. Second quarter will be about flat.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just one last quick question on -- corporate expense came in a little bit lighter than what we were looking for. Any unusual items or timing within corporate?
componenttext: Got it. And then just one last quick question on -- corporate expense came in a little bit lighter than what we were looking for. Any unusual items or timing within corporate?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're not. In fact, it was about what we had expected. It encompasses both some deal expenses as well as the equity compensation for the company is all recorded at the corporate G&A line. And the fact that stock price is up nicely from where it was la
componenttext: No, we're not. In fact, it was about what we had expected. It encompasses both some deal expenses as well as the equity compensation for the company is all recorded at the corporate G&A line. And the fact that stock price is up nicely from where it was last year, that's reflected in that number also.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I should emphasize that, that was -- it came in higher than what we were looking for, so I just want...
componenttext: Got it. I should emphasize that, that was -- it came in higher than what we were looking for, so I just want...
