headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Roper Technologies Second Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call will now begin. I will now turn the call over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer.
componenttext: The Roper Technologies Second Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call will now begin. I will now turn the call over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our second quarter financial results. Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our results. The press release also includes replay information for today's cal
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our second quarter financial results. 
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also on our website at ropertech.com. 
Now if you please turn to Slide 2. We'll begin with ours safe harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will make forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties as described on this page, and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information. 
Next slide. Today, we will be discussing our results for the quarter, primarily on an adjusted non-GAAP basis. A full reconciliation between GAAP and adjusted measures is in our press release this morning and also as a part of this presentation on our website. 
For the second quarter, the difference between our GAAP results and adjusted results consist of 2 items: First, a $2.5 million purchase accounting adjustment to acquire deferred revenue for software acquisitions that we've made. This represents revenue that those companies would have recognized if not for our acquisition; second, a small inventory step up expense related acquisition of RF IDeas last year in fourth quarter.
Now if you please turn to Slide 4, I'll turn over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President, Chief Executive Officer. After his remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. We'll take a quick look at sort of summary, an enterprise financial results here in the quarter and then look at individual performance of the segments and the outlook for each segments and then turn to the guid
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. 
We'll take a quick look at sort of summary, an enterprise financial results here in the quarter and then look at individual performance of the segments and the outlook for each segments and then turn to the guidance for the remainder of the year and go to Q&A. 
So next slide is simply the introduction to the Q2 enterprise results. Next slide is the explanation of so. 
Orders were actually up to a record $956 million. They were up 9% in the quarter and our book to bill for the enterprise was 1.02. 
Revenue was up 5% to $934 million versus last year's first quarter. Organic revenue was down 2%. We had the divestiture that's still in our numbers through the third quarter, the ABEL divestiture, which pulled 1% away and acquisition were up 80%. 
We had really terrific growth in Medical and in software, in water, we'll talk more about that within those respective segments. 
But the oil and gas declines were actually worse than we expected. We went into the year thinking that we'd be down may be in the high teens to 20%. In the quarter, we were down 25%. But in the upstream areas, we were down dramatically more, 44%, 51%, 52% numbers that really were amazing for us. Those are, of course, all businesses, so they all are directly EPS-type businesses because they don't have much in the way of noncash amortization. 
The toll and traffic project delay was also a little bit of a disappointment as Saudi is rolling out their program slowly. We're on track with everything we do, but their rate of initiation of new zones has been slow. 
Our gross margin was another record, up 90 basis points to 61% and EBITDA was up to $314 million, 33.6% of revenue. 
Our DEPS number at $1.56 was disappointing from our perspective because it did hit the low end of the range but in the quarter where we had record orders of record sales, record backlog and record EBITDA and operating profit, we just came up a little light on the revenue side from the oil and gas and project delays, each of which probably cost us $6 million to $7 million of revenue, and that's why we were $1.56 at the low range instead of being up at the higher end up $1.61. 
Our operating cash flow was $170 million, which is strong in Q2. Year-to-date, our operating cash flow has been $414 million, which is 23% of revenue, and that's a particularly pleasing number when you're going through the sort of oil and gas decline that you could still maintain these kind of ratios. 
Our recent acquisitions are performing well. We have an extremely strong pipeline, which is very active. We'll talk about it a little bit. 
So it was a solid quarter, but we did have to adjust our outlook for the economic realities we see in the second half of the year, and we'll talk about that when we get to guidance. 
Next slide. Here, we're looking at Q2 income statement. As you can see, orders up 9%; book to bill, 1.02; revenue, up 5%; gross profit was up 6%; gross margin, up 90 basis points. The operating income ratio is 27.4% versus last year's 28.5%, but as you can see, amortization increased by $10 million and our EBITDA performance, if we were reporting that way, would look better in terms of continued sustained upward trends in our ratios. 
The earnings before tax number was down 2% and the tax rate was a relatively big headwind in the quarter, although the tax rate is really sort of appropriate for us at 29.8%. 
Last year, we had extremely unusual event in the Q2 numbers, which was $15.9 million of a good guide that came from a long-term settlement of a tax position, and that really, that $1.70, if you adjust it, for the $0.16 of that onetime benefit would have been $1.54 and this year, we're at $1.56. 
Next slide. If we look here at the revenue bridge, I think most people find this to be quite surprising. The underlying core nature of the business is continuing to grow at double digits. 
Here, you can see, if we look at last year's second quarter, we printed $892 million. That included the $10 million Puerto Rico situation that we were trying to get out of because of all the reasons everybody knows. We were successful, but it's still in the number in the second quarter at $10 million. Now we have the divestiture of the Eastern German pump company for $6 million and then the oil and gas decrement in the second quarter alone was $33 million. 
So those things were at $49 million headwind. If we look at the base entity, 43, you'll see we added $91 million to that number, so while the total revenue is up 5%, the revenue, excluding the oil and gas and these things that are anniversary-ing was up 11%. It's really almost identical to what happened in the first quarter where if you exclude oil and gas in Puerto Rico and divestiture, we were also up 11%. 
The good news is that for the balance of the year, we think the second half will be similar, where we got more than 10%, excluding oil and gas but will have a better organic growth so there'll be a little less in the acquisition dollars and more in the organic growth dollars where at least until we do another acquisition. 
So actually we felt the growth is pretty solid despite the headwinds. 
Next slide. Here, you can see that we continue with the governance process we have to make remarkable progress in our asset-light business model. 2 years ago, our inventory was at 6% of revenue and at the end of June, this year, it's down to 5.1% so a 90 basis point improvement. Receivables actually declined from 17.7% to 16.9%, so we got faster receivables and payables and [indiscernible] went up as we like, from 17.4% to 18.9%. 
So we literally cut our working capital as a function of annualized sales in half in the last 2 years from 6.2% to 3.1%. And that really speaks to the quality of the work that all of our independent operating people do at executing our strategy. 
Next slide. On cash flow performance, again, extremely good cash flow performance. Year-to-date, it's $414 million, which is 23% of revenue. Our free cash flow was 22% of revenue and our operating cash flow conversion was 132%. 
And note on this slide, you'll see in 2 years ago, our year-to-date cash flow had been $353 million, and last year, we printed $433 million. But $20 million of that was a onetime payment by Puerto Rico as we got out of that situation with Puerto Rico. So it's real money, but it wasn't onetime event. 
So if you take the $20 million, you're looking at $413 million [ph] and this year is $414 million. Our cash performance will be even stronger in the second half. But still conversion is great. 
Next slide. From a balance sheet perspective, we continue to be a very well positioned. You can see that they got completely undrawn revolver of $1.850 billion at the moment, up from $1.185 billion last year. So if you look at the cash on undrawn revolver, you're getting about $2.5 billion. Our trailing 12 months EBITDA is $1.267 billion, so our net debt number to EBITDA is running about $1.9 billion -- or 1.9x, and that's after in that 12-month period, we've invested $1.450 billion.  So after -- well $1.45 billion, we still have a 1.9x debt-to-EBITDA number so ample liquidity. We've got a very active pipeline and really, most of the newer acquisitions that we're involved with now in late stages are application software companies, and it's likely we'll be doing something soon. 
Next slide. Here, we'll look at the individual detail and the outlook for each one of the segments. 
Next slide. All 4 segments continue to perform remarkably well. When you look at the kind of all up in the oil and gas that affects the energy business and to a lesser degree, the Industrial Technology because Roper Pumps is sitting there. 
Here these 2 are clipping along with energy at 26%, EBITDA to revenue and actually sequentially up for the first quarter. And Industrial Technology at 31%. So those remain remarkable performance numbers. 
Our software business at 38%, Medical at 43%. As you can see in te4h enterprise as a whole, running at 37% without the corporate expense. 
Next slide. So we'll take the largest segment first, which is Medical. Here you can see that revenue was up 12%, 19 -- 8 points of acquisition and 4 points overall organic revenue, although Imaging pulled that down by 1 point. So medical organic in the quarter was 5%, which is the 10th consecutive quarter that our medical organic revenue has been mid-single digits or better. We certainly don't see that slowing. 
Growth was really led by the adoption of new products in 3 of our medical product companies and software businesses as well. We had strong adoption of our ultimate site Healthware Solution businesses where as SHP and SoftWriters were growing at a very high rate and our internal software within MHA did well as well. 
Our new product launches at Sunquest, which should be very important for 2017 and hopefully, important yet as the year winds down, are launched and on schedule. We've got the sales pipeline, which is growing, growing really rapidly, and we had a couple of large people that we're talking to, but we would expect to begin to see that affect the second half results favorably, which we'll see below. 
In the second half, we think that the organic growth in Medical is going to be in the sort of 6% to 9% range. The product growth that we have in the core products are going to continue. We think that trend, the alternate site growth strength and tear because we are getting some real push out of SHP and SoftWriters becoming organic rather than just acquisitions.  Anyway it actually has same favorable comps that we benefit MHA as the year unfolds. 
The laboratory software orders are going to increase on the adoption many new products and while they're literally over 15 different things that are being launched, there are 4 core large launches around analytics and diagnostic communities and integrated pathologies and clinical content that we think will drive the future of Sunquest. 
Our Imaging businesses are going to benefit in the second half as the cryo-EM technology emergence is getting better understood by people and sort of our phones are ringing off the hook. They have a strong backlog going into the second half and their product releases are on schedule. 
Importantly, and here when you look at the operating profit margin, you see 33.7%, which is down from the prior year. A couple of reasons for that, the newer acquisitions have a lot of amortization. In fact, the second quarter number at 33.7% for OP when you add back the noncash amortization at 7.9%, you wind up at 41.6% for the -- every dollar of revenue contributing. 
And an on EBITDA basis, it's nearly 43%. So good mix between Medical products and software and service. And then Imaging should do better in the second half. 
Next slide. In the RF segment, which is really now increasingly split between RF and Software, you can see revenue was up 14%, acquisitions were up 18%, organic was down 4%. But the organic revenue on our software and SaaS business segment was up 9%. 
Our toll and traffic had very strong orders but our revenue declined because of the Puerto Rico contract, which finally anniversary-ed in the second quarter, so that's a $10 million headwind that goes away. And then the Riyadh project is moving much more slowly. It could easily be $20 million less than what we were told earlier in the year, which is part of the reason for our guide down on the earnings profile. It's still going to continue to happen, the contribution margin we're getting as it rolls out is fine. It's just it's moving more slowly, and it's not the only thing going into Saudi Arabia these days, it's moving very slowly. 
We had very strong segment book to bill here at 1.09. Orders were up 26% with organic orders being up 9. Again, lots of amortization in this segment so you're see an OP margin of 31.5%, which is up 20 basis points, but when you add back the amortization, which is 5.8% of revenue in the segment, and you see the EBITDA number, it's 37.3, the EBITDA number is 38.1, up 190 basis points from the second quarter of last year. 
We see at bottom here in terms of forecasting revenue for the balance of the year earnings. The segment organic revenue, we think would be up 5% to 7%. Toll and traffic will improve in the second half. We've gotten strong orders in Q2. The execution of those should be pretty favorable, and we have a big pipeline of opportunity. What has caused us to slow down the guidance for the balance of the year and is that decision-making process around that has been slower than normal. And whether that's related to an election situation with people wondering about kind of ensuring their commitments is something that's not clear. 
Our software and SaaS businesses continue to grow at high single digits with incredible cash returns that turns other investments and acquisitions. 
And then RFID business and our On Center acquisitions from last year will go to organic in the fourth quarter, which is why you'll see this greater mix of organic in the second half of the year and less on acquisitions than you did in the first 2 quarters. 
Next slide. On the Industrial Technology segment. Here, you can see that orders declined -- well actually orders were up 3%,but the organic growth declined by 1%. The divestiture was 3%. 
The organic, if we exclude oil and gas and industrial, was up 4%. The problem with this segment was simply that the upstream was worse than expected for Roper Pump, and we had expected a big down, but it was down 44%. A little bigger than we had anticipated. The good news is it does appear that, that's the bottom of the situation. And of course, Roper Pump impact for the segment is dramatically be escalated as the revenue has dropped so much over the last 2 years. 
Neptune on the other hand is doing extremely well. They had double-digit growth in the second quarter on both orders and revenue. They continue to gain share in the marketplace despite people other people that are trying to sale their businesses. Neptune will continue to have record performance. 
The material analysis portion of the business, sort of test and measurement had record orders in the second quarter, which is very encouraging because revenue had been down sort of high single digits, so that bodes well for the second half. 
If you look at second half, we think that the overall organic revenue in the business will be flat because we don't see any improvement in the upstream markets, although there is a declining impact in the segment as the underlying base business of Roper Pump is getting very strong. 
Neptune and instrumentation will be able to offset any of the declines we have in oil and gas and finally, in the fourth quarter, the divestiture will anniversary and go away. 
Next slide. Here, we look at the Energy Systems & Controls segment. You can see that revenue there was down 15%, and it's really a tale of 2 different businesses, the Test and Measurement business, which was okay. And then the Oil and Gas businesses, which were off. So oil and gas was down 25% in the segment, and that really doesn't quite tell the story either because our Petroleum Analyzer business, if you exclude its small portion of the upstream [indiscernible] was really flat, which actually improved profit contribution. But Compressor Controls, which is a high margin business was down by more than a third of revenue and delevered at a quite high rate. But we do feel that from here, it gets no longer as negative on the comparison basis as we sort of see some of course softness throughout the year. 
We did have sequential margin improvement. You can see the OP margin came in at 22.5% and the segment had some amortization, which brought it to 25.8% and EBITDA a little bit higher. The OP margin in the first quarter was 20.4, so we picked up 210 basis points of sequential margin improvement. 
In the second half of the year, we think that the organic revenue and energy is likely to be down between 7% and 10%, which is really driven by the continued lack of improvement in the oil and gas businesses. 
We do have an easier comp in the fourth quarter in these Oil and Gas businesses. They are normal so there may be some optimism there and fourth quarter seasonal increase, we assume will be similar to what it was last year, which was not very good and that could be a positive surprise. 
The industrial Test and Measurement businesses will continue to improve. They're doing pretty well now certainly in the low to mid-single digits growth mode. And the margins there are going to continue to improve, and so that's quite good.  And the orders in the to bill of the segment is about 1, so this seems to be pretty well under control. 
When we get to the guidance here -- next slide. The outlook for the year, we took the full year down to $6.57 to $6.71, which gives you a midpoint, I guess, of $6.64, which is certainly lower than what we had before. It really is being driven by the more severe downturn in oil and gas. We thought maybe we'd be down in a neighborhood of $75 million in oil and gas for the year, but we're going to be down like $100 million. So that's a $25 million revenue hit. And then the project pushout and tolling are another sort of $20 million, $25 million. And then there's currency that we didn't have, Brexit and other factors in currency is another $10 million, so there's about $60 million revenue hit there, and you can assume that comes in at close to 50% on a contribution basis. 
And then the rest is really just recognition of a somewhat lower global growth environment, so we think that takes 1 point or maybe 2 points off of the organic growth versus what we expected when we initiated guidance at the beginning of the year. 
We get a very thorough bottoms-up review for guidance this time with all of our senior operating people involved and really kind of rebuilding what everybody had to assure ourselves that we were very comfortable with whatever the guidance we're going to put in place. We really could have some things that will become favorable for us. The fact that if we brought it down in the oil and gas, severity, project delays and tolling, global growth challenges, maybe there's a little optimism there, but we're not ready to embed any of that in our guidance. 
In terms of an upside, certainly the toll projects could accelerate. I think that people had a clearer view of what's going to happen with the election. They might have a better idea about whether they think they're going to be personally benefited or not economically from policy. 
The product launches that we have pretty ramps faster than we have in our guidance, that would be nice, but you never know. And then our capital deployment, which we certainly expect to have more of augment growth as the year unfolds, but it's not in our guidance numbers. 
If we look at kind of forward revenue and EBITDA leverage. EBITDA leverage is running a little better than 1/3 of new revenue. So even with the deleverage we got from oil and gas, we're still having overall net positive EBITDA leverage on new revenue and if we what else we got sort of organic growth is 2% to 4% with revenue growth at 7% to 9% for the second half. If we did a bridge like we did at the beginning of the presentation, you'd see it would show similar results with revenue being up by 10% or more, excluding oil and gas. 
Our second half tax rate is probably around 30% and then in third quarter, we're looking at $1.59 to $1.63. 
Next slide. Here, if we look at the summary of what happened in the quarter, you can see for us it was normally we'll talk about the fact that we had record orders and backlog record sales and operating profit and EBITDA, which is good, the margins are good, but we hit the lower end the guidance, so we don't feel like meeting this kind of record results when we were a little bit disappointed on the actual EPS number. 
Orders, as we said, were all-time record and up 9% with a backlog of $1.14 billion, a book to bill, well above 1, so we're well positioned to continue to have a stronger second half. 
We get rid of the $10 million a quarter drag from Puerto Rico beginning now here in the third quarter, and we get rid of the drag on the divestiture of ABEL in the fourth quarter, so a little bit of a drag in Q3. 
Revenue being up 5%, we were able to do that because we had sort of high single digits, low double-digit growth between medical, software and water, which allowed us to survive this greater than 40% reduction in our upstream oil and gas businesses. Gross margin at 61%, we feel very good about that. EBITDA margin is fine, like we're going to improve in the second half a little bit. 
Operating cash flow, the same thing, 132% conversion and $414 million, it'll to be stronger as always is in the second half, so we're quite comfortable with where we are on the operating cash flow. 
Back in '14, our Oil and Gas business was a little above $500 million and 14% of the company. In 2015, that had dropped to around $400 million and about 11.5% of the company. And today, we think it will finish the year at around $300 million, which will be less than our 8% of the company and the upstream portion is going to be less 50% of the company with midstream being around 6. So the orders were behind us for this kind of change and we're looking forward to that. 
We got a very active pipeline. We opened on quite a few deals. We said at the beginning of the year, we expect to deploy $1 billion, but $275 million to work thus far. It's not going to be difficult to find our way to deploying that well of activity. 
We still have a great opportunity to continue to compound results. It's really continues to drive our strategy, so we've got our underlying core businesses doing relatively well in a growth perspective, adjusted the oil and gas and unique situation with Puerto Rico, which was a win for us even though it shows up negatively in the first half revenue. It keeps us all of our strategies alive, and we're very comfortable with our ability to compound results from here out. 
So with that, we'll open it up to questions.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Deane Dray with RBC capital markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Deane Dray with RBC capital markets.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian or John, I was hoping you could start with bridging the guidance for third quarter and fourth quarter. It just looks like the guidance cut here this morning is weighing higher obviously on the third quarter, down 12% versus consensus. But you not as
componenttext: Brian or John, I was hoping you could start with bridging the guidance for third quarter and fourth quarter. It just looks like the guidance cut here this morning is weighing higher obviously on the third quarter, down 12% versus consensus. But you not as appear in the the fourth quarter. But maybe if there some seasonality, is it the comps getting easier, better visibility on these product launches? But just some color there on the difference here, assumptions in third and fourth quarter.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Deane, so you did touch on it. So one of the things that we're expecting for this year is historically, strong from a seasonality perspective but stronger than what we saw last year. And that's not just on the energy businesses, but also at some of t
componenttext: Yes, Deane, so you did touch on it. So one of the things that we're expecting for this year is historically, strong from a seasonality perspective but stronger than what we saw last year. And that's not just on the energy businesses, but also at some of the other industrial businesses that have some more seasonal activity as customers flush out some of their budget. So we do expect that for the fourth quarter, and that's why you see slightly higher in the fourth quarter than the third quarter as we look forward to this. My answer must have left everyone dumbfounded. Are we live on the call here?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you are still alive. We will now hear from Robert McCarthy from Stifel, Nicolaus and Company.
componenttext: Yes, you are still alive. We will now hear from Robert McCarthy from Stifel, Nicolaus and Company.

componenttext: So we had lot chances responsible for the medical and software businesses, there is an opportunity to explain, the pipeline is growing candidly more rapidly than it could have [indiscernible]. And we can tell you little bit about what these new launches at Sunquest are designed to do. So Neil, with that, fire away.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. The second half has slide across-the-board, break it down by product and software. From the product side, there's new project at Verathon that continue to gain traction. On the software side, a number of this, we talked about the 4 number, t
componenttext: Good morning. The second half has slide across-the-board, break it down by product and software. From the product side, there's new project at Verathon that continue to gain traction. On the software side, a number of this, we talked about the 4 number, the faster-growing software businesses, our [indiscernible], Strata innovations, SoftWriters, SHP. And then with the second half from the MHA, we do see likely where the earnings comes and then the market conditions new comps would give us an opportunity to do better in the second half than the first half.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

So I'll let you talk about the launch of the new -- you've got 4 major offerings and then you got mid-teens in terms of enhancements and upgrades that match -- putting in place that we're already starting to solicit revenue. So you might explain of what these things do.p.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So well at Sunquest, we're excited about Sunquest. The reality at Sunquest is we've worked very hard for the last 18 months on a series of new products. We talked about those number of new products are being grandeur, material upgrades or enhancement or i
componenttext: So well at Sunquest, we're excited about Sunquest. The reality at Sunquest is we've worked very hard for the last 18 months on a series of new products. We talked about those number of new products are being grandeur, material upgrades or enhancement or increases being in the high teens. We're on track for all of that. We just come off a great user conference at Sunquest where the customers were excited about the road map, and all that was happening. It's in a pretty meaningful increase in the pipeline the sales pipeline, the sales funnel activity that you expect to see coming behind a large number of new products. We'd like to see that pipeline convert in the second half. We expect it to convert in the second half so we'll see bookings momentums, and that will give us some momentum heading into 2017 for Sunquest that we've talked about in the past.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And switching gears to M&A capital redeployment. I think the messaging may be up until this cost, but it will be more muted kind of second quarter given where public valuations are for a lot of companies, given where the cost of funds is. Maybe you could
componenttext: And switching gears to M&A capital redeployment. I think the messaging may be up until this cost, but it will be more muted kind of second quarter given where public valuations are for a lot of companies, given where the cost of funds is. Maybe you could just talk about -- do you think it's a difficult environment to transact deals just given political uncertainty, attentively arising stock market with improving valuations and public fundamentals kind of bleeding in the private fundamentals and then kind of perhaps some of your companies seeking about the alternative route for initial public offerings. Could you just talk about how you look at this environment, and how do you think Roper is going to be able to transact in this environment and what kind of cadence you guys can transact in?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think for us it's kind of a perfect environment, although you're right about the pricing of assets and expectation of sellers. It's a pretty high, but fortunately for us, we do not find public companies and paying a premium for it. So we're buying
componenttext: Well, I think for us it's kind of a perfect environment, although you're right about the pricing of assets and expectation of sellers. It's a pretty high, but fortunately for us, we do not find public companies and paying a premium for it. So we're buying private companies than if they were public the do trade and public marketplace, which gives us always some beneficial arbitrage. There are as many things available in the acquisition market as I've ever seen. We have looked at billions of dollars of transactions this year, and we're directly engaged with a couple now that have a higher likelihood of closing. I think that the ones that we were looking at earlier of the year because of the quality of the business. A lot of the people that are running these private companies aren't interested in becoming public. They would much rather join our firm at the public equity and our firm that -- and not have the quarterly calls and all of the things that you have to do with investors and banks. So we remain a very attractive home for people and I think that acquisitions we made in the last couple of years give us a wider variety of things that we can look at. Application software has a huge number of potential verticals and there are a lot of niches within that the largest people, that are roll up people are going to be interested in. So it's still a very favorable hunting ground for us. Now the challenge, I think, for the all the industry guys in buying things is they tend to not buy things that are us higher quality is what we're buying. And if you're in a marketplace where you're looking for synergies that are going to be driven by overhead absorption or business consolidation or administrative synergies or something, those businesses are trading at a disproportionately high price than the way they normally would because the interest rates are so low. The highest quality businesses, oddly enough, trade at a much deeper discount to public comps. People will look at Roper and say, oh my gosh, look, they pay 12x for something. Well, if you look at the public company comp, it was trading at 25 or 26x. So I think that people are focused on product-oriented, more asset-intensive businesses that are trading at 12 or 13x because of very low interest rates and people are buying them for 12 or 13 or 14. We're not in that space. We're in a space where buying stuff at 12 or 13 or 14 that if we were public we'll trade at a higher number because of our willingness and experience in how to effectuate those companies joining our public family.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I appreciate the opportunity. Let me give you 30 seconds on the importance of what Sunquest does for our customers. So Sunquest customers are the largest, most complicated laboratories in the United States. These are laboratories that do milli
componenttext: Sure. Well, I appreciate the opportunity. Let me give you 30 seconds on the importance of what Sunquest does for our customers. So Sunquest customers are the largest, most complicated laboratories in the United States. These are laboratories that do million of tests a year and what our software does is automate from start to finish the laboratory processes, so you get a super high quality results at low cost to operate the lab. So what Sunquest, the new [indiscernible] I n Sunquest is the extend that capability that's been steeped in the [indiscernible] side or the fluid side of the lab and extend to the other parts of the laboratory. So first is a major product that is the integration of the pathologies inside of a hospital. So it integrates the blood and the tissue to the molecular genetic, very important products for us and for our customers as they deliver medicine inside of their institutions. The second one is a completely refreshed view about how do you collect samples at the bedside. It's mobile-enabled, it's integrated into a nurse workflow, important in terms of getting the draws correct at the right location with the right patient and get it into the laboratories as quickly as possible. The third category of new products is helping to hospitals extend their reach into the communities. Importantly, in the changing reimbursement landscape in U.S. health care, health hospitals want the collaboratory samples that are in the community being where the physicians that feed patients into the hospital. They want a blood test that are collected in all laboratories test that are collected in the physicians offices to be routed into the hospital's laboratory, not just to drive volume in laboratory but to give the clinical information. And so we have a series of tools that integrate into the electronic medical records at the physicians offices for ordering and resulting. And then finally, laboratory space has been baked in at any meaningful analytics about how they run the operations, how they benchmark themselves against their peers and improve the operations, so we have a large analytics release that's happening in the second half of this year. Those are 4 net new opportunities. As we talked earlier this a series of meaningful upgrades. We've just released a major upgrades to our core of clinical pathology and our core blood bank. We've seen the opportunities associated with those upgrades, number in the hundreds, and so we're excited about what the team has been able to build their products with respect at Sunquest.

So to comment, this segment has our highest gross margins across the enterprise with gross margins that are north of 70%. Some of our businesses here even have gross margins above that. And so we see incremental growth and the top side, we expect that the fall through. And so that really is what drive the margin improvement as we go throughout the year. And that's true on -- not only the software-type businesses like Neil was just talking about, but also our product businesses and particularly at Gatan, some of our imaging business will have have higher gross margins because of all the technology and all the R&D that we invest there. It does result in higher gross margins. So if the volume increases, we expect the fall through to improve. And that results in a higher margin in the fourth quarter than what we had throughout the first part of the year.

componenttext: Well, as far as the numbers, I'll turn it to Brian on the commentary about the business outlook. If the order growth was both on the toll and traffic side where the book to bill ratio was very strong, 1.14, I believe. But it was also on the softer side. Now a little bit of that is seasonal as our CBORD business, in particular, which serves the college, university market. They have a lot of their renewals and upgrades and security applications that are booked in the second quarter and then delivered or recognized as revenue throughout the year. And so little bit of that is seasonal, but we saw fundamental growth in the software orders as well. But the largest reason for the book to bill being well above 1 is the backlog that's building on the toll and traffic side even though we've seen delays there, we still see fundamental growth happening there on the second half.

I'm just wondering whether any of the 10 market dynamics have kind changed your be about the portfolio and then there's any potential divestitures that you guys are considering.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I'd say the answer is no. When we went into the year thinking that would be down about $100 million in the oil and gas, which comes in a little bit into industrial, mostly into energy -- I'm sorry, we thought we did -- we're down about $75 million. No
componenttext: No, I'd say the answer is no. When we went into the year thinking that would be down about $100 million in the oil and gas, which comes in a little bit into industrial, mostly into energy -- I'm sorry, we thought we did -- we're down about $75 million. Now, we're going to be down $100 million. So that $25 million extra negative situation on revenue is disappointing because it comes in at 50% or frankly, 60% contribution. So it's a big EPS number. It doesn't really diminish our cash performance if I mention all, and those businesses at the moment are just a free shot and goal for 2017 and '18. They're on the books for we did extremely low basis, so the only way if you were going to do something if you want to do either a straight stand or response to stand or you want to do on what somebody about it, it would be safe to say that our phone's been ringing off people who want to do those kinds of things. But we actually think there's substantial upside in those businesses just not this year. And probably not in the first 3 quarters and next year. But if they start cranking just modestly in 2018, we're going to have windfall kind of results, so we prefer to hold onto them, continue to invest. The industrial business was 26% EBITDA in the quarter, I would say and Energy business we used to get 31 in Industrial, 26 on energy. So these are really good businesses. Most of our investors when we talk to that guys, their fear is, gee, if you put those someplace, how could be trusted around them as well as you can and we always say, boy, say well it may be right. So these are great businesses. They're just in situation where if somebody is off, 44% to 52%, it's incredible, but they're still able to perform at the levels they are because there's some nimble. So I don't really see those as necessary sales. We know how to run them, we know how to run them well. If they didn't have this extra $25 million headwind the second half, our guidance reduction would have been so great. And no one could have predict what happened with -- what's going on in Saudi is certainly an interesting time, it affected several of our businesses revenues in the second quarter. So I think the underlying thesis for us is, we've got some cash cow businesses that are at their absolute nadir. They're going to drive a lot of performance over the years and they're great annuity value for our investors.

componenttext: Sure. I mean, the M&A does have an impact here, right? Because we acquired CliniSys, which is an operating is below the segment average. And then the other piece as far as the relative mix between so medical grow so far this year and in fact, for the remainder of the year as well, although not as much in the fourth quarter has been driven more by product, by medical products sales. Still terrific businesses in great margin, but not the highest margin businesses inside the segment, which is really more of the software and services side. So it's more of mix issue, but we see that mix issue actually moderating as we go throughout the year. And to an earlier question, that's why we see some fall through in margin expansion in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: Well, we just don't know. Last year was -- normally, you get basically because people have a lot of MRO left at the end of the year, but we didn't see any benefit of that because people just shut down. This year, all year long, anybody who's in the upstream business would know that people are cannibalizing what nobody is buying anything, rental fleets in distress, but there are increasing number of signals that would say that the cannibalization of all the stack horsepower business out there at some point will turn into new orders and revenue. We just have no idea whether it will be. We do expect a modest improvement in the fourth quarter this year versus last year. And could it be even better? I don't know.

We've seen good success with Sunquest and MHA and tucking in some related businesses at Sunquest, at CliniSys and GeneInsight and Atlas. And I'm curious, do we stay on that path with more of the bolt-ons to Sunquest and MHA? Or is there something in there with some scale that we could pull in?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's a really good question. The answer is yes, and yes. So one of the incredible about Sunquest and MHA is their platform stack. So if they allow us to do these incredibly attractive small acquisitions that we wouldn't do on our own. I mean, things li
componenttext: So it's a really good question. The answer is yes, and yes. So one of the incredible about Sunquest and MHA is their platform stack. So if they allow us to do these incredibly attractive small acquisitions that we wouldn't do on our own. I mean, things like SoftWriters and Strata just really amazing. I mean, these are very high-growth businesses and hopefully, we'll continue like that even though they're on a small base. If you look at the last larger transaction was Aderant. There are a lot of things that was sort of the size of Aderant. And Aderant also offers us an opportunity for some bolt-on acquisitions to kind of grow its platform status. I would hope that the next acquisition we have is more like that, where it's meaningful, it's something that we know how to do, people would be confident that we're already doing those kinds of things. So that is likely what the next thing would be. Now that said, this year, we look at the number of very large transactions. And those are always of interest. We're incredibly conservative and careful around those. But I would be disappointed in the next 2 or 3 years if we didn't do a quite large transaction.

So we have enough internal intellectual capital to handle a large acquisition that would not be in the medical space.
