headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our second quarter financial results.Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss our second quarter financial results.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also on our website at www.ropertech.com.
Now if you please turn to Slide 2. We'll begin with our safe harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will make forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties that are described on this page, and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
Next slide. Today, we will be discussing our results for the quarter, primarily on an adjusted non-GAAP basis. A full reconciliation between GAAP and adjusted measures is in our press release this morning and also as a part of this presentation on our website.
For the second quarter, the difference between our GAAP results and adjusted results consist of 2 items: first, a $2.5 million purchase accounting adjustment to acquire deferred revenue for software acquisitions that we've made. This represents revenue that those companies would have recognized if not for our acquisition; second, a small inventory step-up expense related to the acquisition of RF IDeas last year in the fourth quarter.
Now if you please turn to Slide 4, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody.We'll take a quick look at sort of summary of the enterprise results here in the quarter, and then look at individual performance in this segments and the outlook for each segments, and then turn to the guidance
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody.
We'll take a quick look at sort of summary of the enterprise results here in the quarter, and then look at individual performance in this segments and the outlook for each segments, and then turn to the guidance for the remainder of the year, and go to Q&A.
So next slide is simply the introduction to the Q2 enterprise results. Next slide is the explanation of those.
So orders were actually up to a record $956 million. They were up 9% in the quarter, and our book to bill for the enterprise was 1.02.
Revenue was up 5% to $934 million versus last year's first quarter. Organic revenue was down 2%. We had the divestiture that's still in our numbers through the third quarter, the ABEL divestiture, which pulled 1% away, and acquisition were up 80%.
We had really terrific growth in medical and in software, in water, we'll talk more about that within those respective segments.
But the oil and gas declines were actually worse than we expected. We went into the year thinking that we'd be down may be in the high teens to 20%. In the quarter, we were down 25%. But in the upstream areas, we were down dramatically more, 44%, 51%, 52% numbers that really were amazing for us. Those are, of course, all businesses, so they all are directly EPS-type businesses because they don't have much in the way of noncash amortization.
The toll and traffic project delay was also a little bit of a disappointment as Saudi is rolling out their program slowly. We're on track with everything we do, but their rate of initiation of new zones has been slow.
Our gross margin was another record, up 90 basis points to 61% and EBITDA was up to $314 million, 33.6% of revenue.
Our DEPS number at $1.56 was disappointing from our perspective because it did hit the low end of the range, but in a quarter where we had record orders of record sales, record backlog and record EBITDA and operating profit, we just came up a little light on the revenue side from the oil and gas and project delays, each of which probably cost us $6 million to $7 million of revenue, and that's why we were about $1.56 at the low range instead of being up at the higher end of $1.61.
Our operating cash flow was $170 million, which is strong in Q2. Year-to-date, our operating cash flow has been $414 million, which is 23% of revenue, and that's a particularly pleasing number when you're going through the sort of oil and gas decline that you could still maintain these kind of ratios.
Our recent acquisitions are performing well. We have an extremely strong pipeline, which is very active. We'll talk about it in a little bit.
So it was a solid quarter, but we did have to adjust our outlook for the economic realities we see in the second half of the year, and we'll talk about that when we get to guidance.
Next slide. Here, we're looking at the Q2 income statement. As you can see, orders up 9%; book to bill, 1.02; revenue, up 5%; gross profit was up 6%; gross margin, up 90 basis points. The operating income ratio is 27.4% versus last year's 28.5%, but as you can see, amortization increased by $10 million, and our EBITDA performance, if we were reporting in that way, would look better in terms of continued sustained upward trends in our ratios.
The earnings before tax number was down 2%, and the tax rate was a relatively big headwind in the quarter, although the tax rate is really sort of appropriate for us at 29.8%.
Last year, we had an extremely unusual event in the Q2 numbers, which was $15.9 million of a good guy that came from a long-term settlement of a tax position, and that really, that $1.70, if you adjust it, for the $0.16 of that onetime benefit would have been about $1.54 and this year, we're at $1.56.
Next slide. If we look here at the revenue bridge, I think most people find this to be quite surprising. The underlying core nature of the business is continuing to grow at double digits.
Here, you can see, if we looked at last year's second quarter, we printed $892 million. That included the $10 million Puerto Rico situation that we were trying to get out of because of all the reasons everybody knows. We were successful, but it's still in the number in the second quarter at $10 million. Now we have the divestiture of the Eastern German pump company for $6 million, and then the oil and gas decrement in the second quarter alone was $33 million.
So those things were at $49 million headwind. If we look at the base entity, 43, you'll see we added $91 million to that number, so while the total revenue is up 5%, the revenue, excluding the oil and gas and these things that are anniversarying was up 11%. It's really almost identical to what happened in the first quarter, where if you exclude oil and gas in Puerto Rico and the divestiture, we were also up 11%.
The good news is that for the balance of the year, we think the second half will be similar, where we got more than 10%, excluding oil and gas, but will have a better organic growth, so there'll be a little less in the acquisition dollars and more in the organic growth dollars, where at least until we do another acquisition.
So -- actually, we felt the growth is pretty solid despite the headwinds.
Next slide. Here, you can see that we continue with the governance process. We have to make remarkable progress in our asset-light business model. Two years ago, our inventory was at 6% of revenue, and at the end of June, this year, it's down to 5.1%, so a 90 basis point improvement. Receivables actually declined from 17.7% to 16.9%, so we got faster receivables, and payables and accruals went up, as we like, from 17.4% to 18.9%.
So we literally cut our working capital as a function of annualized sales in half, in the last 2 years, from 6.2% to 3.1%. And that really speaks to the quality of the work that all of our independent operating people do executing our strategy.
Next slide. On cash flow performance, again, extremely good cash flow performance. Year-to-date, it's $414 million, which is 23% of revenue. Our free cash flow was 22% of revenue, and our operating cash flow conversion was 132%.
And note on this slide, you'll see in 2 years ago, our year-to-date cash flow had been $353 million, and last year, we printed $433 million. But $20 million of that was a onetime payment by Puerto Rico as we got out of that situation with Puerto Rico. So it's real money, but it was a onetime event.
So if you take the $20 million, you're looking at $413 (sic) [ 433 ] million and this year's $414 million, our cash performance will be even stronger in the second half. But still conversion is great. 
Next slide. From a balance sheet perspective, we continue to be very well positioned. You can see that we got a completely undrawn revolver of $1.850 billion at the moment, up from $1.185 billion of last year. So if you look at the cash and undrawn revolver, you're getting about $2.5 billion. Our trailing 12 months EBITDA is $1.267 billion, so our net debt number to EBITDA is running about $1.9 billion -- or 1.9x, and that's after in that 12-month period, we've invested $1,450,000,000. So after -- well, $1.45 billion, we still have a 1.9x debt-to-EBITDA number, so ample liquidity. We've got a very active pipeline, and really, most of the -- numerous acquisitions that were involved with now in late stages are application software companies, and it's likely we'll be doing something soon.
Next slide. Here, we'll look at the individual detail and the outlook for each one of the segments.
Next slide. All 4 segments continue to perform remarkably well. When you look at it as a kind of all-up in the oil and gas that affects the energy business and to a lesser degree, the Industrial Technology because Roper Pump is sitting in there.
Here these 2 are clipping along with energy at 26%, EBITDA to revenue and, actually, sequentially up from the first quarter, and Industrial Technology at 31%. So those remain remarkable performance numbers.
Our software business at 38%, medical at 43% as you can see, and the enterprise as a whole running at 37% without the corporate expense.
Next slide. So we'll take the largest segment first, which is medical. Here you can see that revenue was up 12%, that came from 8 points of acquisition and 4 points overall organic revenue, although imaging pulled that down by 1 point. So medical organic in the quarter was 5%, which is the 10th consecutive quarter that our medical organic revenue has been mid-single digits or better. We certainly don't see that slowing.
Growth was really led by the adoption of new products in 3 of our medical product companies and software businesses as well. We had strong adoption of our alternate site healthcare solution businesses where SHP and SoftWriters were growing at a very high rate and our internal software within MHA did well as well.
Our new product launches at Sunquest, which should be very important for 2017, and hopefully, important yet as the year winds down, are launched and on schedule. We've got the sales pipeline, which is growing, growing really rapidly, and we have a couple of large people that we're talking to. But we would expect to begin to see that affect the second half results favorably, which we'll see below.
In the second half, we think that the organic growth in medical is going to be in the sort of 6% to 9% range. The product growth that we have in the core products is going to continue. We think that trend, the alternate site growth strength is here because we are getting some real push out of SHP and SoftWriters becoming organic rather than just acquisitions. Anyway, actually we had some favorable comps that will benefit MHA as the year unfolds.
The laboratory software orders are going to increase on the adoption of many new products. And while they're literally over 15 different things that are being launched, there are 4 core large launches around analytics and diagnostic communities and integrated pathologies and clinical content that we think will drive the future of Sunquest.
Our imaging businesses are going to benefit in the second half as the cryo-EM technology emergence is getting better understood by people and sort of our phones are ringing off the hook. They have a strong backlog going into the second half and their product releases are on schedule.
Importantly -- and here, when you look at the operating profit margin, you see 33.7%, which is down from the prior year. A couple of reasons for that, the newer acquisitions have a lot of amortization. In fact, the second quarter number at 33.7% for OP when you add back the noncash amortization at 7.9%, you wind up at 41.6% for the -- every dollar of revenue contributing, and on an EBITDA basis, it's nearly 43%. So good mix between medical products and software and service, and then imaging should do better in the second half.
Next slide. In the RF segment, which is really now increasingly split between RF and software, you can see revenue was up 14%, acquisitions were up 18%, organic was down 4%. But the organic revenue on our software and SaaS business segment was up 9%.
Our toll and traffic had very strong orders, but our revenue declined because of the Puerto Rico contract, which finally anniversaried in the second quarter, so that's a $10 million headwind that goes away. And then the Riyadh project is moving much more slowly. It could easily be $20 million less than what we were told earlier in the year, which is part of the reason for our guide down on the earnings profile. It's still going to continue to happen, the contribution margin we're getting as it rolls out is fine. It's just that it's moving more slowly, and it's not the only thing going in the Saudi Arabia these days that's moving very slowly.
We had very strong segment book to bill here at 1.09. Orders were up 26% with organic orders being up 9%. Again, lots of amortization in this segment, so you see an OP margin of 31.5%, which is up 20 basis points, but when you add back the amortization, which is 5.8% of revenue in the segment and you see the EBITA number is 37.3%, the EBITDA number is 38.1%, up 190 basis points from the second quarter of last year.
We see there -- at bottom here, in terms of forecasting revenue for the balance of the year earnings, the segment organic revenue, we think will be up 5% to 7%. Toll and traffic will improve in the second half. We've gotten strong orders in Q2. The execution of those should be pretty favorable. And we have a big pipeline of opportunity. What has caused us to slow down the guidance for the balance of the year is that decision-making process around that has been slower than normal, and whether that's related to an election situation with people wondering about -- kind of ensuring their commitments is something that's not clear.
Our software and SaaS businesses continue to grow at high single digits with incredible cash returns that earns other investments and acquisitions.
And then RFID business and our On Center acquisitions from last year will go to organic in the fourth quarter, which is why you'll see this bigger mix of organic in the second half of the year and less on acquisitions than you did in the first 2 quarters. 
Next slide. On the Industrial Technology segment. Here, you can see that orders declined -- well, actually, orders were up 3%, but the organic growth declined by 1%. The divestiture was 3%.
The organic, if we exclude oil and gas and industrial, was up 4%. The problem with this segment was simply that the upstream was worse than expected for Roper Pump, and we had expected a big down, but it was down 44%, so a little bigger than we had anticipated. The good news is it does appear that, that's the bottom of the situation. And of course, Roper Pump's impact on the segment is dramatically de-escalated as their revenue has dropped so much over the last 2 years.
Neptune on the other hand is doing extremely well. They had double-digit growth in the second quarter on both orders and revenue. They continue to gain share in the marketplace despite people reading about other people that are trying to sell their businesses. Neptune will continue to have record performance.
The material analysis portion of the business, sort of test and measurement, had record orders in the second quarter, which is very encouraging because their revenue had been down sort of high single digits, so that bodes well for the second half.
If you look at the second half, we think that the overall organic revenue in the business will be flat because we don't see any improvement in the upstream markets, although there is a declining impact in the segment as the underlying base business of Roper Pump is getting very small.
Neptune, an instrumentation, will be able to offset any of the declines we have in oil and gas and finally, in the fourth quarter, the divestiture will anniversary and go away.
Next slide. Here, we look at the Energy Systems & Controls segment. You can see that revenue there was down 15%, and it's really a tale of 2 different businesses, the test and measurement business, which was okay. And then the oil and gas businesses, which were off. So oil and gas was down 25% in the segment, and that really doesn't quite tell the story either because our petroleum analyzer business, if you exclude its small portion of the upstream it has was really flat, which actually improved profit contribution. But Compressor Controls, which is a high margin business was down by more than 1/3 in revenue and delevered at a quite high rate. We do feel that, from here, it gets no longer as negative on a comparison basis as we sort of see of course some softness throughout the year.
We did have sequential margin improvement. You can see the OP margin came in at 22.5%, and this segment had some amortization, which brought it to 25.8% and EBITDA a little bit higher. The OP margin in the first quarter was 20.4%, so we picked up 210 basis points of sequential margin improvement.
In the second half of the year, we think that the organic revenue and energy is likely to be down between 7% and 10%, which is really driven by the continued lack of improvement in the oil and gas businesses.
We do have an easier comp in the fourth quarter in these oil and gas businesses. They are normal, so there may be some optimism there. And fourth quarter seasonal increase, we assume, will be similar to what it was last year, which was not very good and that could be a positive surprise.
The industrial test and measurement businesses will continue to improve. They're doing pretty well now, certainly in a low to mid-single digits growth mode. And the margins there are going to continue to improve, and so that's quite good. And the orders, book to bill, in the segment is about 1, so this seems to be pretty well under control.
When we get to the guidance here -- next slide. The outlook for the year, we took the full year down to $6.57 to $6.71, which gives you a midpoint, I guess, of $6.64, which is certainly lower than what we had before. It really is being driven by the more severe downturn in oil and gas. We thought maybe we'd be down in a neighborhood of $75 million in oil and gas for the year, but we're going to be down more like $100 million, so that's a $25 million revenue hit. And then the project pushouts and tolling are another sort of $20 million, $25 million. And then there's currency that we didn't have, Brexit and other factors in currency is another $10 million. So there's about $60 million revenue hit there, and you can assume that comes in at close to 50% on a contribution basis.
And then the rest is really just recognition of a somewhat lower global growth environment, so we think that takes 1 point, or maybe 2 points, off of the organic growth versus what we expected when we initiated guidance at the very beginning of the year.
We get a very thorough bottoms-up review for guidance this time with all of our senior operating people involved, and really kind of rebuilding what everybody had to assure ourselves that we were very comfortable with whatever the guidance we're going to put in place. We really could have some things that will become favorable for us. The fact that if we brought it down in the oil and gas, severity, project delays and tolling, global growth challenges, maybe there's a little optimism there, but we're not ready to embed any of that in our guidance.
In terms of an upside, certainly, the toll projects could accelerate. I think that people had a clearer view of what's going to happen with the election. They might have a better idea about whether they think they're going to be personally benefited or not economically from policy.
The product launches that we have could ramps faster than we have in our guidance, that would be nice, but you never know. And then our capital deployment, which we certainly expect to have more of augment growth as the year unfolds, but it's not in our guidance numbers.
If we look at kind of forward revenue and EBITDA leverage, EBITDA leverage is running a little better than 1/3 of new revenue. So even with the deleverage we got from oil and gas, we're still having overall net positive EBITDA leverage on new revenue. And if we -- what else we got -- sort of organic growth is 2% to 4% with revenue growth at 7% to 9% for the second half. If we did a bridge like we did at the beginning of the presentation, you'd see it would show similar results with revenue being up by 10% or more, excluding oil and gas.
Second half tax rate is probably around 30%, and then in the third quarter, we're looking at $1.59 to $1.63.
Next slide. Here, if we look at the summary of what happened in the quarter, you can see for us it was -- normally, we'd talk about the fact that we had record orders and backlog record sales and operating profit and EBITDA, all which is good, the margins are good, but we hit the lower end of the guidance, so we just didn't feel like leading with this kind of record results when we were a little bit disappointed on the actual EPS number.
Orders, as we said, were an all-time record and up 9%, with a backlog of $1.14 billion; a book to bill, well above 1. So we're well positioned to continue to have a stronger second half.
We get rid of the $10 million a quarter drag from Puerto Rico beginning now, here in the third quarter, and we get rid of the drag on the divestiture of ABEL in the fourth quarter, so a little bit of a drag in Q3.
Revenue being up 5%. We were able to do that because we had sort of high single digits, low double-digit growth between medical, software and water, which allowed us to survive this greater than 40% reduction in our upstream oil and gas businesses. Gross margin at 61%, we feel very good about that. EBITDA margin is fine, likely we're going to improve in the second half a little bit.
Operating cash flow is the same thing, 132% conversion and $414 million. It'll to be stronger as always is in the second half, so we're quite comfortable with where we are on the operating cash flow.
Back in '14, our oil and gas business was a little above $500 million and 14% of the company. And in 2015, that had dropped to around $400 million and about 11.5% of the company. And today, we think it will finish the year at around $300 million, which will be less than 8% of the company, and the upstream portion is going to be less 50% of the company with the midstream being around 6. So the orders stood behind us for this kind of change, and we're looking forward to that.
We got a very active pipeline. We are open on quite a few deals. We said at the beginning of the year, we expect to deploy $1 billion, but $275 million to work thus far. It's not going to be difficult to find our way to deploying that level of activity.
We still have a great opportunity to continue to compound results. It's really continues to drive our strategy, so we've got our underlying core businesses doing relatively well on a growth perspective, it's just the oil and gas and unique situation with Puerto Rico, which was a win for us, even though it shows up negatively in the first half revenue. It keeps us and all of our strategies alive, and we're very comfortable with our ability to compound results from here out.
So with that, we'll open it up to questions.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Deane Dray with RBC capital markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Deane Dray with RBC capital markets.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian or John, I was hoping you could start with bridging the guidance for third quarter and fourth quarter. It just looks like the guidance cut here this morning is weighing higher, obviously, on the third quarter, down 12% versus consensus, but it does
componenttext: Brian or John, I was hoping you could start with bridging the guidance for third quarter and fourth quarter. It just looks like the guidance cut here this morning is weighing higher, obviously, on the third quarter, down 12% versus consensus, but it does not appear in the fourth quarter? And maybe is there some seasonality? Is it the comps getting easier, better visibility on these product launches? But just some color there on the difference here, assumptions in third and fourth quarter?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Deane, so you did touch on it. So one of the things that we're expecting for this year is maybe not historically strong from a seasonality perspective, but stronger than what we saw last year. And that's not just on the energy businesses but also at
componenttext: Yes, Deane, so you did touch on it. So one of the things that we're expecting for this year is maybe not historically strong from a seasonality perspective, but stronger than what we saw last year. And that's not just on the energy businesses but also at some of the other industrial businesses that have some more seasonal activity as customers flush out some of their budget. So we do expect that for the fourth quarter, and that's why you see slightly higher in the fourth quarter than the third quarter as we look forward to this. My answer must have left everyone dumbfounded. Are we live on the call here?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you are still alive. We will now hear from Robert McCarthy from Stifel, Nicolaus & Company.
componenttext: Yes, you are still alive. We will now hear from Robert McCarthy from Stifel, Nicolaus & Company.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Deane must have dropped the mic. In any event, maybe you could talk about the medical business, in terms of maybe amplifying your comments around the product launches, the favorable compares to MHA? And then, what drives the 6% organic growth versus the 9
componenttext: Deane must have dropped the mic. In any event, maybe you could talk about the medical business, in terms of maybe amplifying your comments around the product launches, the favorable compares to MHA? And then, what drives the 6% organic growth versus the 9% organic growth, kind of, for the back half?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we had lot of chances responsible for the medical and software businesses. There is an opportunity to explain. The pipeline is growing candidly more rapidly than we could have hoped. And we can tell you a little bit about what these new launches at Sun
componenttext: So we had lot of chances responsible for the medical and software businesses. There is an opportunity to explain. The pipeline is growing candidly more rapidly than we could have hoped. And we can tell you a little bit about what these new launches at Sunquest are designed to do. So Neil, with that, fire away.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. The second half has stretched across the board. I will break it down by product and software. From the product side, there's new project at Verathon that continue to gain traction. On the software side, a number of areas, we talked about the
componenttext: Good morning. The second half has stretched across the board. I will break it down by product and software. From the product side, there's new project at Verathon that continue to gain traction. On the software side, a number of areas, we talked about the 4 number of the faster-growing software businesses, our -- turned organic, Strata, Data Innovations, SoftWriters, SHP. And then with the second half from the MHA, we do see likely where they all read your comps and then the market conditions around new customer adds give us an opportunity to do better in the second half than the first half.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So people are more interested in Sunquest. So I'll just talk about the launch of the new -- you've got 4 major offerings and then you got mid-teens in terms of enhancements and upgrades that match -- putting in place that we're already starting to solicit
componenttext: So people are more interested in Sunquest. So I'll just talk about the launch of the new -- you've got 4 major offerings and then you got mid-teens in terms of enhancements and upgrades that match -- putting in place that we're already starting to solicit revenue. So you might explain what those things do.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Sunquest, we're excited about Sunquest. The reality at Sunquest is we've worked very hard for the last 18 months on a series of new products. We talked about those number of new products are being grandeur, material upgrades or enhancement or increa
componenttext: Well, Sunquest, we're excited about Sunquest. The reality at Sunquest is we've worked very hard for the last 18 months on a series of new products. We talked about those number of new products are being grandeur, material upgrades or enhancement or increases being in the high teens. We're on track for all of that. We just come off a great user conference at Sunquest where the customers were excited about the road map, and all that was happening. We've seen a pretty meaningful increase in the pipeline, the sales pipeline, the sales funnel activity that you expect to see coming behind a large number of new products. We'd like to see that pipeline convert in the second half. We expect it to convert in the second half, so we'll see bookings momentum, and that will give us the momentum heading into 2017 for Sunquest that we've talked about in the past.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And switching gears to M&A and capital redeployment. I think the messaging may be up until this cost, but it will be more muted in kind of second quarter given where public valuations are for a lot of companies, given where the cost of funds is. Maybe you
componenttext: And switching gears to M&A and capital redeployment. I think the messaging may be up until this cost, but it will be more muted in kind of second quarter given where public valuations are for a lot of companies, given where the cost of funds is. Maybe you could just talk about -- do you think it's a difficult environment to transact deals just given political uncertainty, attentively arising stock market with improving valuations and public fundamentals kind of bleeding in the private fundamentals, and then kind of perhaps some of your companies thinking about the alternative route for initial public offerings? Could you just talk about how you look at this environment? And how do you think Roper is going to be able to transact in this environment? And what kind of cadence you guys can transact in?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, for us, it's kind of a perfect environment, although you're right about the pricing of assets and the expectation of sellers. It's pretty high, but fortunately, for us, we are not buying public companies and paying a premium for it. So we'r
componenttext: Well, I think, for us, it's kind of a perfect environment, although you're right about the pricing of assets and the expectation of sellers. It's pretty high, but fortunately, for us, we are not buying public companies and paying a premium for it. So we're buying private companies that if they were public we'd trade at a higher value than they do trade in the private marketplace, which gives us always some beneficial arbitrage. There are as many things available in the acquisition market as I've ever seen. We have looked at billions of dollars of transactions this year, and we're directly engaged with a couple now that have a higher likelihood of closing. I think that the ones that we were looking at earlier in the year because of the quality of the business. A lot of the people that are running these private companies aren't interested in becoming public. They would much rather join our firm at the public equity and our firm that -- and not have the quarterly calls and all of the things that you have to do with investors and banks. So we remain a very attractive home for people, and I think that acquisitions we made in the last couple of years give us a wider variety of things that we can look at. Application software has a huge number of potential verticals, and there are a lot of niches within that the largest people, that are roll up people, aren't going to be interested in. So it's still a very favorable hunting ground for us. Now the challenge, I think, for the -- all the industry guys in buying things is they tend to not buy things that are us higher quality is what we're buying. And if you're in a marketplace where you're looking for synergies that are going to be driven by overhead absorption or business consolidation or administrative synergies or something, those businesses are trading at a disproportionately high price than the way they normally would because the interest rates are so low. The highest quality businesses, oddly enough, trade at a much deeper discount to public comps. People will look at Roper and say, "Oh my gosh, look, they paid 12x for something." Well, if you looked at the public company comp, it was trading at 25x or 26x. So I think that people are focused on product-oriented, more asset-intensive businesses that are trading at 12x or 13x because of very low interest rates, and people are buying them for 12x or 13x or 14x. We're not in that space. We're in a space where buying stuff at 12x or 13x or 14x, that if it we were public, we'd trade at a higher number because of our willingness and experience in how to effectuate those companies joining our public family.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you indulge, it will be just one last question. And I apologize at the outset to be a little impolite. But do you think this is the last guidance comp we're going to face for 2016?
componenttext: If you indulge, it will be just one last question. And I apologize at the outset to be a little impolite. But do you think this is the last guidance comp we're going to face for 2016?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do, I bet money on that.
componenttext: I do, I bet money on that.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will now hear from Joe Giordano with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We will now hear from Joe Giordano with Cowen and Company.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you -- I don't want to beat on Sunquest too much, you've already talked about it, but can you kind of get into a little bit more detail about these new products? Or actually what actually are they? How are they extending the platform? And maybe talk
componenttext: When you -- I don't want to beat on Sunquest too much, you've already talked about it, but can you kind of get into a little bit more detail about these new products? Or actually what actually are they? How are they extending the platform? And maybe talk a bit about the competitive dynamics in that markets versus you to -- versus you guys? And how they're concerned? And how that's being progressing over the last, maybe, 12 months or something like that?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a great question, Joe. So Neil, why don't -- you can explain these 4 core products and all the enhancements?
componenttext: Yes. It's a great question, Joe. So Neil, why don't -- you can explain these 4 core products and all the enhancements?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I appreciate the opportunity. So let me give you 30 seconds on the importance of what Sunquest does for our customers. So Sunquest customers are the largest, most complicated laboratories in the United States. These are laboratories that do mi
componenttext: Sure. Well, I appreciate the opportunity. So let me give you 30 seconds on the importance of what Sunquest does for our customers. So Sunquest customers are the largest, most complicated laboratories in the United States. These are laboratories that do millions of tests a year. And what our software does is automate from start to finish the laboratory processes. So you get super high-quality results at low cost to operate the labs. So what Sunquest, the new -- the current products at Sunquest is to extend that capability that's been steeped in the blood side or the fluid side of the lab and extend it to the other parts of the laboratory. So first is a major product that is the integration of the pathologies inside of a hospital. So it integrates the blood, to the tissue, to the molecular genetic. Very important product for us and for our customers as they deliver medicine inside of their institutions. The second one is a completely refreshed view about how do you collect samples at the bedside. It's mobile-enabled, it's integrated into a nurse workflow, important in terms of getting the draws correct at the right location with the right patient, and get it to the laboratories as quickly as possible. The third category of new products is helping the hospitals extend their reach into the communities. Importantly, in the changing reimbursement landscape in U.S. health care, hospitals want the laboratory samples that are in the community being where the physicians that see patients into their hospitals. They want the blood test that are collected in all laboratories test that are collected in the physicians offices to be routed into the hospital's laboratory, not just to drive volume in laboratory but to give the clinical information. And so we have a series of tools that integrate into the electronic medical records at the physicians offices for ordering and resulting. And then finally, laboratory space has been vacant of any meaningful analytics about how they run the operations, how they benchmark themselves against their peers and improve the operations. So we have a large analytics release that's happening in the second half of this year. Those are 4 net new opportunities. As we talked about earlier, there is a series of other meaningful upgrades. We've just released a major upgrade to our core clinical pathology on our core blood bank. We've seen the opportunities associated with those upgrades number in the hundreds, and so we are very excited about what the team has been able to build their products with respect to Sunquest.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. One just kind of going with that, typically, we see a pretty steep margin ramp in the second half for that segment overall, because most of us are calling in that boat [ph] right now. So can you kind of talk us through what drives tha
componenttext: That's very helpful. One just kind of going with that, typically, we see a pretty steep margin ramp in the second half for that segment overall, because most of us are calling in that boat [ph] right now. So can you kind of talk us through what drives that historically? And is that something we should still think is applicable for this year?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's was it is. It's something that we're expecting as well. And it's really volume-driven. So it's a comment -- this segment has our highest gross margins across the enterprise with gross margins that are north of 70%. Some of our businesses here ev
componenttext: Yes. It's was it is. It's something that we're expecting as well. And it's really volume-driven. So it's a comment -- this segment has our highest gross margins across the enterprise with gross margins that are north of 70%. Some of our businesses here even have gross margins above that. And so as we see incremental growth on the top side, we expect that to fall through. And so that really is what drives the margin improvement as we go throughout the year. And that's true on -- not only the software-type businesses, like Neil was just talking about, but also our products businesses, and particularly at Gatan and some of our imaging business will have very high gross margins because of all the technology and all the R&D that we invest there. It does result in higher gross margins. So if the volume increases, we expect that fall through to improve. And that results in a higher margin in the fourth quarter than what we had throughout the first part of the year.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

So I want to see what you guys are thinking about that business in the U.S., particularly in the second half?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as far as the numbers are concerned, I'll turn it over to Brian on the commentary around the business outlook. If the order growth was both on the toll and traffic side where the book-to-bill ratio was very strong, 1.14, I believe, but it was also o
componenttext: Well, as far as the numbers are concerned, I'll turn it over to Brian on the commentary around the business outlook. If the order growth was both on the toll and traffic side where the book-to-bill ratio was very strong, 1.14, I believe, but it was also on the software side. Now a little bit of that is seasonal is our CBORD business, in particular, which serves the college -- the university market. They have a lot of their renewals and upgrades and security applications that are booked in the second quarter and then delivered or recognized as revenue throughout the year. And so a little bit of that is seasonal, but we saw fundamental growth on the software orders as well. But the largest reason for the book to bill being well above 1 is the backlog that's building on the toll and traffic side. Even though we've seen delays there, we still see fundamental growth happening there in the second half.

componenttextpreview: So my first question is on the portfolio. Brian, if clearly energy surprised the downside, industrial remains weak, but can you guys are continuing to evolve as a technology company? I'm just wondering whether any of the 10 market dynamics have kind chang
componenttext: So my first question is on the portfolio. Brian, if clearly energy surprised the downside, industrial remains weak, but can you guys are continuing to evolve as a technology company? I'm just wondering whether any of the 10 market dynamics have kind changed your view about the portfolio? And then if there's any potential divestitures that you guys are considering?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I'd say the answer is no. See, when we went into the year thinking that would be down about $100 million in the oil and gas, which comes in a little bit into industrial, mostly into energy -- I'm sorry, we thought we did -- we're down about $75 millio
componenttext: No, I'd say the answer is no. See, when we went into the year thinking that would be down about $100 million in the oil and gas, which comes in a little bit into industrial, mostly into energy -- I'm sorry, we thought we did -- we're down about $75 million, now we're going to be down $100 million. So that $25 million extra negative situation on revenue is disappointing because it comes in at 50%, or frankly, 60% contribution. So it's a big EPS number. It doesn't really diminish our cash performance by much at all. And those businesses, at the moment, are just a free shot on goal for 2017 and '18. They're on the books for an extremely low basis. So the only way if you were going to do something with them, if you want to do either a straight stand or response or to stand or whether you want to do an RFP with somebody on it, it will be safe to say that our phone has been ringing off the hook, with people who want to do those kind of things. But we actually think there's substantial upside in those businesses just not this year, and probably not in the first 3 quarters or next year. But if they start cranking, just modestly in 2018, we're going to have windfall kind of results. So we prefer to hold onto them, continue to invest. The industrial business was 26% EBITDA in the quarter, I would say, and energy business -- we got 31% in industrial and 26% in energy. So -- I mean, these are really good businesses. Most of our investors, when we talk to the long [ph] guys, their fear is, "Gee, if you put those someplace, how could we trust they can run them as well as you can." And we always humbly say, "Well, you may be right." So these are great businesses. They're just in situation where if somebody is off 44% to 52%, it's incredible, but they're still able to perform at the levels they are, because they are so nimble. So I don't really see those as necessary sales. We know how to run them, we know how to run them well. If they didn't have this extra $25 million headwind in the second half, our guidance reduction wouldn't have been so great. And then no one could have predict what happened with -- what's going on in Saudi is certainly an interesting time, and it affected several of our businesses' revenues in the second quarter. So I think the underlying thesis for us is we've got some cash cow businesses that are at their absolute nadir. They're going to continue to drive a lot of performance over the years, and they are a great annuity value for our investors.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. That's helpful color, Brian. Maybe switching gears, John, one quick question for you on the Medical & Scientific Imaging margins. In the first half of the year, down 250-plus basis points year-over-year, it looks like the D&A of the percentage of
componenttext: Got you. That's helpful color, Brian. Maybe switching gears, John, one quick question for you on the Medical & Scientific Imaging margins. In the first half of the year, down 250-plus basis points year-over-year, it looks like the D&A of the percentage of sales was roughly the same as last year's. I'm just wondering, whether any mixed issues that impacted the first half as well beyond just the M&A?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, the M&A does have an impact here, right? Because we acquired CliniSys, which on an operating-profit basis is below the segment average. And frankly, even on an EBITDA basis, it's below the segment average, right? Remember the segment average
componenttext: Sure. I mean, the M&A does have an impact here, right? Because we acquired CliniSys, which on an operating-profit basis is below the segment average. And frankly, even on an EBITDA basis, it's below the segment average, right? Remember the segment average here is at the low 40% EBITDA margin range. So the fact that CliniSys comes in at only in the 35%, if it were less than that EBITDA margin range going to drag it down. So that is a contributor. And then the other piece is as far as the relative mix between -- so our medical growth so far this year and in fact, for the remainder of the year as well, although not as much in the fourth quarter has been driven more by product, by medical products sales. Still terrific businesses and great margin, but not the highest margin businesses inside the segment, which is really more of the software and services side. So it's more of a mix issue, but we see that mix issue actually moderating as we go throughout the year. And to an earlier question, that's why we see some fall through in margin expansion in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: Well, there's no question about that. I mean, the decision -- I mean, look, that decision is made. It's done. We've started. But we would have expected it to be in the 30s of millions of dollars. It totally offset some of the issues with Puerto Rico. It's going to be above $10 million. How much above that is hard to say. If you were to really -- they're doing a massive transit system over there. They've got lots of priorities. They're extremely happy with our performance. We're happy with the relationship. It's going to be extremely valuable over a long period of time. But in the short run, we're going to likely get at least $20 million less than we expected in the beginning of the year. And we got somewhat less in the quarter -- in this quarter. And all of our numbers issues are really just around the severity of the upstream being far worse than we thought. And the toll and traffic kind of stuff, if you look at the quarter, it's pretty significant. When you look at the year, it's easier to calibrate now.

componenttextpreview: Well, we just don't know. Last year was -- normally, you get basically because people have a lot of MRO left at the end of the year, but we didn't see any benefit of that because people just shut down. This year, all year long, anybody who's in the upstre
componenttext: Well, we just don't know. Last year was -- normally, you get basically because people have a lot of MRO left at the end of the year, but we didn't see any benefit of that because people just shut down. This year, all year long, anybody who's in the upstream business would know that people are cannibalizing what they have got, nobody is buying anything, rental fleets are in distress. But there are increasing number of signals that would say that the cannibalization of all the stack horsepower business out there, at some point, will turn into new orders and revenue. We just have no idea where it will be. We do expect a modest improvement in the fourth quarter of this year versus last year. And could it be even better? I don't know.

componenttext: Yes. So the medical products was up by, I think, it was in the 9% or 10% range with the medical software and services up, I think, 1%. headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand. Okay. And then, just one last question for Brian. You have mentioned earlier in the M&A pipeline, it was pulled the application software businesses. There were labs on those prospects in there. Is there anything that Roper could do in that a
componenttext: I understand. Okay. And then, just one last question for Brian. You have mentioned earlier in the M&A pipeline, it was pulled the application software businesses. There were labs on those prospects in there. Is there anything that Roper could do in that application software area that would have more scale? We've seen good success with Sunquest and MHA and tucking in some related businesses at Sunquest, at CliniSys and GeneInsight and Atlas. And I'm curious, do we stay on that path with more of the bolt-ons to Sunquest and MHA? Or is there something in there with some scale that we could pull in?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's a really good question. The answer is yes and yes. So one of the incredible things about Sunquest and MHA is their platform status. So if they allow us to do these incredibly attractive small acquisitions that we wouldn't do on our own. I mean, th
componenttext: So it's a really good question. The answer is yes and yes. So one of the incredible things about Sunquest and MHA is their platform status. So if they allow us to do these incredibly attractive small acquisitions that we wouldn't do on our own. I mean, things like SoftWriters and Strata are just really amazing. I mean, these are very high-growth businesses, and hopefully, we'll continue like that even though they're on a small base. If you look at the -- the last larger transaction was Aderant. There are a lot of things that was sort of the size of Aderant. And Aderant also offers us an opportunity for some bolt-on acquisitions to kind of grow its platform status. I would hope that the next acquisition we have is more like that, where it's meaningful, it's something that we know how to do, people would be confident that we're already doing those kinds of things. So that is likely what the next thing would be. Now that said, this year, we look at a number of very large transactions. And those are always of interest. We're incredibly conservative and careful around those. But I would be disappointed in the next 2 or 3 years if we didn't do a quite large transaction.

But I'm thinking, anything literally -- it's a bad word these days, but something on the industrial side that would be more software or SaaS? Is there any of those opportunities in the pipeline?

componenttextpreview: Well, there aren't a lot of industrial situations, there are a few, but there are a lot of things that are not medical that are vertical just like Aderant is certainly not a medical business. Some of the other acquisitions we've made are not medical at al
componenttext: Well, there aren't a lot of industrial situations, there are a few, but there are a lot of things that are not medical that are vertical just like Aderant is certainly not a medical business. Some of the other acquisitions we've made are not medical at all. I think that you're likely to see some acquisitions that are not medical at all, that's why we're kind of suggesting there's a lot of attractive application software businesses that are immediately in front of us. And there are project management businesses that are out there, quite a few of those, that are very interesting, some, which are sort of horizontal opportunities and other that are small verticals. So we have enough internal intellectual capital to handle a large acquisition that would not be in the medical space.
