componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Deane Dray at RBC Capital.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Andrew Krill on for Deane. I want to start on would ConstructConnect. That's the second meaningful deal you guys have done recently in Software-as-a-Service after Aderant. I was wondering if you could talk about market share within Construction. A
componenttext: This is Andrew Krill on for Deane. I want to start on would ConstructConnect. That's the second meaningful deal you guys have done recently in Software-as-a-Service after Aderant. I was wondering if you could talk about market share within Construction. And if there any unique barriers to entry versus peers for the business?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so this is John Humphrey. And as far as the barriers, I mean the barriers, of course, for a network business is the strength and size of the network and the ability for all of the different users to be able to transact business and grow their own bu
componenttext: Well, so this is John Humphrey. And as far as the barriers, I mean the barriers, of course, for a network business is the strength and size of the network and the ability for all of the different users to be able to transact business and grow their own business by utilizing the ConstructConnect network and software solutions. And I think it goes to the size of the network. What Brian talked about, 800,000 users and $55 million invitations to bid every year encompassing almost 400,000 different commercial construction projects. I mean, the size of the network and the combination that the ConstructConnect has been able to put together between their different brands of square foot and bid quarter Construct data and really turn that into a single integrated platform, that's really unique insight industry. So from a competitive position, I think for most of those customers, the way that they are able to grow their business and to bid on more projects and to win more is through connection to the ConstructConnect network. And so that's really the strength of that and the competitive position, there are couple of comparators out there that also provide, particularly on the construction data side. But on the network and integrated data, we really don't think there's any one of size there.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow. Do you have any sense of potential accretion that, I guess, kind of very guys you think the EBITDA margin could eventually go versus the sort of 33%, so you're expecting next year?
componenttext: Just a quick follow. Do you have any sense of potential accretion that, I guess, kind of very guys you think the EBITDA margin could eventually go versus the sort of 33%, so you're expecting next year?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we still have a lot of work to do but everywhere the close on the transaction. But as we're thinking about it there's probably somewhere in the $0.10 to $0.15 accretive for next year we'll be able to update you on that, of course, as we finalize the
componenttext: Well, we still have a lot of work to do but everywhere the close on the transaction. But as we're thinking about it there's probably somewhere in the $0.10 to $0.15 accretive for next year we'll be able to update you on that, of course, as we finalize the purchase accounting. And the margin profile here is also very good, right? We're talking about that's something already in the mid-30% EBITDA margin, and so as it continues to grow, it will grow with high incremental margins. And so that's how we see the margin progression over time as this network continues to get bigger.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to add to the understanding that these acquisitions have a lot of noncash amortization. So a GAAP DEPS basis, people are looking at expensing that amortization and depressing what otherwise looks like earnings per share. Reality is it will be
componenttext: I just want to add to the understanding that these acquisitions have a lot of noncash amortization. So a GAAP DEPS basis, people are looking at expensing that amortization and depressing what otherwise looks like earnings per share. Reality is it will be very cash accretive. But on a GAAP DEPS basis, it mainly add $0.10 for $0.15. I think you'll get paid as a shareholder for monitoring what's happening to the quality of the cash earnings. The cash earnings of ConstructConnect will be great.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

But in terms of the medical cadence for the fourth quarter in Energy, could you just expand on your comments about what kind of brought the guy down for the fourth quarter?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think 2 things in terms of DEPS is that it's just our view of that is we're not going to get much in the way of seasonality. When we look at the orders that came in the third quarter, we'll get a lot of footprints, and we call them [indiscernible], so t
componenttext: I think 2 things in terms of DEPS is that it's just our view of that is we're not going to get much in the way of seasonality. When we look at the orders that came in the third quarter, we'll get a lot of footprints, and we call them [indiscernible], so they're booked within a quarter, shipped within the next quarter. And we didn't see any uptick that, that would give us a reason to think we can have normalized Q4 seasonality. But we could be wrong about that, that would be upside, that it could happen to us. So I think it's back more than any one item and then we've been ready to go on a couple of projects so we expect, and we're ready [indiscernible].

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Energy is not particularly surprising, but the medical cadence. Could you just expand upon that? Because I think your expectations kind of high single growth, that's kind of an exit rate for fourth quarter?
componenttext: Energy is not particularly surprising, but the medical cadence. Could you just expand upon that? Because I think your expectations kind of high single growth, that's kind of an exit rate for fourth quarter?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Robert, I think you're right about that. And once again, it goes back to what Brian was talking about. We will get the product orders so -- and I'll talk specifically around medical products where we expected that kind of last time we talked that the
componenttext: Yes, Robert, I think you're right about that. And once again, it goes back to what Brian was talking about. We will get the product orders so -- and I'll talk specifically around medical products where we expected that kind of last time we talked that the exit closer to 10% growth rate, that's exiting closer to the 5% growth rate. And that combined with the timing of imaging to orders and delivery. So all the life science things that Brian talked about earlier, those are actually very sophisticated instruments and cameras and filters. There are as kind of I don't -- it's not just like machining and creating a vault. So the process in order to be able to turn bad from order to delivery can easily be a 60, 90, 120 days depending on yield and throughput, particularly from suppliers around some of the centers. And so as we look at the deliveries and the delivery schedule, particularly on the imaging product side and also on the medical products side, that's where we see a slight difference from what we would have thought before. But we still see this segment exiting at the mid-single-digit rate very consistent with where it has been over the past 2.5 years.

Because it has been in the main kind of difficult environment to get deals done?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you go back to January '15, in that 21 period we've deployed $2.7 billion in capital. I mean, in the next 21-month period or much sooner, I would think that, that kind of run rates are possible. We've got not hundreds of millions but millions of d
componenttext: Yes, if you go back to January '15, in that 21 period we've deployed $2.7 billion in capital. I mean, in the next 21-month period or much sooner, I would think that, that kind of run rates are possible. We've got not hundreds of millions but millions of dollars of capital to be able to put to work and getting the new $2.5 billion revolver, which is undrawn done was a big deal because it's given us some flexibility around how much we can deploy at any 1 point in time, and that's very helpful. So there are a number of small deals that we're engage with at the moment and a couple of larger transactions which would be even bigger than ConstructConnect that we're involved with that we think are very attractive. So you never know in terms of your word cadence how that will happen, but I'd be very, very surprised if we didn't deploy quite a bit of capital in the next 12 months.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you get the sense that given where the rates are and when you're looking at deals are you having to stretch a little bit more in terms of multiple because competitors who are looking at the same assets are able to kind of do some funny math with rates
componenttext: Do you get the sense that given where the rates are and when you're looking at deals are you having to stretch a little bit more in terms of multiple because competitors who are looking at the same assets are able to kind of do some funny math with rates being here in terms of returns?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I wish it was funny math, but it wasn't funny math. The difference is we don't like to go above like we're not [indiscernible] to EBITDA. So those guys are willing to take debt stable and banks split on bank and nonbank entities put on 30% 8x EBITDA
componenttext: Well, I wish it was funny math, but it wasn't funny math. The difference is we don't like to go above like we're not [indiscernible] to EBITDA. So those guys are willing to take debt stable and banks split on bank and nonbank entities put on 30% 8x EBITDA, right? So they don't deploy much more equity in a transaction than we do. We just don't want to have 7 or 8x debt-to-EBITDA. We're going to remain investment-grade and to do that, you want to be around 4x debt-to-EBITDA, coming back to 3%, to 3.5%. So we're very disciplined about wanting to and guaranteeing ourselves to maintain an investment-grade status. The prices that people are paying for things are really bifurcated. I mean, on industrial assets are trading and really more than there were normalized interest rate environment in a M&A world because they don't have a lot of EBITDA even though they'll require a lot of capital spending to maintain that EBITDA. So there's multiples are interestingly high. Then the asset-light business is traded a premium for that, but the arbitrage for us on the asset-light business is more favorable than those people that are buying the capital intensive businesses. So something like ConstructConnect will be a long-term compounder of investment for us, which is great as opposed to the guys that are buying the capital-intensive businesses, thinking that [indiscernible], it's looks like paying a lot the of their cyclical activity and when they're desired number this will happen, we'll leave that field to everybody else. It's not where we're going.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on Neptune as well. I mean, the results this quarter obviously very, very strong. There's this story up there that's been out there for a while they're not about a lack of investment. You talked about $550 million [ph] of M&A. Can y
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on Neptune as well. I mean, the results this quarter obviously very, very strong. There's this story up there that's been out there for a while they're not about a lack of investment. You talked about $550 million [ph] of M&A. Can you just talk about your positioning there on the highest technology type products like an AMI development and how you're capitalizing on your installed base? I mean, the numbers speak for themselves, but this is kind of been out there for a while and maybe give you guys the chance to address that.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I'm not -- $50 million is what we've done in R&D, not M&A.
componenttext: Yes, I think I'm not -- $50 million is what we've done in R&D, not M&A.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm sorry if I misspoke year.
componenttext: Yes, I'm sorry if I misspoke year.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the last 3 years, we put $50 million of work there. We're also opening a new software development center for Neptune that will really help us and not the things we're doing. So we don't provide a lot of information about what we're doing, but I just us
componenttext: In the last 3 years, we put $50 million of work there. We're also opening a new software development center for Neptune that will really help us and not the things we're doing. So we don't provide a lot of information about what we're doing, but I just use the best reading technology that's available, it has the highest integrity results. We have an enormous installed base and maybe people forget, the way our R900 product works, we can upgrade that, the AMI status and there's a lot of ways to collect the technology, but if you got the right core unit that can use multiple ways of gathering the data, you'd be a little bit ahead of the game. So we're able to do upgrades for people in the AMI arena that they always -- if they ever were migrating to it, they do that and when a lot of -- it's over $3 million of that just in the third quarter. If you saw other things, you see mobile activity, you see Verizon picking us as person that they're working with development on mobile technology. So there's a lot of different things going on, and we're not going to provide more information than we have around that, but we're -- this Neptune will have record performance in 2016. So if anybody thought it didn't have some kind of long-term reason for performing well explain to me why they're growing so much.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair enough. And last, if I could. John, you talked last quarter -- when you were talking about Sunquest some small hospitals taking maybe epic on, and you said that made sense for that size of the customer and your core being large hospitals. Can
componenttext: That's fair enough. And last, if I could. John, you talked last quarter -- when you were talking about Sunquest some small hospitals taking maybe epic on, and you said that made sense for that size of the customer and your core being large hospitals. Can you just talk about how that went through for 3Q? Is it kind of stabilized and the customer base that you focus on your remain to be the capture rate there is being consistent?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It has been consistent. And I think that should be right. Brian talked about the order intake, right? So [indiscernible] that fully 2/3 if not more of Sunquest revenue is recurring revenue in terms of maintenance on installed software that's already
componenttext: Yes. It has been consistent. And I think that should be right. Brian talked about the order intake, right? So [indiscernible] that fully 2/3 if not more of Sunquest revenue is recurring revenue in terms of maintenance on installed software that's already been out there. And so when we look at the order intake, it's a much smaller piece of their total revenue buy. But one day look at their order intake, which is about the new lab 8.0 , it's about the new blood bank solution, it's the new outreach solution, so the nurses can start the testing process right at the bedside and be able to start that data flow and workflow to the lab right from the bedside, so all of those upgrades are driving that order intake to be a record level for the third quarter. It is true that on the lower end, the smaller hospitals and integrated solution can make economic sense for them, but the competitive environment and the solution that Sunquest delivers is it continues to be very good and our competitive position venues very strong, particularly in those large hospitals.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could expand a little bit on Sunquest. You talked about record quarters. Maybe just the richness of this product upgrade cycle that we've seen and maybe give us a little bit of a preface is what we might expect for 2017.
componenttext: Wondering if you could expand a little bit on Sunquest. You talked about record quarters. Maybe just the richness of this product upgrade cycle that we've seen and maybe give us a little bit of a preface is what we might expect for 2017.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's early to talk about 2017. We actually have a review coming up with Sunquest in about a month. We will be talking about only 2017, but importantly, 2018 and 2019 and the plants that they have around the investments there. And so one is what I
componenttext: I think it's early to talk about 2017. We actually have a review coming up with Sunquest in about a month. We will be talking about only 2017, but importantly, 2018 and 2019 and the plants that they have around the investments there. And so one is what I always kind of just mentioning in terms of the continued on the upgrade side around Lab 8.0 and the new blood bank solution but all, so I wouldn't ignore the investments that we've made around genetic testing and the workflows associated with that. So you really have the blood side, which is the core lab higher volume testing environment that every hospital have to have. And the other side, which is the anatomic pathology and the emerging genetic workflows around genetic testing. That's where we've made important investments with the acquisition of GeneInsight and continued R&D around being able to make that workflow as efficient and as quick with getting the information back to the doctor as timely as happens today on the blood site. And so for all of those reasons, I think the Sunquest and our entire platform of hospitals software solutions, which, of course, includes Data Innovations and CliniSys and GeneInsight and a variety of other things, all of those businesses really delivered those software solutions to hospitals. I think their future looks very bright as a result of investment that we continue to make there.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: Great, that's helpful. Maybe just a follow-up on the M&A pipeline. It sounds robust. You certainly have a lot of dry powder. Can you maybe talk about the quality of those deals? Some of the -- this ConstructConnect looks very asset-light negative working capital. It appears that the quality is actually increasing as the pipeline is. Could you maybe discuss that?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you can really see that when you look at that net working capital sharp where you're down at 5.8. People think you're not going to get lower and now, we're at 1.9. Certainly a lot of that the deferred revenue you get paid in advance for work you do a
componenttext: Yes, you can really see that when you look at that net working capital sharp where you're down at 5.8. People think you're not going to get lower and now, we're at 1.9. Certainly a lot of that the deferred revenue you get paid in advance for work you do and most of the things that we look at these days have those qualities. So we thought enough we'll get to 0 will ultimately negative at some point, but I don't see us going up. The amount of small niche businesses that work kind of oligopolies were customer industry is critical and then those that have the ability to have kind of the network effect, there are more of those things out there than you might imagine because when you're focused on product businesses, you don't necessarily tick some of these kind of things. But all of the people that are involved in transactions in the banking businesses and the private equity business kind of know what we favor, what we look like. And so the final that we have incoming opportunity is really amazing. And just incumbent on us to sort through that and I the best management teams and the best in market opportunities there in probably competitive environments. Believe me, there is more high-quality kinds available at our balance sheet could tolerate. Fortunately, but a big enough balance sheet to capture some of them.

componenttext: Brian, could you just talk for 1 minute or 2 about the New York MTA contract? I think you mentioned 3 sites should be performed in the fourth quarter kind of accelerated. Given the size of the contract, are we talking about maybe $20 million to $25 million of revenue in the fourth quarter? And then the balance of the sites, the other 6 sites, has that all falling into the first half of '17?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. I think that the contract is very specific in terms of what they been willing to release, and it will be done by November of 2017. It's what we're told. There was really even 1 -- remember you get the like ramp, right? So we've been doing some
componenttext: No, no, no. I think that the contract is very specific in terms of what they been willing to release, and it will be done by November of 2017. It's what we're told. There was really even 1 -- remember you get the like ramp, right? So we've been doing some engineering work with them to assure that the overhead kiosk and everything built and are going to be okay. Say it will start slow. I don't know, maybe we could get $10 million in the fourth quarter of revenue that we have with the rest being whatever it is, it's about $72 million for the entire period, and it will be really up to them at the pace they want us to do the installation and release [indiscernible] technology.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And in the last question I have just around MHA. There's a lot of noise around drug pricing, both generic as well as branded. And then also, I noticed in the slide that you had -- that there was a suggestion that the alternative sites so
componenttext: Okay, understood. And in the last question I have just around MHA. There's a lot of noise around drug pricing, both generic as well as branded. And then also, I noticed in the slide that you had -- that there was a suggestion that the alternative sites solutions business would kind of be a leader here in the fourth quarter. Can you just kind of pull all that together? Has the noise around drug pricing impacted just the revenue stream in the past through there at MHA? And then also, is the alternative sites solutions business being kind of the fourth quarter leader? Is the timing there or is there contract renewals or what would drive that in the fourth quarter?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. In terms of its contribution on the growth side, it was up in the kind of 3% or 4% in the third quarter, and we expect that to be modestly better in the fourth quarter. From a drug pricing standpoint, I mean, you're right, that is something tha
componenttext: Yes, sure. In terms of its contribution on the growth side, it was up in the kind of 3% or 4% in the third quarter, and we expect that to be modestly better in the fourth quarter. From a drug pricing standpoint, I mean, you're right, that is something that we look at. A lot of the headlines that you see around drug pricing aren't really targeted for or being sold our senior population. Remember MHA is around alternate site health care and the largest portion of their revenue is coming from skilled nursing homes, long-term care facilities. It's not really the headline prices around EpiPen or whatever else that you might read in the Wall Street Journal. It's really for kind of the longer chronic illnesses that they are being sold through the MHA contracting vehicles. So we do look at drug pricing. It's been lower than what we would have seen in years past, but still positive in 2016. While I want talk an awful lot of drug pricing left as we think about the future for MHA. They continue to expand their solutions and nondrug supply chains, including food and other things for our long-term care facilities and other nursing homes. So they continue to expand that and then also expand their software solutions around data analytics. You've seen us make a couple of acquisition that also serve the alternate site health care, which are not GPO but are really around software solutions that allow those numbers and customers to run their businesses more efficiently. That's where we look for growth. We don't really count on underlying drug price increases as something that is going to drive our performance. Although it does have an impact on our revenue.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Audra, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the third quarter financial results for Roper Technologies. Joining me on the call this morning are Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Humph
componenttext:
Thank you, Audra, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the third quarter financial results for Roper Technologies. 
Joining me on the call this morning are Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Humphrey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Paul Soni, our Vice President and Controller. 
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast or also available on our website. 
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 2. We begin with our safe harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we'll be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information. 
And now please turn to Slide 3. Today, we'll be discussing our results for the quarter primarily on an adjusted non-GAAP basis. A full reconciliation between GAAP and adjusted measures is in our press release this morning and also included as a part of this presentation on our website. 
For third the quarter, the difference between our GAAP results and adjusted results consist of 2 items: First, a $2.2 million purchase accounting adjustment to acquire deferred revenue relating to software acquisitions. This represents revenue that those companies would have recognized if not for our acquisition. Second, a $0.9 million debt extinguishment charge related to the replacement of our former credit facility with a new $2.5 billion facility that closed in the quarter. 
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 4. I will turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we will take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob, and good morning, everybody. We'll start here with the Q3 enterprise results, so next slide. We had a record for just about everything again in the third quarter. Our orders were an all-time record at $929 million. And by the way, if we
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob, and good morning, everybody. We'll start here with the Q3 enterprise results, so next slide. 
We had a record for just about everything again in the third quarter. Our orders were an all-time record at $929 million. And by the way, if we had booked the MTA order a couple of days earlier, but it wasn't quite ready to go, we would have been -- we'd have our first $1 billion quarter in our history. 
Revenue was strong. Net earnings were, of course, a record EBITDA cash flow. Revenue was up 7% to $947 million, which gave us 2 points of organic growth despite the headwinds in oil and gas. FX cost is 1 point. And acquisitions and divestitures, netted out, plus 6% because this was still the last quarter without all of the divestment in it.
Growth was led by both the Medical and RF Technology and Software businesses. And certainly, Neptune had an outstanding quarter. You'll see in a minute. 
Declines in oil and gas were basically about what we thought. We thought they'd be sort of down 20% or so, and they were. Gross margins were up 60 basis points to 61.3%, and EBITDA was up 8% to $328 million. Our net earnings reached $169 million, which gave us a DEPS earnings per share number of $1.65, ahead of our guidance. 
Free cash flow was up 40%. Really, an astonishing quarter, where our free cash flow is up 11% year-to-date, but up 40% in the third quarter. 
And then our ConstructConnect acquisition, which we're announcing today and which will close this week, is another terrific business for us. It's a SaaS network business for the preconstruction industry, and we'll detail that later in the call this morning, and it should close yet this week. 
So we have very strong cash quarter. We had record results, and then we had this great acquisition. 
So the next slide. Here if you look at the income statement, you can see orders were up 4%. The book-to-bill was 0.98, which is okay because of sort of lumpy activity. It's in the wheelhouse. But had we been able to book the MTA order, our book-to-bill would have been 105, which gives you some idea about how strong really the core orders were. The only thing then in the quarter that was odd is that the normal fourth quarter delivery schedule stuff was not very strong. 
Revenue was up 7%, our gross profit was up 8%. You can see we're up 60 basis points in gross profit. The operating income margin, because of the acquisition and amortization in these things, you can see it going to 28.5%, which is still spectacular but down 20 basis points. The reality is, on the next slide, you'll see the EBITA margin actually went up 30 basis points, which is the right way to look at a cash-oriented business like ours. And then net earnings were up 4%. Tax rate, about what we thought. 
Next slide. If you compare the operating and the EBITA margins, we certainly have not reported leading, first, with those kind of numbers. But our EBITA margin, as you can see in 2014's third quarter, were 32.5%. Last year at 33.4%. And this year, 33.7%. So our margins on the operating cash side are up 120 basis points in just 2 years, and our gross margins continue up as well. If -- focusing on the operating profit margin, where you get a lot of noncash amortization charges, would lead people to the wrong conclusion, it's the wrong way to think about cash business like ours, even though the results are outstanding. So we're really focused on continuing to improve our EBITA margins, which were up 30 basis points. 
Next slide. We continue to comp out cash flow at a quite strong clip, and we don't see that slowing down anytime soon. We really have terrific operating cash flow in the quarter, $317 million. Both operating and free cash flow were up 40%. And you can see the comparison to last year at $660 million year-to-date operating cash flow and now we're at $731 million, up 11% despite less-than-robust end markets in our industrial and energy businesses. 
Conversion was pretty spectacular. You can see our year-to-date conversion on operating cash flow is 146%, so excellent cash performance. 
Next slide. Our asset-light business model, which 5 years ago people told me you couldn't make it any better than it was, continues to improve at really phenomenal rates. Here, you can see inventory is down 80 basis points from 2 years ago. Receivables are down 150 basis points, and payables and accruals are actually up 160. So 2 years ago, we had 5.8% net working capital to revenue, and the way we measure it, today, we closed the quarter at 1.9%. That's a 67% reduction as a function of revenue in just 2 years, 390 basis points. So the quality of the asset-light acquisitions that we've been doing the last couple of years in addition to our own governance process around improving everything we own is really having just astonishing impact on our ability to compound cash and deploy future capital. 
Next slide. If you look here at the financial position of the company, you get some sense of the balance sheet. Just as a quick note, this is absolutely the biggest balance sheet that we have ever had to capture capital deployment opportunities. We now have an undrawn revolver of $2.5 billion, and we have $882 million of cash, so nearly $3.4 billion of powder. Even after paying for the ConstructConnect business, our acquisition powder is right around $2.8 billion. 
We begin -- we've deployed capital since January 1, 2015, at a rate of $2.7 billion during that 21-month period. So our compounding of the cash and the strength of the balance sheet and the flexibility that our new credit facility gives us is all great because we're going to be able to put that to good use with the incredible acquisition pipeline that we continue to see. And you can see our net debt to EBITDA number is only 1.7 after the acquisition. It's still just around 2, so we got a lot of ramp space here to be able to continue to make transactions that are accretive to the company. 
Next slide. We'll look at the segment detail of each of the 4 segments the way we record it, and then talk about the detail of the business here after that. 
So the next slide. Here, if we look at the Q3 segment performance of energy, you can see its EBITDA margin was 29%; Industrial Tech, 32%. The first point about thinking around these businesses is how remarkable their margin performance is in these challenging markets. The nimble execution that we have inside the presence that's around those businesses is really amazing. In 2003, those businesses, the energy and industrial businesses taken together, had about $377 million in revenue. And this year taken together, they had $303 million and yet the EBITDA margin in '14 was 32% of those combined businesses. And here this year, it's 31%. So despite a significant falloff in revenue, the margins have been able to be maintained. 
The second point of this slide is that, of course, our future in the nature of the enterprise you can see continues to compound towards the RF, the application software, the medical software and the medical products businesses, which now make up nearly 75% of the EBITDA of Roper's entire entity. And they also have done remarkably well. Two years ago, those businesses had about 39% EBITDA. Today, those businesses have about 41% EBITDA. 
Next slide. If we look at the first, our smallest segment, Energy Systems now is down to barely 10% of the company. And its organic growth was down 13% generally the way we thought it would be. The segment, while down, is expected really did modestly better than it did in the second quarter and is likely to do modestly better again in the fourth quarter. 
Terrific profitability. The OP margins in the second and third quarter were 25.4%, and EBITDA margins were 29.2%. 
When we look at the fourth quarter, we think oil and gas will be down about another 20% in this particular segment, same as it was in the third quarter, but we don't think we're going to get much growth in terms of fourth quarter seasonality. We didn't get much last year. But generally, it's been quite substantial, so we're sort of assuming that we won't get that this year. 
Margins will improve again in the fourth quarter. We started the year out in energy with 20.4% OP; second quarter went to 22.5%; the third quarter is already up to 25.4%; and the fourth quarter will be substantially materially above that. So these businesses still in our view represents sort of free shot on goal for us, and they only represent 10% or less of revenue. 
Next slide. On the Industrial Technology side, you can see that this is the -- fortunately, the last quarter we'll talk about this divestiture of ABEL. If you adjust for the divestiture, the segment was actually flat despite the upstream oil and gas piece that's in Industrial Technology being down 35%. So how did that happen? What happened from double-digit growth at Neptune, who continues to gain market share, and very strong demand for the R900 Automated Meter Reading and AMI technology with lots of migrating upgrades. We had a significant number of wins last quarter, over 10. And really, the $50 million that we put into R&D in the last 3 years in Neptune has gotten us into a very outstanding position that people will begin to appreciate just how much we've done and how far advanced we are going to be over the next couple of years in the space. 
We did get some sequential improvement at Roper Pump, and we expect to have a little bit better results again in the fourth quarter despite basically that -- 2 other businesses in here that are really purely related to upstream and have been severely hampered. 
The rest of our businesses in here are -- it's kind of test businesses are all doing relatively well. Some of them actually have record quarters. And on balance, we don't see any deterioration in those businesses. 
In the fourth quarter, we think we'll have sort of similar revenue and margin performance to what we had in the third quarter. And while upstream markets are sequentially flat, there is a tiny bit of improvement that we're seeing. 
Next slide. Here, we'll look at the RF Technology and Software segment. It's really increasingly right to think about 3 legs in this segment with the RF product side of activity, and then you have the tolling side of activity, and then you have all this application software business. And of course now in addition to that, with ConstructConnect. 
So here, the business' revenue was up 20% in the quarter. The operating profit was up 26%. The OP margin is 31.7%, but the EBITDA margin was 38%, up 230 basis points. 
We had organic growth of 7% in this segment and had about 1 point of foreign exchange headwind, and acquisitions helped by 14%. 
Very strong growth at toll and traffic on project activity in Florida and Texas and Pennsylvania. Sounds like swing states in the election. 
Continued high single-digit growth in Software led by freight matching and CBORD. We did some really exciting things at freight matching. We've moved to a more modern software-friendly location in the Portland, Oregon area, and then we've put together the freight matching network, so DAT in the U.S. and Getloaded, into a new software development process that's going to expand our customer base. 
We had double-digit growth in the RF products business. A lot of that's driven by senior living. There are several of our businesses that touch senior living. 
And then toll and traffic had -- would have had spectacular orders, of course, if we would have been able to book the bridge and toll project -- toll -- tunnel project, which we hoped would happen a little bit earlier in the year. We had a 5-year extension of our toll mandate in Dubai. And the Saudi project is sort of back on track. We wound up with about 30 installations here in the fourth quarter, we think, which will get us to about 70 of the 350. So we feel much better about the progress in Riyadh. 
In the fourth quarter, TransCore was awarded a $70 million plus MTA project to convert 9 bridges and tunnels around the 5 boroughs. All of you who go back and forth are now well aware of what that's like. There's like 800,000 people a day going through that process. And conversion with our Infinity Lane technology will allow people to not have tollbooths, and there'll be fines, of course, based on video tolling. But if you have your normal tool tank, you'll be able to get through. The growth in toll and traffic, we think, will continue to manifest itself in the fourth quarter and certainly, into 2017. 
The Software businesses universally remain strong. We had kind of mid-single-digit organic growth in the whole segment, which gives a really strong momentum going into '17, certainly the best position we've had in this segment in a long time. 
And now we've acquired ConstructConnect, which we'll talk about here in a second, for $632 million. Got about $150 million in revenue and sort of Roper-type expected EBITDA margins, which will get better as it gets inside the Roper -- the governance process. 
Next slide. So talking about ConstructConnect for a minute. We issued a separate press release on this. I think today is an interesting day in addition to being a record quarter. It's a record number of press releases for Roper. This is really an amazing business. When our teams made the trips in the diligence process and working with Dave Conway's staff, you get a work in there, training center, and you can watch the network live. It's really -- it's just like watching the floor or the exchange with all this activity going -- you realize how many people are interacting with this thing. They had $55 million of bid -- $1 billion of bid activity, and it's just remarkable. It's like our freight matching network works some things up for maybe 1, 1.2 seconds before it's grabbed by somebody else in the network. And here, you're seeing all this usage around the data, which is just unprecedented, that is inside the network that's accessible to everybody. So it's all cloud-based technology. 
The network allows people to see what projects are coming up. They can see what contractors form their own opinions about who might be competing for it, what the call-off is for everyone's specifications. They're also going to be benefited, by the way, because they will work together with our On Center business that was just for drywall construction only and their other niche things that are going to be able to fold into ConstructConnect going forward. 
Those 800,000 users, we're laughing about this. In preparation of the call, basically, there's 800,000 people that use the bridge and tunnels in New York every day, so we've decided that perhaps every person going through the tunnel represents a ConstructConnect user. This business is headquartered in Cincinnati. Its revenue for next year should be something hopefully above $150 million. It's -- it kind of generates something in the $50-plus million of EBITDA to us. And remember, lots of noncash amortization in these things. So terrific cash business. It'll meet all of our acquisition requirements. It's got a great management team. Dave has been running this business through its acquisition phase and through its evolutionary shaping of the preconstruction industry, so he really is the domain expert. Very high recurring revenue. It's a subscription business, so you have all of this great cash characteristics. It has deferred revenues. You have very few assets of any kind, and it really has multiple growth opportunities. And that's another reason why we found it to be a very attractive acquisition. I think a great home for ConstructConnect, who can now focus really on continuing to shape the evolution of the preconstruction industry. 
Next slide. The Medical and Scientific Imaging business. You can see here we were up 12%: 8% on acquisitions, 4% on organic. A little less than 1 point of negative FX, but rounded down as opposed to up. The medical businesses are 85% of the segment, and they grew organically at 5%. And interestingly throughout the year, the medical businesses have grown organically at 5%. Each one of the separate businesses are sort of hospital software, alternate site solutions business and the medical products, all 3 groups group, grew. 
Sunquest. The way we look at order intake is sort of different than bookings against the entire business because there's so much recurring revenue that doesn't really change from a bookings basis. But on an order intake basis, they had a record in the third quarter. It was up the most it's ever been. 
Scientific Imaging, which is about 15% in the second, did okay in the third quarter. It's had modest growth. But actually, it's a bifurcated situation, where the life science portion -- because of cryo-EM market opportunities grew over 100% in the quarter, while the physical science business continued to be pretty weak. It was down about 20%. So these -- the opportunity in front of these businesses is the best it's ever been. In the fourth quarter, we think we'll have continued mid-single-digit growth for the medical businesses, led really by the alternate site solutions business. 
Scientific Imaging, we think, will be terrific on demand and bookings for new products, but most of those probably will have early 2017 deliveries, which was another reason that -- maybe hit some here in the fourth quarter. We'll just have to see. But we're going to assume that mostly that's going to be a first half next year benefit. 
Okay. The next slide is the guidance update. Turn to page -- here's the specifics on the guidance. We're going to go in for the fourth quarter at $1.77 to $1.89. It's a broad range. Probably not really a broad range given how much money we make and how few shares we have. So seasonality in the industrial and energy business is not something that we think will help this year. We could be wrong about that. And if we get normal seasonality, then we'd be towards the higher the end of the range. 
The New York City MTA ramp is very important in the fourth quarter. There's a commitment to get the first 3 projects completed by January 1, and how that project ramps will have a direct effect on whether we're towards the low or the higher end of the guidance. And then customer preferences around delivery. We thought the third quarter orders were satisfactory, but not carrying immediate delivery kind of results. So I think there's some hesitancy in the industrial and energy markets about exactly when they want things that they're booked and committed to. 
The full year guidance, given the fourth quarter as addition to our year-to-date results, would give us somewhere around $6.48 to $6.60. I think most of our internal projections and external projections run around $6.55 to $6.60. 
3-year cash flow conversion will still be spectacular, 140% or so, and that will allow us despite terrific oil and gas headwinds this year to have 5% to 6% revenue and EBITDA growth for the year. 
Next slide. If we look at the summary of how we did in the third quarter, it's kind of a long list of good things. We got record orders revenue, net earnings EBITDA and cash flow. Four standout businesses there. Medical, Software, tolling and Neptune were quite good because remember, we got 20-plus negative on the energy side of the business. EBITDA got up to 34.6% of revenue, and our free cash flow was phenomenal. 
The New York City MTA bridge and tunnel All-Electronic Tolling project, we really expected to win this for some time, but the news about it, the commitment around it, didn't come until last Friday. So we have been planning for a Q4 kickoff, and we will do what we said we would do for them, which is to get the 3 projects done. But almost the vast majority of this work is going to come in 2017 and not in the fourth quarter. 
We acquired a great SaaS network business in ConstructConnect, and it, along with the things it can do with On Center in a cooperative way, will be very beneficial for us in 2017. 
The cash performance that we have year-to-date, along with the brand-new balance sheet with a much better credit facility, supports our continued ability to deploy capital. It's the most powder we've ever had, and the opportunities that we see are excellent. 
So we had outstanding results in the third quarter, and we're very well positioned for 2017 and ready to take your questions.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Deane Dray at RBC Capital.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Andrew Krill on for Deane. I want to start off on ConstructConnect. This is the second meaningful deal you guys have done recently in Software-as-a-Service after Aderant. I was wondering if you could talk about market share within construction and
componenttext: This is Andrew Krill on for Deane. I want to start off on ConstructConnect. This is the second meaningful deal you guys have done recently in Software-as-a-Service after Aderant. I was wondering if you could talk about market share within construction and if there any unique barriers to entry versus peers for the business.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well -- so this is John Humphrey. I -- so as far as barriers, I mean, the barrier, of course, for a network business is the strength and size of the network and the ability for all of the different users to be able to transact business and grow their own
componenttext: Well -- so this is John Humphrey. I -- so as far as barriers, I mean, the barrier, of course, for a network business is the strength and size of the network and the ability for all of the different users to be able to transact business and grow their own business by utilizing the ConstructConnect network and software solutions. And I think it goes to the size of the network. When Brian talked about 800,000 users and $55 million invitations to bid every year encompassing almost 400,000 different commercial construction projects, I mean, the size of the network and the combination that ConstructConnect has been able to put together between their different brands of iSqFt and BidClerk and Construct Data and really turn that into a single integrated platform, that's really unique inside the industry. So from a competitive position, I think for most of those customers, the way that they're able to grow their business and to bid on more projects and to win more is through connection to the ConstructConnect network. And so that's really the strength of that and the competitive position. There are a couple of competitors out there that also provide, particularly on the construction data side. But on the network and the integrated data, we really don't think there's anyone of size there.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. It's very helpful. And as a quick follow-up, do you have any sense of potential accretion? And then, I guess, kind of where do you guys think the EBITDA margin could eventually go versus the sort of 33% or so you're expecting next year?
componenttext: Okay, great. It's very helpful. And as a quick follow-up, do you have any sense of potential accretion? And then, I guess, kind of where do you guys think the EBITDA margin could eventually go versus the sort of 33% or so you're expecting next year?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we still have a lot of work to do by -- and we're going to close on the transaction. But as we're thinking about it, it's probably somewhere in the $0.10 to $0.15 accretive for next year. We'll be able to update you on that, of course, as we finaliz
componenttext: Well, we still have a lot of work to do by -- and we're going to close on the transaction. But as we're thinking about it, it's probably somewhere in the $0.10 to $0.15 accretive for next year. We'll be able to update you on that, of course, as we finalize the purchase accounting. And the margin profile here is also very good, right? We're talking about something that's already in the mid-30% EBITDA margin. And so as it continues to grow, it will grow with high incremental margins. And so that's how we see the margin progression over time as this network continues to get bigger.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to add to the understanding that these acquisitions have a lot of noncash amortization. So on a GAAP DEPS basis, people are looking at expensing that amortization and depressing what otherwise looks like earnings per share. The reality is it'l
componenttext: I just want to add to the understanding that these acquisitions have a lot of noncash amortization. So on a GAAP DEPS basis, people are looking at expensing that amortization and depressing what otherwise looks like earnings per share. The reality is it'll be very cash-accretive. But on a GAAP DEPS basis, it may only add $0.10 or $0.15. I think you get paid as a shareholder for monitoring what's happening to the quality of the cash earnings. The cash earnings of ConstructConnect will be great.

componenttext: I guess, first, just talking about -- and again, congratulations on a very strong cash generation quarter. These questions will relate, obviously, to DEPS. But in terms of the medical cadence for the fourth quarter in energy, could you just expand on your comments about what kind of brought the guy down for the fourth quarter?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think 2 things in terms of DEPS is that it's just our view of that is we're not going to get much in the way of seasonality. When we look at the orders that came in the third quarter, we'll get a lot of bookments. And we call them bookments so they're b
componenttext: I think 2 things in terms of DEPS is that it's just our view of that is we're not going to get much in the way of seasonality. When we look at the orders that came in the third quarter, we'll get a lot of bookments. And we call them bookments so they're booked within a quarter, shipped within the next quarter. And we didn't see any uptick in that, that would give us a reason to think we'd have normalized Q4 seasonality. But we could be wrong about that, but that would be upside that could happen to us. So I think it's that more than any one item. And then we've been ready to go on a couple of projects that we expect, and we're ready to [indiscernible].

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Energy is not particularly surprising, but the medical cadence. Could you just expand upon that? Because I think your expectation was kind of high single-digit growth as kind of an exit rate for fourth quarter.
componenttext: Energy is not particularly surprising, but the medical cadence. Could you just expand upon that? Because I think your expectation was kind of high single-digit growth as kind of an exit rate for fourth quarter.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Robert, I think you're right about that. And once again, it goes back to what Brian was talking about. We will get the product orders so -- and I'm talking specifically around medical products. Where we expected that kind of last time we talked that
componenttext: Yes. Robert, I think you're right about that. And once again, it goes back to what Brian was talking about. We will get the product orders so -- and I'm talking specifically around medical products. Where we expected that kind of last time we talked that the exit, closer to the 10% growth rate. That's exiting closer to the 5% growth rate. And that combined with the timing of imaging the orders and delivery. So all the life science things that Brian talked about earlier, those are actually very sophisticated instruments and cameras and filters that aren't as kind of the -- it's not just like machining and creating a pump. So the process in order to be able to turn that from order to delivery can easily be a 60, 90, 120 days depending on yield and throughput, particularly from suppliers around some of the sensors. And so as we look at the deliveries and the delivery schedule, particularly on the imaging product side and also on the medical product side, that's where we see a slight difference from what we would have thought before. But we still see this segment exiting at the mid-single-digit rate, very consistent with where it has been over the past 2.5 years.

componenttext: Okay. So you see no underlying deterioration in the core organic growth rate of that segment?

componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the M&A pipeline, obviously, you've transacted on a very interesting deal this quarter. But I mean, what's the state of play in terms of how you look over the next kind of 12 to 18 months in terms of capacity to do deals and the environment to get deals done? Because it has been, in the main, kind of a difficult environment to get deals done.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- if you go back to January '15, in that 21-month period, we've deployed $2.7 billion in capital. I mean, in the next 21-month period or much sooner, I would think that, that kind of run rate is very possible. We've got not hundreds of millions
componenttext: Yes. The -- if you go back to January '15, in that 21-month period, we've deployed $2.7 billion in capital. I mean, in the next 21-month period or much sooner, I would think that, that kind of run rate is very possible. We've got not hundreds of millions but billions of dollars of capital to be able to put to work. And getting the new $2.5 billion revolver, which is undrawn and done, was a big deal because it's given us some flexibility around we -- how much we can deploy at any one point in time, and that's very helpful. So there are a number of small deals that we're engaged with at the moment and a couple of larger transactions, which would be even bigger than ConstructConnect that we're involved with that we think are very attractive. So you never know in terms of your word, cadence, how that will happen. But I'd be very, very surprised if we didn't deploy quite a bit of capital in the next 12 months.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: The final question is just around -- you've heard this many times, but would you consider doing something akin to what some of your competitors have -- ostensibly not competitors, but public comps in terms of perhaps just shifting to an EPS, excluding amo
componenttext: The final question is just around -- you've heard this many times, but would you consider doing something akin to what some of your competitors have -- ostensibly not competitors, but public comps in terms of perhaps just shifting to an EPS, excluding amortization?

componenttext: Well, there's a lot of smiling in the room because that's the proper way to measure us. I guess, we're not interested in stepping on the SEC. Those people that are doing that, if they can continue to do it for a longer time and the SEC doesn't say anything about it, that's a smart thing to do because it's the proper way to measure the business. It's just not the way GAAP measures the earnings. So we had $50 million of amortization in the third quarter. And what do we have? 101 million or 102 million of shares. You can do the math. I'm apparently not allowed to say what that math generates. EBITA earnings per share for the company will be and are spectacular.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you get the sense that given where rates are and when you're looking at deals, are you having to stretch a little bit more in terms of multiple because competitors, who are looking at the same assets are able to kind of do some funny math with the rate
componenttext: Do you get the sense that given where rates are and when you're looking at deals, are you having to stretch a little bit more in terms of multiple because competitors, who are looking at the same assets are able to kind of do some funny math with the rates being here in terms of returns?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I wish it were funny math. It wasn't funny math. The difference is we don't like to go above like 4x debt to EBITDA. And those guys are willing to take debt staples and bank split-on things, and nonbank entities split-on things had 8x EBITDA, right?
componenttext: Well, I wish it were funny math. It wasn't funny math. The difference is we don't like to go above like 4x debt to EBITDA. And those guys are willing to take debt staples and bank split-on things, and nonbank entities split-on things had 8x EBITDA, right? So they don't deploy much more equity in a transaction than we do. We just don't want to have 7 or 8x debt to EBITDA. We're going to remain investment-grade. And to do that, you want to be around 4x debt to EBITDA, coming back to 3%, 3.5% or something. So we're very disciplined about wanting to and guaranteeing ourselves to maintain an investment-grade status. The prices that people are paying for things are really bifurcated. Oddly enough, the industrial assets are trading really more than they're worth in a normalized interest environment in a M&A world because they don't have a lot of EBITDA, even though they'll require a lot of capital spending to maintain that EBITDA. So those multiples are interestingly high. Then the asset-light business has traded a premium to that, but the arbitrage for us on the asset-light businesses is more favorable than those people that are buying the more capital-intensive businesses. So something like ConstructConnect is -- will be a long-term compounder of investment for us, which is great, as opposed to the guys that are buying the capital-intensive businesses thinking that, gee, it looks like I'm paying a lot, but they're at the [indiscernible] of their cyclical activity. And when there's a desired number, this will happen, and we'll leave that field to everybody else. It's not where we're going.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on Neptune as well. I mean, the results this quarter, obviously, very, very strong. There's this story up there that's been out there for a while. They're not about a lack of investment. You talk about 5 -- $50 million of M&A. Can y
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on Neptune as well. I mean, the results this quarter, obviously, very, very strong. There's this story up there that's been out there for a while. They're not about a lack of investment. You talk about 5 -- $50 million of M&A. Can you just talk about your positioning there on the highest technology-type products, like AMI development, and how you're capitalizing on your installed base? I mean, the numbers speak for themselves, but this has kind of been out there for a while. And I guess, maybe give you guys a chance to address that.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think I'm not -- $50 million was what we've done in R&D, not M&A.
componenttext: Yes. I think I'm not -- $50 million was what we've done in R&D, not M&A.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I'm sorry if I misspoke, yes.
componenttext: Right. I'm sorry if I misspoke, yes.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In the last 3 years, we put $50 million to work there. We're also opening a new software development center for Neptune that will really help us in a lot of things we're doing. So we're not going to provide a lot of information about what we're doing
componenttext: Yes. In the last 3 years, we put $50 million to work there. We're also opening a new software development center for Neptune that will really help us in a lot of things we're doing. So we're not going to provide a lot of information about what we're doing, but I can just suggest to you that we have the best reading technology that's available. It has the highest integrity results. We have an enormous installed base. And maybe people forget that the way our R900 product works, we can upgrade that, the AMI status, and there's a lot of ways to collect the technology. But if you've got the right core unit that can use multiple ways of gathering the data, you'd be a little bit ahead of the game. So we're able to do upgrades for people in the AMI arena that they always -- if they ever were migrating to it, they do that. And we won a lot of it. There's over $3 million of that just in the third quarter. You saw other things. You see mobile activity. You see Verizon picking us as the person that they're working with development on mobile technology. So there's a lot of different things going on, and we're not going to provide more information than we have around that. But we're -- this -- Neptune will have record performance in 2016. So if anybody thought it didn't have some kind of long-term reason for performing well, explain to me why they're growing so much.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair enough. And last, if I could. John, you talked last quarter about -- when we were talking about Sunquest some small hospitals you were -- that we're taking maybe Epic on, and you said that made sense for that size of a customer and your core b
componenttext: That's fair enough. And last, if I could. John, you talked last quarter about -- when we were talking about Sunquest some small hospitals you were -- that we're taking maybe Epic on, and you said that made sense for that size of a customer and your core being large hospitals. Can you just talk about how that went through, through 3Q? Has it kind of stabilized? And the customer base that you focus on, you remain to be -- the capture rate there is being consistent?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it has been consistent. And you're absolutely right. Brian talked about the order intake, right? So remember that fully, 2/3 if not more of Sunquest revenue is recurring revenue in terms of maintenance on installed software that's already been out th
componenttext: Yes, it has been consistent. And you're absolutely right. Brian talked about the order intake, right? So remember that fully, 2/3 if not more of Sunquest revenue is recurring revenue in terms of maintenance on installed software that's already been out there. And so when we look at the order intake, it's a much smaller piece of their total revenue buy. But when they look at their order intake, which is about the new Lab 8.0, it's about the new blood bank solution, it's the new outreach solution, so the nurses can start the testing process right at the bedside and be able to start that data flow and workflow to the lab right from the bedside. So all of those upgrades are driving that order intake to be a record level for the third quarter. It is true that on the lower end, the smaller hospitals and integrated solution can make economic sense for them, but the competitive environment and the solution that Sunquest delivers is -- continues to be very good, and our competitive position continues to be very strong, particularly in those larger hospitals.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Brian Gesuale at Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Brian Gesuale at Raymond James.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could expand a little bit on Sunquest. You talked about record orders. Maybe just the richness of this product upgrade cycle that we've seen and maybe give us a little bit of a preface as what we might expect in 2017.
componenttext: Wondering if you could expand a little bit on Sunquest. You talked about record orders. Maybe just the richness of this product upgrade cycle that we've seen and maybe give us a little bit of a preface as what we might expect in 2017.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's early to talk about 2017. We actually have a review coming up with Sunquest in about a month. We will be talking about not only 2017, but importantly, 2018 and 2019 and the plans that they have around the investments there. And so one is the
componenttext: I think it's early to talk about 2017. We actually have a review coming up with Sunquest in about a month. We will be talking about not only 2017, but importantly, 2018 and 2019 and the plans that they have around the investments there. And so one is the -- is what I was kind of just mentioning in terms of the continued on the upgrade side around Lab 8.0 and the new blood bank solution. But also, I wouldn't ignore the investments that we've made around genetic testing and the workflows associated with that. So you really have the blood side, which is the core lab high-volume testing environment that every hospital has to have. And the other side, which is anatomic pathology and the emerging genetic workflows around genetic testing. That's where we've made important investments with the acquisition of GeneInsight and continued R&D around being able to make that workflow as efficient and as quick with getting the information back to the doctor as timely as happens today on the blood side. And so for all those reasons, I think the Sunquest and our entire platform of hospital software solutions, which, of course, includes Data Innovations and CliniSys and GeneInsight and a variety of other things, all of those businesses really deliver those software solutions to hospitals. I think their future looks very bright as a result of the investments that we continue to make there.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. Maybe just to follow up on the M&A pipeline. It sounds robust. You certainly have a lot of dry powder. Can you maybe talk about the quality of those deals? Some of the -- this ConstructConnect looks very asset-light, negative workin
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. Maybe just to follow up on the M&A pipeline. It sounds robust. You certainly have a lot of dry powder. Can you maybe talk about the quality of those deals? Some of the -- this ConstructConnect looks very asset-light, negative working capital. It appears that the quality is actually increasing as the pipeline is. Could you maybe discuss that?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You can really see that when you look at that net working capital chart, where you're down at 5.8%. People think you could never get lower, and now we're at 1.9%. Certainly, a lot of that as you get deferred revenue and you get paid in advance for wo
componenttext: Yes. You can really see that when you look at that net working capital chart, where you're down at 5.8%. People think you could never get lower, and now we're at 1.9%. Certainly, a lot of that as you get deferred revenue and you get paid in advance for work you do, and most of the things that we look at these days have those qualities. So we -- I thought it enough if we get to 0 or ultimately negative at some point, but I don't see us going up. The amount of small niche businesses that work in kind of oligopolies or customer industry is critical, and then those that have the ability to have kind of a network effect, there are more of those things out there than you might imagine because when you're focused on product businesses, you don't necessarily see some of these kind of things. But all of the people that are involved in transactions in the banking businesses and the private equity businesses kind of know what we favor, what we look like, and so the funnel that we have of incoming opportunity is really amazing. And it's just incumbent on us to sort through that funnel, find the best management teams and the best end market opportunities there in favorably competitive environments. And believe me, there is more high-quality things available that our balance sheet could tolerate. Fortunately, we got a big-enough balance sheet to capture some of them.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, could you just talk for a minute or 2 about the New York MTA contract? I think you had mentioned 3 sites should be performed in the fourth quarter kind of accelerated. Given the size of that contract, are we talking about maybe $20 million to $25 m
componenttext: Brian, could you just talk for a minute or 2 about the New York MTA contract? I think you had mentioned 3 sites should be performed in the fourth quarter kind of accelerated. Given the size of that contract, are we talking about maybe $20 million to $25 million of revenue in the fourth quarter? And then the balance of the sites, the other 6 sites, is that all falling into the first half of '17?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. I think commitment to the contract is pretty specific in terms of what they've been willing to release and will -- it'll be done by November of 2017 is what we're told. There was really even one -- remember, you got to like ramp, right? So we'
componenttext: No, no, no. I think commitment to the contract is pretty specific in terms of what they've been willing to release and will -- it'll be done by November of 2017 is what we're told. There was really even one -- remember, you got to like ramp, right? So we've been doing some engineering work with them to assure that the overhead kiosks and everything that are being built in are going to be okay, so it will start slow. I don't know, maybe we could get $10 million in the fourth quarter of revenue that we have, with the rest being -- but whatever it is, it's about $72 million for the entire period. And it'll be really up to them at the pace they want us to do the installation and release the technology.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And just the -- this is the last question I have. It's just around MHA. There's a lot of noise around drug pricing, both generic as well as branded. And then also, I noticed in the slide that you had -- that there was a suggestion that t
componenttext: Okay, understood. And just the -- this is the last question I have. It's just around MHA. There's a lot of noise around drug pricing, both generic as well as branded. And then also, I noticed in the slide that you had -- that there was a suggestion that the alternative site solutions business would kind of be a leader here in the fourth quarter. Just -- can you just kind of pull all that together? Has the noise around drug pricing impacted just the revenue stream in the pass-through there at MHA? And then also, with this alternative site solutions business being kind of the fourth quarter leader, is there timing there? Or is there contract renewals? Or what would drive that in the fourth quarter?

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So in terms of its contribution on the growth side, it was up in the kind of 3% or 4% in the third quarter, and we expect that to be modestly better in the fourth quarter. From a drug pricing standpoint, I mean, you're right, that is something
componenttext: Yes, sure. So in terms of its contribution on the growth side, it was up in the kind of 3% or 4% in the third quarter, and we expect that to be modestly better in the fourth quarter. From a drug pricing standpoint, I mean, you're right, that is something that we look at. A lot of the headlines that you see around drug pricing aren't really targeted for or being sold to the senior population. Remember, MHA is around alternate site health care, and the largest portion of their revenue is coming from skilled nursing homes, long-term care facilities. It's not really the headline prices around EpiPen or whatever else that you might read in the Wall Street Journal. It's really for kind of the longer chronic illnesses that are being sold through the MHA contracting vehicles. So we do look at drug pricing. It's been lower than what we would have seen in years past, but still positive in 2016. We're not counting on an awful lot of drug pricing lift as we think about the future for MHA. They continue to expand their solutions in nondrug supply chains, including food and other things for our long-term care facilities and other nursing homes. So they continue to expand that and then also expand their software solutions around data analytics. You've seen us make a couple of acquisitions that also serve the alternate site health care, which are not GPO but are really around software solutions that allow those members and customers to run their businesses more efficiently. That's where we look for growth. We don't really count on underlying drug price increases as something that is going to drive our performance, although it does have an impact on our revenue.

headline: Roper Technologies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
